title = Other | content = *[[Clannad (film)|''Clannad'' film]] }} {{Infobox animanga/Footer}} {{Nihongo|'''''Clannad'''''|クラナド|Kuranado}} is a Japanese [[visual novel]] developed by [[Key (company)|Key]] and released on April 28, 2004 for [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] [[Personal computer|PCs]]. While both of Key's first two previous works, ''[[Kanon (visual novel)|Kanon]]'' and ''[[Air (visual novel)|Air]]'', had been released first as [[Eroge|adult games]] and then censored for the younger market, ''Clannad'' was released with a rating for all ages. It was later [[Porting|ported]] to the [[PlayStation 2]], [[PlayStation Portable]], [[Xbox 360]], [[PlayStation 3]], [[PlayStation Vita]] and [[PlayStation 4]] consoles. An English version for Windows was released on [[Steam (software)|Steam]] by [[Sekai Project]] in 2015. The story follows the life of [[List of Clannad characters#Tomoya Okazaki|Tomoya Okazaki]], an average high school student who meets many people in his last year at school, including five girls, and helps resolve their individual problems. The [[gameplay]] of ''Clannad'' follows a [[Nonlinear gameplay#Branching storylines|branching plot line]] which offers pre-determined scenarios with courses of interaction, and focuses on the appeal of the five female main characters by the [[player character]]. The game was ranked as the best-selling PC game sold in Japan for the time of its release, and charted in the national top 50 several more times afterwards. Key went on to produce an adult [[Spin-off (media)|spin-off]] titled ''[[Tomoyo After: It's a Wonderful Life]]'' in November 2005, which expanded on the scenario of [[List of Clannad characters#Tomoyo Sakagami|Tomoyo Sakagami]], one of the five heroines from ''Clannad''. ''Clannad'' has made several transitions to other media. There have been four [[manga]] adaptations published by [[ASCII Media Works]], [[Flex Comix]], [[Fujimi Shobo]] and [[Jive (publisher)|Jive]]. [[Comic anthology|Comic anthologies]], [[light novel]]s and [[art book]]s have also been published, as have [[audio drama]]s and several albums of music. An animated film by [[Toei Animation]] was released in September 2007, followed by two [[anime]] series including two [[original video animation]] (OVA) episodes by [[Kyoto Animation]] produced between 2007 and 2009. Both anime series and their accompanying OVAs are licensed by [[Sentai Filmworks]] and were released in North America in 2009. The animated adaptations have received high sales figures in Japan as well as critical acclaim abroad. ==Gameplay== [[File:Nagisa Furukawa Key screenshot.png|thumb|200px|left|Average dialogue and narrative in ''Clannad'' depicting the main character Tomoya talking to Nagisa.]] ''Clannad'' is a [[drama]] and [[Romance (love)|romance]] [[visual novel]] in which the player assumes the role of Tomoya Okazaki. Much of its [[gameplay]] is spent on reading the story's [[narrative]] and [[dialogue]]. ''Clannad'' follows a [[Nonlinear gameplay#Branching storylines|branching plot line]] with multiple endings; depending on the decisions that the player makes during the game, the plot will progress in a specific direction. There are six main plot lines that the player will have the chance to experience, five which are initially available.{{cite video game|title=Clannad|developer=[[Key (company)|Key]]|publisher=[[VisualArt's]]|platform=[[Microsoft Windows|Windows]]|language=Japanese}} Throughout gameplay, the player is given multiple options to choose from, and text progression pauses at these points until a choice is made. To view all plot lines in their entirety, the player must replay the game multiple times and make different choices to change the plot progression. When first playing the game, the scenarios for all five heroines and additional smaller scenarios are available in what is called the School Life [[story arc]]. When the player completes a character's scenario, he or she receives an [[Orb (optics)|orb]] of light. When eight of these lights are obtained, the game's second story arc, called After Story, is made available. One of the lights disappears during School Life, but reappears in After Story. To view the true ending of ''Clannad'', all 13 lights must be obtained. Originally, the lights were meant to be items that players could use in the game, but since this increased the game's complexity, and detracted from the storyline, the function of the lights was simplified and made less intrusive. ==Plot== ===Setting and themes=== The first half of the story takes place primarily at Hikarizaka Private High School, a fictional school located in Japan. Outside of the school, frequented locations include the bakery run by Nagisa's parents, and the dormitory where [[List of Clannad characters#Youhei Sunohara|Youhei Sunohara]] lives. Throughout the story, glimpses into an Illusionary World are shown. This world is devoid of all life except for a young girl, though she later makes a body out of junk pieces through which the player can interact with her. The remaining half of the story takes place in the same city, after the conclusion of the first half. While the town's name was never directly mentioned, one can infer that the town's name is Hikarizaka based on the many companies and establishments that share this name. There are recurring themes that appear throughout the story. The main theme is the value of having a family, as the title of the series implies because the main scenario writer [[Jun Maeda]] mistakenly thought the name of the [[Clannad|Irish band Clannad]] meant "clan" or "family" in [[Irish language|Irish]].{{cite book|title=pre-Clannad|publisher=[[SoftBank|SoftBank Creative]]|isbn=4-7973-2723-5|id={{ASIN|4797327235|country=jp}}|date=April 15, 2004|language=Japanese}} Of the six main characters, Tomoya, Nagisa, and Kotomi have no siblings, though their parents are major factors in their stories. Nagisa's story was written to incorporate what Maeda described as a "perfect family" with a focus on mental consciousness. In Nagisa's story, there is a recurring appearance of {{Nihongo|"The Big [[Dango]] Family"|だんご大家族|Dango Daikazoku}} (a fictional group [[mascot]] for children) that Nagisa is fond of. Tomoya's and Nagisa's characters were written in a style to exemplify a "growth to adulthood" by the end of the story. Fuko's and Kyou's stories have their sisters playing an integral part, and Tomoyo's story is influenced by her entire family. A minor motif of Irish words continues with the opening theme of the game, "[[Mag Mell]]", which means roughly "plain of joy" and is connected with Irish mythology.{{cite book|author=MacKillop, James|title=Dictionary of Celtic Mythology|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2004|isbn=0-19-860967-1}} The [[Arrangement|arrange]] album, a short music CD that contained remixed versions of songs in the game, that was bundled with the original game release was titled ''[[Mabinogion|Mabinogi]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.product.co.jp/?enter=1&page=1&id=159|title=''Clannad'' PC limited edition official listing|publisher=[[VisualArt's]]|accessdate=June 6, 2009|language=Japanese}} which was a collection of [[prose]] stories from [[medieval]] [[Welsh language|Welsh]] [[manuscript]]s.{{cite book|author=Guest, Lady Charlotte|title=The Mabinogion|publisher=Dover Publications|year=1997|isbn=0-486-29541-9}} ===Main characters=== {{main article|List of Clannad characters}} The player assumes the role of [[List of Clannad characters#Tomoya Okazaki|Tomoya Okazaki]], the protagonist of ''Clannad''. Tomoya has been labeled a [[Juvenile delinquency|delinquent]]; at the beginning of the story, he even expresses hatred toward the city he has lived in all his life where ''Clannad'' is set. He is very straightforward in his comments to others and will not hesitate to speak his mind, even if he comes off as rude during such times. Despite this, Tomoya is loyal to his friends, and has been known to dedicate himself for those around him in need of help or support. He generally has a selfless personality and does not ask much from others in return for what he does for them. Tomoya meets [[Nagisa Furukawa]], the main heroine of ''Clannad'', at the onset of the story. Nagisa is a shy girl who has an illness which causes her to rely on those around her for support. She has developed the strange habit of muttering the names of favorite foods that she plans to eat as a way to motivate herself, such as [[anpan]]. [[Kyou Fujibayashi]], another of ''Clannad''{{'s}} heroines, is a loud, aggressive girl well known as a good cook among her friends and family. When angry she does not hesitate to throw a dictionary at people that she often carries around for such purposes. Despite this attitude, she also has a more subdued side, especially towards her younger [[Twin#Dizygotic twins|fraternal twin]] sister [[List of Clannad characters#Ryou Fujibayashi|Ryou Fujibayashi]]. Tomoya meets a [[genius]] girl named [[List of Clannad characters#Kotomi Ichinose|Kotomi Ichinose]], one day in the school library. She is ranked in the top 10 throughout the whole country in standardized exam results of every subject—she always goes to library to read extra materials, especially books in foreign languages. Kotomi is a quiet girl with poor social skills and it is quite difficult to communicate with her; Kotomi can even completely ignore someone when reading, even if they make loud disturbances around her. ''Clannad''{{'s}} fourth heroine is a second-year student named [[List of Clannad characters#Tomoyo Sakagami|Tomoyo Sakagami]] who transfers into Tomoya's school. Tomoyo is known to be a strong fighter, preferring to use kicking over punching, and is athletic. Although Tomoya is older than her, Tomoyo does not show him respect as a senior student. Tomoyo appears in Key's fifth game, ''[[Tomoyo After: It's a Wonderful Life]]'', as the main heroine.{{cite web|url=http://key.visualarts.gr.jp/product/tomoyo/character/|title=''Tomoyo After'' official character bios|publisher=[[Key (company)|Key]]|accessdate=May 29, 2009|language=Japanese}} The last heroine in ''Clannad'' is a first-year student named [[Fuko Ibuki]] who is eccentric and childish, before she met Tomoya, was generally seen alone by herself making wood carvings of [[starfish]] with a small knife to give to others as presents. Fuko is extremely enthralled by starfish, or things that are star-shaped, and will often go into short [[euphoria (emotion)|euphoric]] bouts where her awareness of her surroundings is completely overtaken. ===Story=== ''Clannad''{{'s}} story revolves around Tomoya Okazaki, a third year high school student who dislikes his life. Tomoya's mother (Atsuko) died when Tomoya was young, leaving his father (Naoyuki) to raise him. After the accident, Tomoya's father turned to [[alcoholism|alcohol]] and [[Problem gambling|gambling]], and had frequent fights with his son. One day, Naoyuki, while arguing with his son, slammed Tomoya against the window, dislocating Tomoya's shoulder. This injury prevents Tomoya from playing on the basketball team, and causes him to distance himself from others. Ever since then, his father has treated Tomoya nicely, but distantly, as if Tomoya and he were strangers rather than a family. This hurts Tomoya more than his previous relationship with his father, and the awkwardness of returning home leads Tomoya constantly to stay out all night. Thus his delinquent life begins. Tomoya's good friend Youhei Sunohara, who was thrown out of the soccer club over a dispute with his seniors, is also a delinquent and often hangs out in his dorm room with Tomoya doing nothing much. The story opens on Monday April 14, 2003 at the beginning of the school year, when Tomoya meets Nagisa Furukawa, a soft-spoken girl who is one year older than he is but is repeating her last year in high school due to being sick much of the previous year. Her goal is to join the drama club which she was unable to do due to her sickness, but they find that the drama club was disbanded after the few remaining members graduated. Since Tomoya has a lot of time to kill, he helps Nagisa in reforming the drama club. During this period, Tomoya meets and hangs out with several other girls whom he gets to know well and help with their individual problems. ====After Story==== In the second part of the story, which starts immediately after the end of the first part but extends into the next seven years, Tomoya and Nagisa start living together, and eventually get married. Tomoya has to endure several hardships that the family has been suffering from, especially Nagisa's illness. Just after Nagisa gives birth to their daughter [[List of Clannad characters#Ushio Okazaki|Ushio]], she [[Maternal mortality in fiction|dies]], which causes Tomoya to become severely depressed. He is barely able to function, let alone look after an infant. As a result, Nagisa's parents, [[List of Clannad characters#Akio Furukawa|Akio]] and [[List of Clannad characters#Sanae Furukawa|Sanae]], take care of their granddaughter. Five years later, Tomoya meets with [[List of Clannad characters#Shino Okazaki|Shino Okazaki]], his paternal grandmother. Shino tells Tomoya of his father's traumatic past, which is eerily similar to Tomoya's current situation. Afterwards, Tomoya resolves to raise Ushio and acknowledges Naoyuki as his father. Shortly after Tomoya overcomes his depression, Ushio is stricken with the same disease that Nagisa had. Tomoya, Sanae and Akio struggle to save her—Tomoya even quits his job—but all of their efforts turn out to be in vain. In the coming winter, wanting to do anything for his daughter, Tomoya takes her on a trip, but she dies shortly after. Tomoya's psychology is developed in his dreams of a bleak world, called the {{Nihongo|Illusionary World|幻想世界|Gensō Sekai}}, where small orbs of light float around. In the first few dreams, he sees a world devoid of all life, except for one girl. Each time he dreams, he finds out more about the world. Tomoya discovers that the girl has a special ability to fuse junk together to create new things, which she uses to create a body for him. Over time, Tomoya comes to the conclusion that only the two of them are "alive". To pass time, Tomoya and the girl try to build another doll with more junk they find, but as it has no soul, it fails to come to life. Remembering the distant world where he came from, Tomoya convinces the girl to build a ship so that the two can escape the approaching winter and continue to live a happy life. Eventually, winter sets in, and the girl becomes cold to the point where she cannot move any more. The girl tells Tomoya that he has another chance to go back and make things right. To do so, he must collect certain "lights" (symbols of happiness) similar to those floating around in the Illusionary World. If all the "lights" are collected throughout both story parts, a chance to save Nagisa from dying will become available, as well as the true ending, where she survives and lives with Tomoya and Ushio. ==Development== The executive producer for ''Clannad'' was Takahiro Baba from [[VisualArt's]], the publishing company which controls Key. [[Jun Maeda]], who was one of three main scenario writers with Kai, and [[Yūichi Suzumoto]], led the planning for ''Clannad'' and wrote the majority of the scenarios. Scenario assistance was provided by Tōya Okano. [[Itaru Hinoue]] headed the art direction, and also worked on the character design.{{cite web|url=http://erogamescape.ddo.jp/~ap2/ero/toukei_kaiseki/game.php?game=3454|title=Clannad staff information|publisher=ErogameScape|accessdate=June 8, 2007|language=Japanese|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120719141645/http://erogamescape.ddo.jp/~ap2/ero/toukei_kaiseki/game.php?game=3454|archivedate=July 19, 2012|df=}} Miracle Mikipon, Mochisuke, [[Na-Ga]], and Shinory supplemented the [[computer graphics]]. Torino provided the background art. The game's music was [[composer|composed]] by Maeda, [[Shinji Orito]], and [[Magome Togoshi]]. For Key's second visual novel ''[[Air (visual novel)|Air]]'', Maeda admitted he felt he was able to write what he wanted to for the game's scenario, but he later discovered that ''Air'' was difficult for players to receive and experience. Due to this, Maeda felt that for Key's next work ''Clannad'', he had a sense of duty to make the game easier to receive for as many users as possible. In any case, he wanted to make it an entertaining game, and started planning on ''Clannad'' almost immediately after ''Air''{{'}}s completion. From the start of ''Clannad''{{'}}s planning, Maeda did not want to write a story like in ''Air'', but instead wanted to focus on writing a deep connection between the 'people and the town', and 'humanity'.{{cite book|title=Clannad Visual Fan Book|publisher=[[Enterbrain]]|year=2004|isbn=978-4-7577-2025-1|id={{ASIN|4757720254|country=jp}}}} Maeda noted that he exceeded his writing ability when writing most of the scenarios in ''Clannad'', and equates ''Clannad''{{'}}s writing process as a "wall that I will never be able to get over again."{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011213916/http://gs.dengekinet.com/ranking/maker.html |url=http://gs.dengeki.com/ranking/maker.html |title=Jun Maeda comments on ''Clannad''{{'}}s popularity |publisher=[[ASCII Media Works]] |archivedate=October 11, 2007 |accessdate=October 25, 2008 |language=Japanese |deadurl=yes |df= }} While at the beginning Maeda felt he was prepared, the entire game's story started to increase to a level Maeda never predicted, and Suzumoto noted that it approximately doubled in size from the original projected length. Suzumoto attributed the increase due to the lengthening structure of the game's base scenario which caused the 'branch' scenarios to increase as well. There were more concerns about ''Clannad'' being similar to ''Air''. When Nagisa's scenario was being written, there were some disputes concerning the length of her scenario, and thus putting too much focus on the main heroine. Some were concerned that having a single prominent character with a unique storyline would be too much like how ''Air'' was structured with the overall focus on [[Air (visual novel)#Main characters|Misuzu Kamio]]. Takahiro Baba, the company president of VisualArt's, is even noted as suggesting to minimize the differences between the other characters' scenarios, but this was ultimately ignored since Maeda thought the game's evaluation by players would not decrease on account of the scenarios being vastly different, and thought the end result was a good one. Maeda was concerned that the After Story arc, mainly a continuation of Nagisa's scenario, would eclipse the entire game's scenario, much like what happened with ''Air'' according to Maeda. In order to prevent the same thing happening in ''Clannad'', Maeda focused on making the first half of the story, the School Life arc, just as enjoyable by making it long and heart-breaking. ''Clannad'' is Key's second longest work, as reported by [[Yūto Tonokawa]] where he stated that ''Clannad'' is about 4,000 words fewer than Key's 2008 game ''[[Little Busters!|Little Busters! Ecstasy]]''.{{cite web|author= [[Yūto Tonokawa]]|url= http://key.visualarts.gr.jp/diary/2008/06/post_22.html|title=''Little Busters EX'' Development Journal|publisher=[[Key (company)|Key]]|date=June 26, 2008|accessdate=August 16, 2008|language=Japanese}} ===Release history=== Key announced in 2001 a release date of 2002{{cite web|url=http://key.visualarts.gr.jp/newsoft/ng_top.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20011213220308/http://key.visualarts.gr.jp/newsoft/ng_top.htm|title=''Clannad'' introduction website|publisher=[[Key (company)|Key]]|archivedate=December 13, 2001|accessdate=November 22, 2008|language=Japanese}} for ''Clannad'' and, after several postponements, ''Clannad'' was released on April 28, 2004 as a limited edition version, playable on a [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] [[Personal computer|PC]] as a DVD.{{cite web|url=http://key.visualarts.gr.jp/product/clannad/|title=Clannad's official visual novel website|publisher=[[Key (company)|Key]]|accessdate=January 30, 2008|language=Japanese}}{{cite web|url=http://www.product.co.jp/products/item/159/|title=Clannad 初回限定版|trans-title=Clannad limited edition|publisher=[[VisualArt's]]|accessdate=December 15, 2014|language=Japanese}} The limited edition came bundled with the [[remix album]] ''[[List of Clannad soundtracks#Mabinogi|Mabinogi]]'' remixing background music tracks featured in the visual novel. Comic Vol. 35|publisher=[[ASCII Media Works]]|accessdate=April 29, 2014|language=Japanese}} ASCII Media Works published five volumes for Shaa's ''Clannad'' manga under their [[Dengeki Comics]] [[imprint (trade name)|imprint]] between February 27, 2008 and July 26, 2014.{{cite book |title=''Clannad'' 1 (Dengeki Comics)|publisher=| language=Japanese |isbn=978-4840242165|id={{ASIN|484024216X|country=jp}}}}{{cite book |title=''Clannad'' 5 (Dengeki Comics)|publisher=|language=Japanese |isbn=4048667130|id={{ASIN|4048667130|country=jp}}}} {{anchor|Clannad: Tomoyo Dearest}}A fourth manga, titled ''Clannad: Tomoyo Dearest'' and illustrated by [[Yukiko Sumiyoshi]], was serialized between February 20 and August 20, 2008 in [[Fujimi Shobo]]'s ''[[Dragon Age Pure]]'' magazine.{{Cite news|title=Clannad|periodical=[[Dragon Age Pure]]|publisher=[[Fujimi Shobo]]|volume=9|date=2008-02-20|language=Japanese}}{{Cite news|title=Clannad|periodical=[[Dragon Age Pure]]|publisher=[[Fujimi Shobo]]|volume=12|date=2008-08-20|language=Japanese}} The story centers on Tomoyo's arc from the ''Clannad'' visual novel.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2008-02-05/new-clannad-da-capo-jinno-manga-to-launch-in-japan|title=New ''Clannad'', ''Da Capo'', Jinno Manga to Launch in Japan|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=February 5, 2008| accessdate=February 17, 2008}} A single volume for ''Clannad: Tomoyo Dearest'' was released on October 9, 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.kadokawa.co.jp/comic/bk_detail.php?pcd=200806000044|title=''Clannad: Tomoyo Dearest'' manga volume listing|publisher=[[Kadokawa Shoten]]|accessdate=June 6, 2009|language=Japanese}} There have also been four sets of manga [[anthology|anthologies]] produced by different companies and drawn by a multitude of different artists. The first volume of the earliest anthology series, released by Ohzora under the title ''Clannad'', was released in June 2004 under their Twin Heart Comics imprint.{{cite book |title=''Clannad'' manga anthology volume 1 by Ohzora|publisher=|language=Japanese |isbn=4776713071|id={{ASIN|4776713071|country=jp}}}} Volumes for this series continued to be released until April 2005 with the fifth volume.{{cite book |title=''Clannad'' manga anthology volume 5 by Ohzora|publisher=| language=Japanese |isbn=477671597X|id={{ASIN|477671597X|country=jp}}}} The second anthology was released in a single volume by [[Jive (publisher)|Jive]] on January 25, 2005 titled ''Clannad Comic Anthology: Another Symphony''.{{cite book |title=''Clannad Comic Anthology: Another Symphony'' product listing|publisher=|language=Japanese |isbn=486176078X|id={{ASIN|486176078X|country=jp}}}} The third anthology series was released in two volumes by [[Ichijinsha]] on June 25, 2004 and July 24, 2004 under their ''DNA Media Comics'';{{cite book |title=''Clannad Comic Anthology'' volume 1 (ID Comics DNA Media Comics)|publisher=|language=Japanese |isbn=4758001898 |id={{ASIN|4758001898|country=jp}}}}{{cite book |title=''Clannad Comic Anthology'' volume 2 (ID Comics DNA Media Comics)|publisher=|language=Japanese |isbn=4758001944|id={{ASIN|4758001944|country=jp}}}} a third special volume was released much later on December 25, 2007.{{cite book |title=''Clannad Comic Anthology'' Tokubetsu Hen (ID Comics DNA Media Comics)|publisher=|language=Japanese |isbn=4758004196|id={{ASIN|4758004196|country=jp}}}} The first volume of the last anthology series, a collection of [[Yonkoma|four-panel]] [[comic strip]]s released by [[Enterbrain]] under the title ''[[Magi-Cu]] 4-koma Clannad'', was released on February 25, 2008 under their MC Comics imprint; the tenth volume in the series was released on August 26, 2009.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120330225657/http://www.enterbrain.co.jp/magical-cute/prev2009.html|url=http://www.enterbrain.co.jp/magical-cute/prev2009.html|title=MC Comics previous publications list|publisher=[[Enterbrain]]|archivedate=March 30, 2012|accessdate=October 26, 2009|language=Japanese}} Each of the anthology series are written and drawn by an average of 20 people per volume. ===Drama CDs=== There are two separate sets of [[drama CD]]s based on the ''Clannad'' series. The first set, produced by [[Frontier Works]], contains five CDs each focusing on a different heroine in ''Clannad''{{'s}} story ranging from Nagisa, to Kotomi, Fuko, Kyou, and Tomoyo. The first volume was released in Japan on April 25, 2007 as a limited edition with an extra track added. The second through fifth volumes followed in one month increments between May 25, 2007 and August 24, 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.animate.tv/special/clannad.php|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070318041433/http://www.animate.tv/special/clannad.php|archivedate=March 18, 2007|title=''Clannad'' drama CDs published by Frontier Works|publisher=[[Animate]]|accessdate=March 16, 2007|language=Japanese}} The second set, produced by [[Prototype (company)|Prototype]], contains four CDs; the first was released on July 25, 2007. Volumes two through four were released in one month intervals after that, with the last being released on October 24, 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.prot.co.jp/similarities/clannad_doramacd/index.html|title=Prototype's official ''Clannad'' drama CD website|publisher=[[Prototype (company)|Prototype]]|accessdate=July 29, 2007|language=Japanese}} Each CD is based on the stories from the ''Official Another Story Clannad: Hikari Mimamoru Sakamichi de'' collection. The artist [[GotoP]], who provided the illustrations for the short stories, also illustrates the drama CD covers. The drama CDs, with text and visuals, are available as [[downloadable content]] via [[Xbox Live]] and the [[PlayStation Store]] when playing the Xbox 360 and PS3 versions of ''Clannad'', respectively. ===Film=== {{main article|Clannad (film)}} [[Toei Animation]] (the same team who worked on the original ''[[Kanon (visual novel)|Kanon]]'' anime and [[Air (2005 film)|''Air'' film]]) announced at the Tokyo Anime Fair on March 23, 2006 that an animated film would be produced.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2006-03-25/tokyo-anime-fair-new-kanon-and-movies|title=Tokyo Anime Fair: New Kanon and Movies|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=March 25, 2006|accessdate=July 22, 2007}} The ''Clannad'' film was released on September 15, 2007, directed by the same director of the ''Air'' film, [[Osamu Dezaki]], and the screenplay was written by [[Makoto Nakamura]].{{cite web|url=http://www.toei-anim.co.jp/movie/2007_clannad/intro.html#staffcast|title=''Clannad'' film staff and cast|publisher=[[Toei Animation]]|accessdate=May 29, 2008|language=Japanese}} The film is a reinterpretation of the ''Clannad'' storyline which centers on the [[story arc]] of the female lead [[Nagisa Furukawa]]. The film was released on DVD in three editions: the Collector's Edition, the Special Edition, and the Regular Edition on March 7, 2008.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101003223226/http://www.clannad-movie.jp/DVD_info.html|url=http://www.clannad-movie.jp/DVD_info.html|title=DVD information at the ''Clannad'' film's official website|publisher=[[Toei Animation]]|archivedate=October 3, 2010|accessdate=February 4, 2012|language=Japanese}} Sentai Filmworks released an English-subbed and dubbed version of the film in March 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2010-11-13/sentai-filmworks-adds-clannad-anime-film|title=Sentai Filmworks Adds ''Clannad'' Anime Film with Dub, Sub|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=November 13, 2010|accessdate=November 14, 2010}} ===Anime series=== {{see also|List of Clannad episodes}} On March 15, 2007, the Japanese television station [[Tokyo Broadcasting System|BS-i]] announced a ''Clannad'' anime series via a short 30-second teaser trailer that was featured at the end of the final episode of the second ''[[Kanon (visual novel)|Kanon]]'' anime series. ''Clannad'' is produced by [[Kyoto Animation]], directed by [[Tatsuya Ishihara]], and written by [[Fumihiko Shimo]], who also worked on other adaptations of [[Key (company)|Key's]] visual novels ''[[Air (visual novel)|Air]]'' and ''Kanon''. The anime aired between October 4, 2007 and March 27, 2008, containing 23 aired episodes out of a planned 24;{{cite web|url=http://www.tbs.co.jp/clannad/01news/news.html|title=''Clannad'' anime news at the official ''Clannad'' anime website|publisher=[[Kyoto Animation]]|accessdate=October 9, 2007|language=Japanese}} the broadcast time was first announced on August 11, 2007 at the [[Tokyo Broadcasting System|TBS]] festival ''Anime Festa'', which is also when the first episode was showcased. The anime series was released in a set of eight [[DVD]] compilations released between December 19, 2007 and July 16, 2008 by [[Pony Canyon]], with each compilation containing three episodes. Of the 24 episodes, 23 were aired on television with the first 22 being regular episodes, followed by an additional extra episode. The last episode was released as an [[original video animation]] (OVA) on the eighth DVD on July 16, 2008 and is set in an [[Parallel universe (fiction)|alternate universe]] from the anime series where Tomoya and Tomoyo are dating, which is based on Tomoyo's scenario in the game. The OVA episode was previewed on May 31, 2008 for an audience of four-hundred people picked via a mail-in [[postcard]] campaign. A [[Blu-ray Disc]] (BD) box set of ''Clannad'' was released on April 30, 2010.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B00329NVYS/ |title=''Clannad'' Blu-ray Box|publisher=|accessdate=March 15, 2010|language=Japanese}}{{cite web|url=http://www.tbs.co.jp/clannad/clannad1/07dvd/dvd.html|title=DVD|publisher=[[Kyoto Animation]]|accessdate=May 25, 2013|language=Japanese}} After the ending of the 23rd episode of the first ''Clannad'' anime series, a 15-second teaser trailer aired promoting a second season titled ''Clannad After Story''. The anime is again animated by Kyoto Animation, and animates the After [[Story arc]] from the visual novel, which is a continuation of Nagisa's story, into 24 episodes. The same staff and cast from the first anime were used and the series broadcast in Japan between October 3, 2008 and March 26, 2009.{{cite web|url= http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2008-03-27/clannad-after-story-tv-sequel-to-be-announced|title= ''Clannad After Story'' TV Sequel to be Announced|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=March 27, 2008|accessdate=March 27, 2008}}{{cite web|url= http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2008-07-11/kuroshitsuji-anime-confirmed-to-premiere-this-fall|title=''Kuroshitsuji'' Anime Confirmed to Premiere This Fall|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=July 11, 2008|accessdate=July 15, 2008}} Of the 24 episodes, 22 are regular episodes, the 23rd is an extra episode, and the last episode is a summary episode showcasing highlights from the series. The episodes were released on eight DVD compilation volumes between December 3, 2008 and July 1, 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.tbs.co.jp/clannad/05goods/dvd.html|title=Goods|publisher=[[Kyoto Animation]]|accessdate=October 9, 2007|language=Japanese}} The eighth DVD volume came with an additional OVA episode set in an alternate universe from the anime series where Tomoya and Kyou are dating. The OVA episode was previewed on May 24, 2009 to a limited number of people.{{cite web|url= http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2009-04-12/clannad-after-story-last-dvd-to-include-kyou-arc|title=''Clannad After Story''{{'}}s Last DVD to Include Kyou Arc|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=April 12, 2009|accessdate=April 12, 2009}} A BD box set of ''Clannad After Story'' was released on April 20, 2011 in Japan with English subtitles.{{cite web|url=http://www.cdjapan.co.jp/detailview.html?KEY=PCXE-60010|title=Clannad After Story (English Subtitles) Blu-ray Box (Limited Release) (Blu-ray)|publisher=CD Japan|accessdate=December 30, 2010}} series;{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2009-07-28/sentai-filmworks-licenses-clannad-after-story-ghost-hound-and-he-is-my-master|title=Sentai Filmworks Adds ''Clannad After Story'', ''Ghost Hound'', ''He is My Master''|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=July 28, 2009|accessdate=July 28, 2009}} [[Section23 Films]] localized and distributed both the television series and OVA starting with the first half season box set with English subtitles released on October 20, 2009. The second half box set was released on December 8, 2009. Sentai Filmworks re-released ''Clannad'' in a complete collection set on June 15, 2010, which featured an English dub, produced at [[Seraphim Digital]].{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2010-03-15/clannad-blue-drop-ghost-hound-tears-to-tiara-get-dubs|title=''Clannad'', ''Blue Drop'', ''Ghost Hound'', ''Tears to Tiara'' Get Slate|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=January 17, 2011|accessdate=January 17, 2011}} and re-released ''Clannad'' on BD in November 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2011-07-03/sentai-filmworks-adds-ro-kyu-bu-loups-garous-ef|title=Sentai Filmworks Adds ''Ro-Kyu-Bu'', ''Loups-Garous'', ''ef''|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=July 3, 2011|accessdate=July 3, 2011}} The opening theme for the first season is {{" '}}Mag Mell' (cuckool mix 2007)" by [[Eufonius]], a [[remix]] of the song {{" '}}Mag Mell' (cockool mix)", featured on the third disc of the game's original soundtrack, which is itself a remix of the game's opening theme {{Nihongo|"Mag Mell"|メグメル|Megu Meru}}. The first season's ending theme is {{Nihongo|"[[Dango]] Daikazoku"|だんご大家族|The Big Dango Family}} by [[Chata]]. It carries the same tune as {{Nihongo|"Chiisana Tenohira"|小さなてのひら|Small Palms}}, the ending theme from the After Story arc of the game. The second season's opening theme is {{Nihongo|"Toki o Kizamu Uta"|時を刻む唄|A Song to Pass the Time}} which uses the same tune as the [[background music]] track {{Nihongo|"Onaji Takami e"|同じ高みへ|To the Same Heights}} from the game's soundtrack. The ending theme is "Torch", and both the opening and ending themes are sung by [[Lia (singer)|Lia]]. The rest of the soundtrack for both anime series is sampled from several albums released for the ''Clannad'' visual novel including the ''[[List of Clannad soundtracks#Clannad Original Soundtrack|Clannad Original Soundtrack]]'', ''[[List of Clannad soundtracks#Mabinogi|Mabinogi]]'', ''[[List of Clannad soundtracks#-Memento-|-Memento-]]'', ''[[List of Clannad soundtracks#Sorarado|Sorarado]]'', and ''[[List of Clannad soundtracks#Sorarado Append|Sorarado Append]]''. The [[cover art]] for ''Sorarado Append'' is also visible as the last shot in the ending video animation of the first season. ===Internet radio shows=== An [[Internet radio]] show to promote the ''Clannad'' anime series called {{Nihongo|''Nagisa to Sanae no Omae ni Rainbow''|渚と早苗のおまえにレインボー}} was broadcast between October 5, 2007 and October 3, 2008, containing 52 episodes.{{cite web|url= http://www.animate.tv/digital/web_radio/detail_112.html|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080624083207/http://www.animate.tv/digital/web_radio/detail_112.html|archivedate=June 24, 2008|title=''Clannad'' radio show official website|publisher=[[Animate]]|accessdate=June 6, 2009|language=Japanese}} The show, produced by Onsen and [[Animate|Animate TV]], was hosted by [[Mai Nakahara]], who played Nagisa Furukawa in the anime, and [[Kikuko Inoue]], who played Sanae Furukawa, and was streamed online every Friday. Several [[Seiyū|voice actors]] from the anime adaptation appeared on the show as guests who included [[Ryō Hirohashi]] (as Kyou), [[Atsuko Enomoto]] (as Yukine), [[Akemi Kanda]] (as Ryou), [[Yuichi Nakamura (voice actor)|Yuichi Nakamura]] (as Tomoya), and [[Daisuke Sakaguchi]] (as Youhei). A two-disc CD compilation containing the show's first 13 broadcasts was produced on June 18, 2008.{{cite web|url= http://news.dengeki.com/elem/000/000/080/80039/index.html|title=The Popular ''Clannad'' and Others' Radio CDs One After Another to Release!|publisher=[[ASCII Media Works]]|date=May 15, 2008|accessdate=May 18, 2008| language=Japanese}} The second two-disc CD compilation containing the 14th through 26th broadcasts was released on October 15, 2008,{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B001DJANZ4/ |title=''Nagisa to Sanae no Omae ni Rainbow'' Radio CD vol. 2 listing|publisher=|accessdate= June 6, 2009|language=Japanese}} and a third CD volume followed on November 19, 2008.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B001GKXQ8G/ |title=''Nagisa to Sanae no Omae ni Rainbow'' Radio CD vol. 3 listing|publisher=|accessdate=June 6, 2009|language=Japanese}} A fourth and final volume was released on February 18, 2009 containing the rest of the broadcasts.{{cite web|url=http://www.onsen.ag/blog/?p=2814|title=''Nagisa to Sanae no Omae ni Rainbow'' CD Volume 4 to be Sold!|publisher=Onsen|date=January 23, 2009|accessdate= June 6, 2009|language=Japanese}} A second Internet radio show to promote the ''Clannad After Story'' anime series called {{Nihongo|''Nagisa to Sanae to Akio no Omae ni Hyper Rainbow''|渚と早苗と秋生のおまえにハイパーレインボー}} was broadcast between October 10, 2008 and April 10, 2009, containing 26 episodes. The show was also produced by Onsen and Animate TV, and was streamed online every Friday. The show had three hosts including the previous two plus [[Ryōtarō Okiayu]] who plays Akio Furukawa in the anime series. Two two-disc CD compilations were released containing the second radio shows broadcasts, the first released on February 18, 2009,{{cite web|url=http://www.onsen.ag/blog/?p=2818|title=''Clannad'' Radio CD Gets Cover Art, and Also a Hyper Sale Decision!|publisher=Onsen|date=January 23, 2009|accessdate=June 6, 2009|language=Japanese}} followed by the second on May 29, 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.onsen.ag/blog/?p=3731|title=(Guest Information Addition) ''Nagisa to Sanae to Akio no Omae ni Hyper Rainbow'' Second CD volume to be Sold!|publisher=Onsen|date=May 1, 2009|accessdate=June 6, 2009|language= Japanese}} ==Music== {{main article|Music of Clannad}} The ''Clannad'' visual novel has four pieces of [[theme music]]: one opening theme, two ending themes, and an insert song. The opening theme is {{Nihongo|"Mag Mell"|メグメル|Megu Meru}} by [[Eufonius]]. The two ending themes are {{Nihongo|"-Kage Futatsu-"|-影二つ-|-Two Shadows-}} and {{Nihongo|"Chiisana Tenohira"|小さなてのひら|Small Palms}} sung by [[Riya]] of Eufonius; the latter is used as the ending theme in the After Story arc. The insert song "Ana" is sung by [[Lia (singer)|Lia]]. Six of the characters have [[background music]] [[leitmotif]]s—the five heroines, and Yukine Miyazawa. Nagisa's theme is the self-titled {{Nihongo|"Nagisa"|渚}}; Kyou's theme is {{Nihongo|"Sore wa Kaze no Yōni"|それは風のように|That's Like the Wind}}; Kotomi's theme is "Étude Pour les Petites Supercordes"; Tomoyo's theme is {{Nihongo|"Kanojo no Honki"|彼女の本気|Her Determination}}; Fuko's theme is {{Nihongo|"Hurry, Starfish"|は〜りぃすたーふぃしゅ|Ha~rī Sutāfisshu}}; lastly, Yukine's theme is {{Nihongo|"Shiryōshitsu no Ochakai"|資料室のお茶会|Tea Party in the Reference Room}}. An [[image song]] album titled ''[[Music of Clannad#Sorarado|Sorarado]]'' was released in December 2003 featuring songs sung by Riya.{{cite web|url= http://key.soundslabel.com/discography.html|title=Key Sounds Label's discography|publisher=[[Key Sounds Label]]|accessdate=April 25, 2008 |language=Japanese}} A [[remix album]], ''[[Music of Clannad#Mabinogi|Mabinogi]]'', came bundled with the original release of ''Clannad'' in April 2004. The [[Music of Clannad#Clannad Original Soundtrack|game's original soundtrack]] was released in August 2004 containing three discs containing 56 tracks. A follow-up to ''Sorarado'' was released in December 2004 called ''[[Music of Clannad#Sorarado Append|Sorarado Append]]''; the songs were again sung by Riya. A remix album titled ''[[Music of Clannad#-Memento-|-Memento-]]'' was also released in December 2004 and contained two discs. A piano [[arrangement]] album was released in December 2005 called ''[[Music of Clannad#Piano no Mori|Piano no Mori]]'', which contained five tracks from ''Clannad'' and five from ''[[Tomoyo After: It's a Wonderful Life]]''. Each of the albums released for the visual novel version were released on Key's [[record label]] [[Key Sounds Label]]. A [[maxi single]] by Eufonius was released in July 2007 for the [[Clannad (film)|''Clannad'' film]] called "[[Music of Clannad#Mag Mell|Mag Mell (frequency⇒e Ver.)]]". The single contained a remix version of the game's opening theme, and instrumental track of that remix, and an original track. An image album titled ''[[Music of Clannad#Yakusoku|Yakusoku]]'' was released in August 2007 featuring a song sung by Lia, an instrumental version of that song, and two background music tracks used in the film. The [[Music of Clannad#Clannad Film Soundtrack|film's original soundtrack]] was released in November 2007.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B000WP2CYA/ |title=''Clannad Film Soundtrack'' listing|publisher=|accessdate=June 6, 2009|language=Japanese}} The albums released for the film were produced by [[Frontier Works]]. A single was released in October 2007 for the first anime series called "[[Dango Daikazoku|Mag Mell / Dango Daikazoku]]" which contained the anime's opening and ending themes in original, short, and instrumental versions plus a remix version of {{Nihongo|"Shōjo no Gensō"|少女の幻想|The Girl's Fantasy}}, a track featured in ''Sorarado'' sung by Riya. A single for the second season anime series was released in November 2008 called "[[Toki o Kizamu Uta/TORCH|Toki o Kizamu Uta / Torch]]", and contains the anime's opening and ending themes sung by Lia. A remix album containing piano arrangement versions of the second anime series' opening and ending themes was released in December 2008 called ''[[Music of Clannad#"Toki o Kizamu Uta / Torch" Piano Arrange Disc|"Toki o Kizamu Uta / Torch" Piano Arrange Disc]]''.{{cite web|url=http://vgmdb.net/album/11549|title=''"Toki o Kizamu Uta / Torch" Piano Arrange Disc'' album listing|publisher=VGMdb|accessdate=June 6, 2009}} The anime series' two singles and one album are released on Key Sounds Label. ==Reception== ===Visual novel=== Across the national ranking of ranking for bishōjo games; Clannad ranks 40|publisher=Peakspub|archivedate=August 10, 2004 | accessdate=March 13, 2007|language=Japanese}} The ''Clannad'' regular edition Windows release premiered at number 26 in the rankings.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051227175947/http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank153.html|url=http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank153.html|title=PC News ranking for bishōjo games; Clannad ranks 26|publisher=Peakspub|archivedate=December 27, 2005 |accessdate=March 13, 2007|language=Japanese}} The next two rankings for the regular edition were at 37 and 41.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051227193948/http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank155.html|url= http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank155.html|title=PC News ranking for bishōjo games; Clannad ranks 37 and 41|publisher=Peakspub|archivedate=December 27, 2005 | accessdate=March 13, 2007|language=Japanese}} According to sales information taken from the Japanese [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] website, the original Windows version of ''Clannad'' sold 100,560 copies in 2004.{{cite web|url=http://astore.amazon.co.jp/wikimania-22/listmania/R1EG2LAMROXE3Z/249-7991717-8843508|title=売上ランキング (2004年 Hゲーム)|trans-title=Sales Ranking (2004 H-games)|work=Wiki-Mania ''Clannad Full Voice'' ranked twice in terms of highest selling PC games nationally in Japan, achieving sales rankings of 7 and 20 in February and March 2008, respectively.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080418031727/http://pc-press.net/sales.html|url=http://www.pc-press.net/sales.html|script-title=ja:セールスランキング|trans-title=Sales Ranking|publisher=PCpress|language=Japanese|archivedate=May 25, 2008|accessdate=December 31, 2010}} For the week of April 18, 2011, the PlayStation 3 port of ''Clannad'' sold 7,466 units.{{cite web|author=Rose, Mike|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/34340/Pokemon_Typing_Game_Tops_Japanese_Sales_Chart.php|title=Pokemon Typing Game Tops Japanese Sales Chart|publisher=[[Gamasutra]]|date=April 28, 2011|accessdate=January 29, 2012}} As of April 18, 2011, the console versions of ''Clannad'' had sold over 113,000 copies.{{cite web|url=http://garaph.info/softwareindividual.php//gid/2387|title=Clannad (PS2) (based on Famitsu data)|publisher=Garaph|accessdate=March 16, 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://garaph.info/gamesearch.php?publisher=Prototype&opt=0|title=Prototype (based on Famitsu data)|publisher=Garaph|accessdate=March 16, 2012}} The two-volume PSP editions of ''Hikari Mimamoru Sakamichi de'' sold 28,984 copies by the end of 2010. The English release of the Windows version debuted on the Steam charts at number three, above ''[[Call of Duty: Black Ops III]]'' and ''[[Grand Theft Auto V]]'', and just below ''[[Fallout 4]]'' and ''[[Counter-Strike: Global Offensive]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.siliconera.com/2015/11/23/clannad-was-outselling-call-of-duty-black-ops-iii-and-grand-theft-auto-v-on-steam/|title=Clannad Was Outselling Call Of Duty: Black Ops III And Grand Theft Auto V On Steam|publisher=Siliconera|date=November 23, 2015|accessdate=December 2, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.digitaltrends.com/gaming/visual-novel-clannad-beats-call-of-duty-in-steam-sales/|title=Japanese visual novel Clannad outranks Call of Duty on Steam charts|publisher=Digital Trends|date=November 24, 2015|accessdate=December 2, 2015}} In the October 2007 issue of ''[[Dengeki G's Magazine]]'', poll results for the 50 best [[bishōjo game]]s were released. Out of 249 titles, ''Clannad'' ranked first at 114 votes; in comparison, the second place title, ''[[Fate/stay night]]'', got 78 votes.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011213916/http://gs.dengekinet.com/ranking/index.html|url=http://gs.dengeki.com/ranking/index.html|title=Dengeki G's Magazine top 50 bishōjo games|publisher=[[ASCII Media Works]]|archivedate=October 11, 2007|accessdate=January 3, 2011|language= Japanese}} The PlayStation 2 release in 2006 was reviewed by the Japanese video game magazine ''[[Famitsu]]'', which gave it an overall score of 26/40 (out of the four individual review scores of 7, 7, 6, and 6).{{cite web|url=http://ps2.ign.com/articles/692/692735p1.html|title=Now Playing in Japan|publisher=IGN|author=Anoop Gantayat|date=March 1, 2006|accessdate=November 10, 2009}} In 2008, ''Clannad'' was voted No. 2 in the ''[[Dengeki]]'' poll of the most emotional games of all time.{{cite web|script-title=ja:【アンケート結果発表】感動して泣いてしまったゲームはありますか?|trans-title=(Survey results) Are There Emotional Games That Made You Cry?|url=http://news.dengeki.com/elem/000/000/113/113442/|publisher=[[ASCII Media Works]]|date=October 15, 2008|accessdate=May 7, 2012|language=Japanese}} In 2011, ''Clannad'' was voted No. 4 in ''Famitsu''{{'s}} poll of the most tear-inducing games of all time.{{cite web|last=Romano|first=Sal|url=http://gematsu.com/2011/12/famitsus-top-20-list-of-tear-inducing-games|title=Famitsu's top 20 list of tear-inducing games|publisher=Gematsu|date=December 29, 2011|accessdate=February 24, 2012}} In 2014, [[Sony Computer Entertainment]] conducted a poll with over 10,000 Japanese fans, where ''Clannad'' was voted No. 18 on the "Most Moving Games Over Books and Movies" list.{{cite web|url=http://www.destructoid.com/poll-final-fantasy-vii-most-wanted-remake-dragon-quest-v-favorite-playstation-game-284529.phtml|title=Poll: Final Fantasy VII most wanted remake, Dragon Quest V favorite PlayStation game|publisher=Destructoid|date=December 3, 2014|accessdate=July 22, 2015}} {{ill|Multiplayer.it|it|Multiplayer.it|vertical-align=sup}} reviewed the Windows version and scored it 9.2 out of 10. They referred to it as "one of the best visual novels ever made", praising the "rich" dialogues and storytelling, "deep" branching narrative, and "lifelike" characterization, referring to the cast as some of the best "characters ever seen" in "the world of video games."{{cite web|author=Tagliaferri, Simone|url=http://multiplayer.it/recensioni/160377-clannad-la-regina-delle-visual-novel.html|title=La regina delle visual novel|publisher=[[:it:Multiplayer.it|Multiplayer.it]]|accessdate=December 15, 2015|language=Italian}} RPGFan gave it an overall score of 83%, including 88% for story, 86% gameplay, 74% control, 72% graphics, and 82% sound. The review praised the large number of dialogue choices which "lets you feel involved in how the tale plays out", "many genuinely funny moments," and "emotionally touching" stories, particularly the After Story arc where ''Clannad'' "truly excels" with "heart-wrenching" and "emotionally-charged" storytelling, but criticized it for not having enough visuals and for having some "less interesting" side-story paths in the School Life arc which require completion to unlock the After Story arc.{{cite web|url=http://www.rpgfan.com/reviews/Clannad_Full_Voice/index.html|title=Clannad Full Voice|publisher=RPGFan|date=August 10, 2014|accessdate=July 12, 2015}} ===Anime=== The two anime series and film DVDs have shown consistent high sales figures. 2009|accessdate=July 15, 2009}} For the anime television adaptation, the first season of ''Clannad'' received reviews ranging from positive to mixed, while the second season ''Clannad After Story'' received wide critical acclaim. The THEM Anime Reviews website gave the entire series a score of 4 out of 5 stars, with reviewer Tim Jones describing the first season as "the most fleshed-out and real Key animated adaption to date,"{{cite web|title=Clannad|author=Tim Jones|publisher=THEM Anime Reviews|url=http://www.themanime.org/viewreview.php?id=1104|accessdate=January 19, 2010}} and reviewer Stig Høgset stating that the second season ''After Story'' "will play up the tragedies and the drama considerably, quite possibly tearing out your heart in the process. This is where time truly starts to fly by, lending the show some real weight in the emotional departments."{{cite web|title=Clannad ~After Story~|author=Stig Høgset|publisher=THEM Anime Reviews|url=http://themanime.org/viewreview.php?id=1179|accessdate=February 2, 2010}} Theron Martin of [[Anime News Network]] gave the first season a 'B+' rating, criticizing its extensive use of [[Moe (slang)|moe]] elements, but considered it appealing entertainment for a "fan base who revels in this kind of thing."{{cite web|title=Review: Clannad Sub.DVD - Collection 2|author=Theron Martin|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/clannad/sub.dvd-collection-2|date=June 19, 2009|accessdate=February 13, 2010}} His review for the second season ''After Story'' was much more positive, giving it an 'A-' rating. He praised the second half of the season as "the best-written quarter of ''Clannad''," stating that it "effectively builds up and delivers its emotional appeal, reinforces the series' central theme (i.e. the importance of family), and peaks visually," and concluding that "only the most cynical of souls will avoid shedding at least a few tears at certain points."{{cite web|title=Review: Clannad After Story Sub.DVD 2 - Collection 2|author=Theron Martin|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/clannad-after-story/sub.dvd-2|date=December 16, 2009|accessdate=January 19, 2010}} On the [[DVD Talk]] website, the reviewer Todd Douglass Jr. gave ''Clannad After Story'' a "Highly Recommended" rating, stating that "the range of emotions ''Clannad'' takes you through is quite daunting. It's charming, cute, hilarious, mysterious, and tragic all at the same time. Few shows are as memorable, and few are this good for this long." He concludes that the storytelling is "heartfelt" and "memorable in so many ways," and that "few shows rise to the levels this one does."{{cite web|title=Clannad: After Story - Collection 2|author=Todd Douglass Jr.|publisher=[[DVD Talk]]|date=December 8, 2009|url=http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/40990/clannad-after-story-collection-2/|accessdate=January 19, 2010}} ===Legacy=== Gamania Entertainment hosted a collaboration event with ''Clannad'' and their two [[massively multiplayer online game]]s (MMOGs) ''Hiten Online'' and ''[[Holy Beast Online]]''.{{cite web|url= http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2008-03-27/clannad-join-forces-with-hiten-holy-beast-mmorpgs|title=''Clannad'' Join Forces with ''Hiten'', ''Holy Beast'' MMORPGs|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=March 27, 2008|accessdate=March 27, 2008}} Between March 26 and June 26, 2008, the two games offered costumes characters could wear which looked like the winter school uniforms from ''Clannad'', along with offering [[Kyou Fujibayashi|Kyou's]] pet boar [[List of Clannad characters#Other characters|Botan]] for players to adopt.{{cite web|url= http://www.4gamer.net/games/024/G002451/20080321025/|title=Gamania × ''Clannad'' Collaboration Plan, School Uniforms to Appear in ''Hiten Online'', ''Holy Beast''|publisher=4gamer.net|date=March 26, 2008|accessdate=March 27, 2008| language=Japanese}} Players of either game who had a character over level 20 could enter a lottery where 500 people were chosen to win ''Clannad''-related goods which included virtual and real-world items such as [[file folder]]s, "netcash" cards, sports towels, [[tapestry|tapestries]], and various items used during gameplay.{{cite web| url=http://www.gamania.co.jp/clannad/| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080331000927/http://www.gamania.co.jp/clannad/| archivedate=March 31, 2008|title=Information on the ''Clannad'' collaboration project|publisher=Gamania|accessdate= March 27, 2008|language=Japanese}} [[ASCII Media Works]] and Vridge produced the PlayStation 2 visual novel {{Nihongo|''Nogizaka Haruka no Himitsu: Cosplay Hajimemashita''|乃木坂春香の秘密 こすぷれ、はじめました♥||lit. ''Haruka Nogizaka's Secret: Cosplaying Has Begun''}} based on the [[light novel]] series ''[[Nogizaka Haruka no Himitsu]]''. Released in September 2008, the game features the series' characters [[cosplay]]ing in various costumes either depicting characters from five popular light novel series published by ASCII Media Works, or three ''Clannad'' heroines. [[Nogizaka Haruka no Himitsu#Main characters|Haruka Nogizaka]] can cosplay as Kotomi Ichinose, [[Nogizaka Haruka no Himitsu#Nogizaka family|Mika Nogizaka]] can cosplay as Nagisa Furukawa (albeit with long hair), and [[Nogizaka Haruka no Himitsu#Classmates and teachers|Shiina Amamiya]] can cosplay as Tomoyo Sakagami.{{cite web|url= http://news.dengeki.com/elem/000/000/103/103016/|title=Other Works' Costumes Appearing in ''Nogizaka Haruka no Himitsu''! Kotomi's Costume Can Also be Worn| publisher=[[ASCII Media Works]]|date=September 2, 2008|accessdate=September 18, 2008|language=Japanese}} The player can also view exclusive [[Computer graphics|CGs]] in the game if one of the girls is taken out to various places while cosplaying as one of the aforementioned five light novel series characters, or as the ''Clannad'' heroines. For example, if Mika is cosplaying as Nagisa, a CG of her eating [[dango]] can become viewable. When cosplaying as one of these tie-in characters, the voice of the girl cosplaying changes to the [[Voice acting in Japan|voice actress]] of the character they are cosplaying; for example, if Shiina cosplays as Tomoyo, she is voiced by Tomoyo's voice actress [[Houko Kuwashima]].{{cite web|url= http://news.dengeki.com/elem/000/000/104/104840/|title=''Nogizaka Haruka no Himitsu''—Cosplaying up ''Clannad''{{'}}s Long Steep Slope|publisher=[[ASCII Media Works]]|date=September 11, 2008|accessdate=September 18, 2008|language=Japanese}} A [[3D computer graphics|3D]] [[virtual world]] called ''[[Ai Sp@ce]]'' was developed by the video game developer Headlock where users can interact with [[bishōjo game]] heroines from ''Clannad'', ''[[Shuffle!]]'', and ''[[Da Capo II]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2008-04-08/clannad-shuffle-d.c-ii-to-launch-3d-virtual-world |title=''Clannad'', ''Shuffle'', ''D.C. II'' to Launch 3D Virtual World|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=April 8, 2008|accessdate=April 8, 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://aisp.jp/home.html|title=''Ai Sp@ce'' official website|publisher=[[Ai Sp@ce]]|accessdate= June 3, 2009|language=Japanese}} Released in October 2008, the world recreates each game franchise on its own virtual island which are linked with a central [[Akihabara]] Island where users can interact, bridging the gap between the separate franchises. Users are able to create a customizable [[avatar (computing)|avatar]] to represent themselves in the game, along with choosing one game heroine to live with, which is referred to as a character doll, or chara-doll for short.{{cite web|url= http://www.itmedia.co.jp/news/articles/0804/08/news104.html|title=''Clannad'', ''Shuffle!'', ''D.C. II'' to Reappear in a 3D World|publisher=IT Media|date=April 8, 2008|accessdate=April 8, 2008|language=Japanese}} The user and chara-doll reside together on one of the three in-game "islands" depending on which franchise the heroine is from, which includes a house with furniture and clothes that can be purchased. The chara-dolls can also be customizable in that they can develop a unique personality for each user. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Clannad (visual novel)}} {{wikiquote|Clannad}} {{wikiquote|Clannad: After Story|Clannad After Story}} * [http://key.visualarts.gr.jp/product/clannad/ Key's official ''Clannad'' website] {{ja icon}} * [http://www.tbs.co.jp/clannad/clannad1/index-j.html Official ''Clannad'' anime website] {{ja icon}} * [http://www.tbs.co.jp/clannad/ Official ''Clannad After Story'' anime website] {{ja icon}} * {{ann|anime|7809|Clannad}} * {{vndb|4|visual novel|Clannad}} {{Key (company)|state=expanded}} {{Kyoto Animation}} {{Authority control}} {{good article}} [[Category:2004 video games]] [[Category:2005 manga]] [[Category:2007 anime television series]] [[Category:2007 manga]] [[Category:2008 anime OVAs]] [[Category:2008 anime television series]] [[Category:2008 manga]] [[Category:2009 anime OVAs]] [[Category:Android (operating system) games]] [[Category:Anime television series based on video games]] [[Category:ASCII Media Works manga]] [[Category:Bishōjo games]] [[Category:Clannad (visual novel)| ]] [[Category:Comi Digi + manga]] [[Category:Dengeki Comics]] [[Category:Dengeki G's Magazine]] [[Category:Enterbrain manga]] [[Category:Fujimi Shobo manga]] [[Category:Ichijinsha manga]] [[Category:Key (company) games]] [[Category:Kyoto Animation]] [[Category:Light novels]] [[Category:PlayStation 2 games]] [[Category:PlayStation 3 games]] [[Category:PlayStation 4 games]] [[Category:PlayStation Portable games]] [[Category:PlayStation Vita games]] [[Category:Romance anime and manga]] [[Category:Romance video games]] [[Category:School life in anime and manga]] [[Category:Seinen manga]] [[Category:Sentai Filmworks]] [[Category:Slice of life anime and manga]] [[Category:Tragedy anime and manga]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]] [[Category:Visual novels]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Xbox 360 games]]

The '''Creoles of color''' are a historic ethnic group of [[Creole peoples|Creole people]] that developed in the former French and Spanish colonies of [[Louisiana]] (especially in the city of [[New Orleans]]), Southern Mississippi, Alabama, and Northwestern Florida in what is now the United States. French colonists in Louisiana first used the term "Creole" to refer to whites born in the colony, rather than in France. It was also used for slaves born in the colony.
But as a group of [[mixed-race]] people developed from unions between Europeans, Africans, and Native Americans, the term Creoles of color was applied to them. In some cases, white fathers would free their concubines and children, forming a class of ''Gens de couleur libres'' ([[free people of color]]). The French and Spanish gave them more rights than the slaves.
==History== [[File:George Herriman and fans.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Creole cartoonist [[George Herriman]]]] [[Mixed-race]] Creoles of color became identified as a distinct ethnic group, ''[[Gens de couleur libres]]'' ([[free persons of color]]), prior to the 19th century. During [[History of Louisiana|Louisiana's]] colonial period, ''Créole'' referred to people born in Louisiana whose ancestors had come from elsewhere; i.e., all natives other than [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native Americans]]. The term ''Créole'' was first used by French colonists to distinguish themselves from foreign-born settlers, and later as distinct from [[English American|Anglo-American]] settlers. Colonial documents show that the term ''Créole'' was used variously at different times to refer to [[white people]], [[mixed-race]] people, and [[black people]], including slaves.<ref>Kein, Sybil. ''Creole: The History and Legacy of Louisiana's Free People of Color''. Louisiana State University Press, 2009, p. 73. {{ISBN|9780807126011}}.</ref>
Many Creoles of color were free, and their descendants often enjoyed many of the same privileges that whites did, including (but not limited to) property ownership, formal education, and service in the militia. During the [[antebellum South|antebellum]] period, their society was structured along class lines and they tended to marry within their group. While it was not illegal, it was a social taboo for Creoles of color to marry slaves and it was a rare occurrence. Some of the wealthier and prosperous Creoles of color owned slaves themselves. Other Creoles of color, such as [[Thomy Lafon]], used their social position to support the abolitionist cause.
Another Creole of color, wealthy planter [[Francis E. Dumas]], emancipated all of his slaves in 1863 and organized them into a company in the Second Regiment of the [[1st Louisiana Native Guard (United States)|Louisiana Native Guards]], in which he served as an officer.<ref>Shirley Elizabeth Thompson, ''Exiles at Home: The Struggle to Become American in Creole New Orleans'', Harvard University Press, 2009, pg. 162. {{ISBN|9780674023512}}.</ref>
Some historians suggest that New Orleans was the cradle of the civil rights movement in the United States, due to the earliest efforts of Creoles to integrate the military ''en masse''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Eaton|first=Fernin|title=Louisiana's Free People of Color-Digitization Grant-letter in support|url=https://www.academia.edu/3505760/Louisianas_Free_People_of_Color-Digitization_grant_awarded_to_LSU_Hill_library_others|accessdate=June 7, 2013}}</ref> Creoles of Color had been members of the militia for decades under both French and Spanish control of the colony of [[Louisiana (New Spain)|Louisiana]]. For example, around 80 free Creoles of Color were recruited into the militia that participated in the [[Battle of Baton Rouge (1779)|Battle of Baton Rouge]] in 1779.<ref>Charles Gayarré, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=Pk4TAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=History+of+Louisiana:+The+Spanish+Domination+1867&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiqh6GrpPPdAhXqg1QKHRSvBVwQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q&f=false History of Louisiana: The Spanish Domination]'', William J. Widdleton, 1867, pp 126-132. {{pre-ISBN}}.</ref>
After the United States made the [[Louisiana Purchase]] in 1803 and acquired the large territory west of the Mississippi, the Creoles of color in New Orleans volunteered their services and pledged their loyalty to their new country. They also took an oath of loyalty to [[William C. C. Claiborne]], the Louisiana Territorial Governor appointed by President [[Thomas Jefferson]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Carter|first=Clarence|title=The Territorial Papers of the United States, Vol. IX, The Territory of Orleans|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TvE8AQAAIAAJ&q=The+Territorial+Papers+of+the+United+States+carter+1940&dq=The+Territorial+Papers+of+the+United+States+carter+1940&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiBjoHWpPPdAhU5GDQIHURED8YQ6AEIKTAA|year=1940|page=174}} {{pre-ISBN}}.</ref>
Months after the colony became part of the United States, Claiborne's administration was faced with a dilemma previously unknown in the U.S.; integration in the military by incorporating entire units of previously established "colored" militia.<ref>{{cite web|last=Eaton|first=Fernin|title=1811 Slave Uprising, etc|url=https://www.academia.edu/1910804/Gov._Claiborne_in_his_own_words--a_salon_publique_at_Pitot_House_Bayou_St._John|work=Salon Publique, Pitot House, November 7, 2011|accessdate=June 7, 2013}}</ref> In a February 20, 1804 letter, Secretary of War Henry Dearborn wrote to Claiborne saying, "…it would be prudent not to increase the Corps, but to diminish, if it could be done without giving offense…" <ref>{{cite book|last=Rowland|first=Dunbar|title=Official Letter Books of W.C.C. Claiborne, 1801-1816|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JD95AAAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=Official+Letter+Books+of+W.C.C.+Claiborne&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi60OmjpfPdAhXIs1QKHVKDCvIQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=Official%20Letter%20Books%20of%20W.C.C.%20Claiborne&f=false|year=1917|publisher=Mississippi Dept. of Archives & History|pages=Vol II, p. 54–55}} {{pre-ISBN}}.</ref> A decade later, the militia of color that remained volunteered to take up arms when the British began landing troops on American soil outside of New Orleans in December 1814. This was the commencement of the [[Battle of New Orleans]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Eaton|first=Fernin|title=1811 Slave Uprising-Governor on Trial: Claiborne in His Own Words|url=https://www.academia.edu/1910804/Gov._Claiborne_in_his_own_words--a_salon_publique_at_Pitot_House_Bayou_St._John|work=Salon Publique, Pitot House, November 7, 2011, pp. 11-13|publisher=academia.edu|accessdate=June 7, 2013}}</ref>
After the [[Louisiana Purchase]], many Creoles of color lost their favorable social status, despite their service to the militia and their social status prior to the U.S. takeover. The territory and New Orleans became the destination of many migrants from the United States, as well as new immigrants. Migrants from the South imposed their [[binary slave society system|caste system]]. In this new caste system, all people with African ancestry or visible African features were classified as black, and therefore categorized as second class citizens, regardless of their education, property ownership, or previous status in French society. Former free Creoles of Color were relegated to the ranks of [[Emancipation Proclamation|emancipated slaves]].
With the advantage of having been better educated than the new [[freedman|freedmen]], many Creoles of color were active in the struggle for [[civil rights]] and served in political office during Reconstruction, helping to bring freedmen into the political system.<ref>Kathe Managan, [http://www.lameca.org/dossiers/new_orleans_creole/eng/p2.htm The Creole Community and the Struggle for Civil Rights], lameca.org, Accessed November 22, 2013.</ref><ref>Adam Fairclough, [https://books.google.com/books?id=QnQbw5EyPREC&lpg=PP1&dq=Race%20%26%20Democracy%3A%20The%20Civil%20Rights%20Struggle%20in%20Louisiana%2C%201915-1972&pg=PA1#v=onepage&q&f=false Race & Democracy: The Civil Rights Struggle in Louisiana, 1915-1972], University of Georgia Press, 2008, pp. 1-21</ref> During late [[Reconstruction Era|Reconstruction]], white Democrats regained political control of state legislatures across the former Confederate states by intimidation of blacks and other Republicans at the polls. Through the late nineteenth century, they worked to impose white supremacy under [[Jim Crow]] laws and customs. They [[Disfranchisement after Reconstruction era (United States)|disfranchised]] the majority of blacks, especially by creating barriers to voter registration through devices such as poll taxes, literacy tests, grandfather clauses, etc., stripping African Americans, including Creoles of color, of political power.
Creoles of color were among the African Americans who were limited when the [[U.S. Supreme Court]] ruled in the case of ''[[Plessy v. Ferguson]]'' in 1896, deciding that "separate but equal" accommodations were constitutional. It permitted states to impose Jim Crow rules on federal railways and later interstate buses.
Finally, more than a century later, social change had reversed much of its two-century eclipse. On June 14, 2013 Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal signed into law Act 276, creating the "prestige" license plate stating "I'm Creole", in honor of the Creoles' contributions, culture, and heritage.<ref>[http://www.legis.la.gov/legis/BillInfo.aspx?s=13RS&b=HB147&sbi=y]</ref> In the 21st century, the term [[Louisiana Creole people]], or Creole, generally refers to people of mixed-race and descendants of the early Catholic culture.
==Contribution to the arts==
===Music=== [[File:Bechet.gif|thumb|right|200px|Creole jazz musician [[Sidney Bechet]], a virtuoso on the [[soprano saxophone]]]] Some Creoles of color trained as classical musicians in 19th-century Louisiana. These musicians would often study with those associated with the French Opera House; some traveled to [[Paris]] to complete their studies. Creole composers of that time are discussed in ''[[Music and Some Highly Musical People]]'' by [[James Monroe Trotter]], and ''Nos Hommes et Notre Histoire'' by [[Rodolphe Desdunes|Rodolphe Lucien Desdunes]].

{{italic title}} {{unreferenced|date=May 2014}} [[File:CrossingTheWater.jpg|thumb|First edition (UK)]] '''''Crossing the Water''''' is a 1971 posthumous collection of poetry by [[Sylvia Plath]] that was prepared for publication by [[Ted Hughes]]. These are transitional poems that were written along with the poems that appear in her poetic opus, ''Ariel''. The collection was published in the United Kingdom by Faber & Faber (1975) and in the United States by Harper & Row (1976).
The poems here tend to dwell on one's state of being in an environment. "Wuthering Heights," for example, details a walk that Plath takes along the Yorkshire moors where [[Emily Brontë]] once trekked, Finisterre is a stormy island where Plath and her family once visited and "Among the Narcissi" describes Plath's similarities at being among asexual vegetation.
