revision.text:
{{Intersex sidebar|medicine}} {{Infobox medical condition | Name = Disorders of sex development | Image = | Caption = | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = | ICD9 = | ICDO = | OMIM = | MedlinePlus = | eMedicineSubj = | eMedicineTopic = | MeshID = D012734 }} '''Disorders of sex development''' ('''DSD'''), sometimes referred to as '''disorders of sex differentiation''' or '''differences of sex development''',<ref>{{cite journal|last=Diamond|first=Milton|author2=Hazel G. Beh|authorlink1= Milton Diamond |title=Changes in the management of children with intersex conditions|journal=Nat Clin Pract Endocrinol Metab|date=January 2008|volume=4|issue=1|pages=4–5|doi=10.1038/ncpendmet0694|pmid=17984980|url=http://www.hawaii.edu/PCSS/biblio/articles/2005to2009/2008-changes-in-management.html|accessdate=18 September 2012}}</ref> are medical conditions involving the reproductive system. More specifically, these terms refer to "[[Congenital disorder|congenital]] conditions in which development of chromosomal, gonadal, or [[anatomical sex]] is atypical."<ref name="lee">{{cite journal | author = Lee P. A., Houk C. P., Ahmed S. F., Hughes I. A. | year = 2006 | title = Consensus statement on management of intersex disorders | url =http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/cgi/reprint/118/2/e488 | journal = Pediatrics | volume = 118 | issue = 2| pages = e488–500 | doi=10.1542/peds.2006-0738| pmid = 16882788 | last2 = Houk | last3 = Ahmed | last4 = Hughes| pmc = 2082839 }}</ref>
The term has been controversial, and research has shown that affected people experience a negative impact, with the terminology impacting choice and utilization of health care providers.<ref name="johnson2017" /> The [[World Health Organization]] and many medical journals still reference DSDs as [[intersex]] traits or conditions.<ref name="bmj.g2926">{{cite journal | author = [[Rebecca Jordan-Young]], Peter Sönksen, and [[Katrina Karkazis]] | year = 2014 | title = Sex, health, and athletes | url = http://www.bmj.com/content/348/bmj.g2926 | journal = [[British Medical Journal]] | volume = 348 | issue = | page = g2926 | doi = 10.1136/bmj.g2926 | pmid=24776640}}</ref> The Council of Europe,<ref name="coe" /> and Inter-American Commission on Human Rights<ref name="iachr" /> have called for a review of medical classifications that unnecessarily medicalize intersex traits.<ref name="coe" /><ref name="iachr" /><ref name="fra" />
==Overview== {{Medref|section|date=August 2017}} DSDs are medical conditions involving the way the reproductive system develops from infancy (and before birth) through young adulthood. There are several types of DSDs and their effect on the external and internal reproductive organs varies greatly.
A frequently-used social and medical adjective for people with DSDs is "intersex".<ref name="un-2016">{{Cite| last1 = UN Committee against Torture | author1-link = United Nations Convention against Torture#Committee against Torture | last2 = UN Committee on the Rights of the Child | author2-link = Committee on the Rights of the Child | last3 = UN Committee on the Rights of People with Disabilities | author3-link = Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities | last4 = UN Subcommittee on Prevention of Torture and other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment | last5 = Juan Méndez, Special Rapporteur on torture and other cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment or punishment | author5-link = Juan E. Méndez | last6 = Dainius Pῡras, Special Rapporteur on the right of everyone to the enjoyment of the highest attainable standard of physical and mental health | last7 = Dubravka Šimonoviæ, Special Rapporteur on violence against women, its causes and consequences | last8 = Marta Santos Pais, Special Representative of the UN Secretary-General on Violence against Children | last9 =African Commission on Human and Peoples' Rights | author9-link = African Commission on Human and Peoples' Rights | last10 = Council of Europe Commissioner for Human Rights | author10-link = Commissioner for Human Rights | last11 = Inter-American Commission on Human Rights | author11-link = Inter-American Commission on Human Rights | work = [[Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights]]| title = Intersex Awareness Day – Wednesday 26 October. End violence and harmful medical practices on intersex children and adults, UN and regional experts urge| date = October 24, 2016| url = http://www.ohchr.org/EN/NewsEvents/Pages/DisplayNews.aspx?NewsID=20739&LangID=E}}</ref> Parents with DSD children and clinicians involved in DSD treatment usually try to make clear distinctions between biological sex, social gender, and sexual orientation. This helps reduce confusion about the differences between being intersex, being transgender, and being gay/lesbian.
The most common DSD is [[congenital adrenal hyperplasia]] (CAH), which results in a person with female (XX) chromosomes having genitals that look somewhat masculine. In mild cases, CAH results in a slightly enlarged clitoris, while in more severe cases it can be difficult to decide on observation whether a baby is male or female (ambiguous genitalia). CAH is caused by a problem with the adrenal glands and is usually treated by taking a daily medication to replace or supplement the missing adrenal hormones. (When this adrenal problem occurs in people with male (XY) chromosomes, the result is over-masculinization and premature puberty).
Another common DSD is [[androgen insensitivity syndrome]] (AIS),also known as testicular feminising syndrome in which a person with male (XY) chromosomes does not respond to testosterone in the usual way. This results in a body that to some degree has a feminine appearance. In complete androgen insensitivity syndrome (CAIS) the result is a totally feminine appearance, including typical female breast development. Consequently, most young women with CAIS are unaware of their condition until the early teen years when they fail to menstruate. In the milder form, called partial androgen insensitivity syndrome (PAIS), the genitals can vary from mostly female to almost completely male. Some people with PAIS think of themselves as women or girls, others regard themselves as men or boys, and some consider themselves [[genderqueer|nonbinary]].
One of the more uncommon DSDs is [[5-alpha-reductase deficiency]] (5ARD). It is caused by a shortage early in life of an enzyme that converts testosterone into DHT. DHT is required for the development of extrenal male genitilia. Therefore,In this condition, a person with male (XY) chromosomes has a body that appears female before puberty. After puberty begins, other testosterone-activating enzymes become available and the body soon takes on a masculine appearance, with the scrotum and penis usually reaching typical or nearly-typical size. If 5ARD is diagnosed at a young age, the child is often raised as a boy (a 1996 Brazilian study suggested that the majority of adults with this condition consider themselves men<ref>Mendoca et al (1996), "Male Pseudohermaphroditism Due to Steroid 5-alpha Reductase 2 Deficiency", ''Medicine'', Vol 75, No 2.</ref> but this has been questioned in some more recent research).
In addition to CAH, CAIS, PAIS, and 5ARD there are several rarer types of DSDs, and in some cases, it is not possible to make a clear diagnosis of the underlying condition.
[[File:Quigley scale for androgen insensitivity syndrome.jpg|thumb|The [[Quigley scale]] is a method for describing genital development in AIS.]] The penis (males) and clitoris (females) are essentially the same organ (differing only in size, and generically called the phallus). In typical males, the urethra is located at the tip of the penis, while in typical females the urethra is located below the base of the clitoris. When the phallus is of intermediate size, it is possible also to have a urethral opening located along the shaft; this condition is known as hypospadias which helps us raise a suspicion of DSD.
Open-minded parenting, appropriate and conservative [[intersex medical intervention|medical intervention]], and age-appropriate child involvement in the treatment plan contribute greatly to successful outcomes for the entire range of DSDs.<ref name=Zderic>{{cite book|first=Stephen |last=Zderic|title=Pediatric gender assignment : a critical reappraisal ; [proceedings from a conference ... in Dallas in the spring of 1999 which was entitled "pediatric gender assignment - a critical reappraisal"]|date=2002|publisher=Kluwer Acad. / Plenum Publ.|location=New York, NY [u.a.]|isbn=0306467593}}</ref>
==Conditions==
*'''47,XXY females''' - There are case reports of 47,XXY females; in some cases SRY or androgen receptor abnormalities are detected.<ref>Röttger, S., K. Schiebel, G. Singer, S. Ebner, W. Schempp, and G. Scherer. Röttger, S., K. Schiebel, G. Singer, S. Ebner, W. Schempp, and G. Scherer. [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11173857 "An SRY-negative 47,XXY mother and daughter."] Cytogenetics and Cell Genetics 91.1-4 (2000): 204-07. National Center for Biotechnology Information. U.S. National Library of Medicine, 2001. Web. 12 Aug. 2013.</ref> *'''47,XXY males''' - see [[Klinefelter syndrome]] below *'''[[48, XXXX]]''' (also known as '''tetrasomy X''', '''quadruple X''', and '''XXXX syndrome''') - A condition that describes a female with two extra female chromosomes. It is considered a variation of [[Triple X syndrome]]. Women with 48, XXXX may or may not have issues associated with the condition though most are developmentally delayed and only about 50% undergo puberty normally. *'''[[XXYY syndrome|48, XXYY]]''' (also known as '''XXYY syndrome''') - A condition that describes a male with one extra female chromosome and one extra male chromosome. It occurs in 1 in 18,000 to 40,000 male births.<ref name="pmid18481271">{{cite journal |vauthors=Tartaglia N, Davis S, Hench A |title=A New Look at XXYY Syndrome: Medical and Psychological Features |journal=Am. J. Med. Genet. A |volume=146A |issue=12 |pages=1509–22 |date=June 2008 |pmid=18481271 |doi=10.1002/ajmg.a.32366 |pmc=3056496 |displayauthors=etal }}</ref> 48, XXYY may result in [[infertility]], low [[testosterone]], and [[neurodevelopmental disorders]] like [[ADHD]] or [[autism]] but some men have no issues. *'''[[49, XXXXX]]''' (also known as '''pentasomy X''' and '''XXXXX syndrome''') - A condition that describes a female with three extra female chromosomes. It is considered a variant of [[Triple X syndrome]]. Women with 49, XXXXX usually suffer from numerous health issues such as [[patent ductus arteriosus]], [[scoliosis]], kidney [[hypoplasia]], and abnormal [[lobulation]] of the lungs. Physical deformities include [[microcephaly]], [[micrognathia]], and [[webbed neck|webbing of the neck]]. *'''[[49, XXXXY syndrome|49, XXXXY]]''' - A condition that describes a male with three extra female chromosomes. It is rare, occurring in 1 in 85,000 to 100,000 males.<ref name="what">[http://www.xxxxysyndrome.com/what_is___.htm What is XXXXY syndrome?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080327055333/http://xxxxysyndrome.com/what_is___.htm |date=2008-03-27 }} Retrieved March 26, 2008.</ref><ref name="pmid17062147">{{cite journal |author=Visootsak J, Graham JM |title=Klinefelter syndrome and other sex chromosomal aneuploidies |journal=Orphanet J Rare Dis |volume=1 |issue= |pages=42 |year=2006 |pmid=17062147 |pmc=1634840 |doi=10.1186/1750-1172-1-42 |url=http://www.ojrd.com/content/1//42|last2=Graham Jr }}</ref> It is considered a variation of [[Klinefelter syndrome]]. Men with 49, XXXXY syndrome often suffer from [[Intellectual disability|mental retardation]]. *'''[[5α-reductase deficiency]]''' (also known as '''5-ARD''') - An [[autosomal recessive]] condition caused by a mutation of the [[5-alpha reductase]] type 2 gene. It only affects people with Y chromosomes, namely genetic males. People with this condition are fertile, with the ability to father children, but may be raised as females due to amibiguous or feminized genitalia. *'''[[17β-Hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency]]''' - A condition characterized by impaired androgen and estrogen synthesis in males and females, respectively. Results in pseudohermaphroditism/undervirilization in males and in excessive virilization of adult females. *'''[[Androgen insensitivity syndrome]]''' (also known as '''AIS''') - A condition which affects a genetic male's virilization. A person with androgen insensitivity syndrome produces androgens and testosterone but their body does not recognize it, either partially or completely. [[Mild androgen insensitivity syndrome]] generally causes no developmental issues and people with this form are raised as males. [[Partial androgen insensitivity syndrome]] results in ambiguous genitalia and there is no consensus regarding whether to raise a child with this form as male or female. [[Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome]] causes a genetic male to have a vagina (often incompletely developed, nearly always blind-ending), breasts, and a clitoris and people with this form are raised as females. *'''[[Aphallia]]''' - A rare occurrence where a male is born without a [[penis]] or where a female is born without a [[clitoris]]. As of 2005, only 75 cases of aphallia have been documented.<ref name="pmid16142564">{{cite journal |author=Chibber PJ, Shah HN, Jain P, Yadav P |title=Male gender assignment in aphallia: a case report and review of the literature |journal=Int Urol Nephrol |volume=37 |issue=2 |pages=317–9 |year=2005 |pmid=16142564 |doi=10.1007/s11255-004-7974-0|last2=Shah |last3=Jain |last4=Yadav }}</ref> It should not be confused with [[Genital modification and mutilation|intentional or accidental amputation of the genitalia]]. *'''[[Aposthia]]''' - A congenital defect where a male is born without a [[foreskin]]. *'''[[Aromatase deficiency]]''' - A disorder in which, in females, is characterized by androgen excess and estrogen deficiency, and can result in inappropriate virilization, though without pseudohermaphroditism (i.e., genitals are phenotypically appropriate) (with the exception of the possible incidence of [[clitoromegaly]]). *'''[[Aromatase excess syndrome]]''' (also known as '''familial hyperestrogenism''') - A condition that causes excessive [[estrogen]] production, resulting in feminization without pseudohermaphroditism (i.e., male genitalia at birth and female secondary sexual characteristics at puberty) in males and hyperfeminization in females. *'''[[Clitoromegaly]]''' - A [[clitoris]] that is considered larger than average. While clitoromegaly may be a symptom of an [[intersex|intersex condition]], it may also be considered a normal variation in clitoris size. Clitoromegaly causes no health issues. Surgical reduction of the clitoris or its complete removal may be performed to normalize the appearance of the genitalia. While [[female genital mutilation]] is outlawed in many countries, reduction or the removal of the clitoris in cases of clitoromegaly are generally exempt, despite the fact that it is a nontherapeutic and sexually damaging surgery. Clitoromegaly may also be caused by females using [[testosterone (medication)|testosterone]] or [[anabolic steroids]] for purposes related to [[trans man|female to male]] [[gender transition]] or [[bodybuilding]]. *'''[[Combined 17α-hydroxylase/17,20-lyase deficiency]]''' - A condition in which presents as a combination of the symptoms of [[congenital adrenal hyperplasia]] and [[isolated 17,20-lyase deficiency]]. See those two conditions for more information. *'''[[Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome]]''' (also known as '''CAIS''') - A condition which completely affects a genetic male's ability to recognize [[androgens]]. It is considered a form of [[androgen insensitivity syndrome]] and is the most severe form. People with complete androgen insensitivity are raised as females and usually do not discover they are genetic males until they experience [[amenorrhoea]] in their late teens or they need medical intervention due to a [[hernia]] caused by their [[undescended testes]]. Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome results in a genetic male having a vagina, clitoris, and breasts which are capable of [[breastfeeding]]. However, they will not have [[ovaries]] or a [[uterus]]. Because they do not have ovaries or sufficiently developed testicles, people with complete androgen insensitivity syndrome are [[infertile]]. *'''[[Congenital adrenal hyperplasia]]''' (also known as '''CAH''') - A condition that causes excessive [[androgen]] production, which causes excessive virilization. It is most problematic in genetic females, where severe virilization can result in her having vaginal agenesis (absence of vagina) and a functional penis which is capable of penetrative intercourse. Females with this condition are usually fertile, with the ability to become pregnant and give birth. The salt-wasting variety of this condition is fatal in infants if left untreated. *'''[[Diphallia]]''' (also known as '''penile duplication''', '''diphallic terata''', and '''diphallasparatus''') - A condition where a male is born with two penises. It's extremely rare, with only 100 cases being recorded since 1609 and an occurrence rate of 1 in 5,500,000 in the United States. The penises may be side by side or one on top of the other, being of equal size or with one penis being distinctively larger than the other, and both penises may be suitable for urination and intercourse. Men with diphallia may be sterile. *'''[[Estrogen insensitivity syndrome]]''' ('''EIS''') - The estrogen counterpart to androgen insensitivity syndrome. Extremely rare, with only one verified case having been reported; a biological male presented with tall stature, a heightened risk of osteoporosis, and sterility. *'''[[Gonadal dysgenesis|Gonadal Dysgenesis]]''' - is any congenital developmental disorder of the reproductive system characterized by a progressive loss of [[primordial germ cells]] on the developing gonads of an embryo. *'''[[Isolated 17,20-lyase deficiency]]''' - A condition that is characterized by an either partial or complete inability to produce androgens and estrogens. Results in partial or complete feminization and undervirilization in males and in a delayed, reduced, or absent puberty in both sexes, in turn causing sexual infantilism and infertility, among other symptoms. *'''[[Klinefelter syndrome]]''' (also known as '''47, XXY''' and '''XXY syndrome''') - A condition that describes a male born with at least one extra female chromosome. Though the most common variation is 47, XXY, a man may also be 48, XXXY or [[49, XXXXY syndrome|49, XXXXY]]. It is a common occurrence, affecting 1 in 500 to 1,000 men.<ref name="The Focus Foundation">The Focus Foundation. ''X & Y Variations.'' [http://www.thefocusfoundation.org/FF/XYvariations.php thefocusfoundation.org] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130113082846/http://www.thefocusfoundation.org/FF/XYvariations.php |date=2013-01-13 }}</ref> While some men may have no issues related to the syndrome, some may experience [[gynecomastia]], [[micropenis]], cognitive difficulties, [[hypogonadism]], reduced fertility/[[infertility]], and/or little or no [[facial hair]]. [[Testosterone]] therapy may be pursued by men who desire a more masculine appearance and those with gynecomastia may opt to undergo a [[reduction mammoplasty]]. Men who wish to father children may be able to do so with the help of [[IVF]].<ref>{{cite journal| author=Fullerton G, Hamilton M, Maheshwari A.|title=Should non-mosaic Klinefelter syndrome men be labelled as infertile in 2009? |journal=Hum. Reprod. | volume=25| issue=3| pages=588–97| year=2010| pmid=20085911| doi=10.1093/humrep/dep431|last2=Hamilton |last3=Maheshwari }}</ref> *'''[[Leydig cell hypoplasia]]''' - A condition solely affecting biological males which is characterized by a partial or complete inactivation of the [[luteinizing hormone receptor]], resulting in stymied androgen production. Patients may present at birth with a fully female phenotype, ambiguous genitalia, or only mild genital defects such as [[micropenis]] and [[hypospadias]]. Upon puberty, sexual development is either impaired or fully absent. *'''[[Micropenis]]''' (also known as '''microphallus''') - A penis that measures 3 inches (7.62 centimeters) or less in length when erect. It is a common condition, occurring in 1 in 200 men.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/health/4071657.stm Op can boost size of micro-penis], [[BBC News]], Published December 6, 2004</ref> Micropenis may be the result of [[undervirilization]] during [[fetal development]] or may be caused by an underlying [[intersex]] condition, such as [[mild androgen insensitivity syndrome]], [[partial androgen insensitivity syndrome]], or [[Klinefelter syndrome]]. It may also be considered a natural variation of penis size. While the majority of men have no issues with having a micropenis, some may opt to use a [[prosthetic penis]] or undergo [[penile enlargement]] to increase the size of their penis. *'''[[Lipoid congenital adrenal hyperplasia]]''' - An endocrine disorder that arises from defects in the earliest stages of [[steroid hormone]] synthesis: the transport of [[cholesterol]] into the [[mitochondrion|mitochondria]] and the conversion of cholesterol to [[pregnenolone]]—the first step in the synthesis of all [[steroid hormone]]s. *'''[[Mild androgen insensitivity syndrome]]''' (also known as '''MAIS''') - A condition which mildly affects a genetic male's ability to recognize [[androgens]]. It is considered a form of [[androgen insensitivity syndrome]] and is considered the least severe form. While men generally do not need any specialized medical care related to this form, mild androgen insensitivity syndrome may result in [[gynecomastia]] and [[hypospadias]]. Neither gynecomastia nor hypospadias require surgerical intervention or adversely affect a man's health though some men may opt to undergo surgery to remove their breasts and/or repair their hypospadias. Men with mild androgen insensitivity syndrome may have reduced fertility. *'''[[Mixed gonadal dysgenesis]]''' - is a condition of unusual and asymmetrical gonadal development leading to an unassigned [[sex differentiation]]. A number of differences have been reported in the [[karyotype]], most commonly a [[mosaicism]] 45,X/ 46, XY. *'''[[Partial androgen insensitivity syndrome]]''' (also known as '''PAIS''') - A condition which partially affects a genetic male's ability to recognize [[androgens]]. It is considered a form of [[androgen insensitivity syndrome]] and while it is not as severe as [[complete androgen insensitivity syndrome]], it is more severe than [[mild androgen insensitivity syndrome]]. Partial androgen insensitivity syndrome causes major problems with [[gender assignment]] because it causes ambiguous genitalia such as a [[micropenis]] or [[clitoromegaly]] in addition to breast development. People with partial androgen insensitivity syndrome who are assigned as males may undergo testosterone therapy to virilize their body while those who are assigned as females may undergo surgical reduction of the clitoris and/ or estrogen therapy. *'''[[Pseudovaginal perineoscrotal hypospadias]]''' (also known as '''PPSH''') - A form of ambiguous genitalia which results in a phallic structure that is smaller than a penis but larger than a clitoris, a [[chordee]], [[hypospadias]], and a shallow vagina. *'''[[Swyer syndrome|Swyer Syndrome]]''' (Also known as '''Pure Gonadal Dysgenesis or XY gonadal dysgenesis''') is a type of [[hypogonadism]] in a person whose [[karyotype]] is 46,XY. The person is externally female with [[streak gonads]], and left untreated, will not experience [[puberty]]. Such gonads are typically surgically removed (as they have a significant risk of developing tumors) and a typical medical treatment would include [[hormone replacement therapy]] with female hormones. *'''[[Triple X syndrome]]''' - A condition that describes a female born with an extra female chromosome, making her [[karotype]] 47, XXX. It is a common occurrence, affecting 1 in 1,000 females.<ref name=ghr>{{cite web |author=National Library of Medicine |title=Genetics Home Reference: Triple X syndrome |year=2007 |url=http://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/condition=triplexsyndrome |accessdate=2007-03-22}}</ref> It generally causes no health issues or abnormal development. *'''[[Turner syndrome]]''' (also known as '''Ullrich-Turner syndrome''' and '''gonadal dysgenesis''') - A condition that describes a female born without a female chromosome or with an abnormal female chromosome, making her karotype 45, XO. It occurs in 1 in 2,000 to 5,000 females. Turner syndrome causes numerous health and development problems, including but not limited to short stature, [[lymphedema]], [[infertility]], [[webbed neck]], [[coarctation of the aorta]], [[ADHD]], [[amenorrhoea]], and [[obesity]]. *'''[[Uterus didelphys]]''' (also known as '''double uterus''') - A condition where a female is born with two [[uteri]]. It is often accompanied by two vaginas. It is generally not considered a health issue and women with uterus didelphys usually have normal sex lives and pregnancies.<ref>[http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/double-uterus/DS00821 Double uterus] [[Mayo Clinic]], Published September 11, 2010</ref> *'''[[Müllerian agenesis]]''' (also known as '''MRKH''' or '''Vaginal Agenesis''') - A condition that causes the uterus and other reproductive organs in a 46,XX female to be small or absent, as well as the vaginal canal itself. It affects 1 out of 4,500 to 5,000 females and can also come with skeletal or endocrine system issues at conception.
==Controversy== {{further|Intersex human rights|Intersex medical interventions}} The term DSD (and particularly its association with medical ''disorders'') has been controversial. The argument over terminology reflects a deeper disagreement over the extent to which intersex conditions require medical intervention, the appropriateness of certain interventions, and whether physicians and parents should make irreversible treatment decisions on behalf of young children if the condition is not life-threatening.
* Use of the term disorder of sex development (DSD) is controversial among many activists and [[Intersex civil society organizations|community organizations]] due to the label "disorders".<ref name="tiger" /><ref>{{Cite web| last = interACT| authorlink = Interact Advocates for Intersex Youth | title = interACT Statement on Intersex Terminology| work = [[Interact Advocates for Intersex Youth]]| accessdate = 30 May 2016| date = May 2016 | url = http://interactadvocates.org/interact-statement-on-intersex-terminology/}}</ref><ref>{{Citation| last = Briffa| first = Tony| author-link = Tony Briffa | title = Tony Briffa writes on "Disorders of Sex Development"| date = 8 May 2014 | url = http://oii.org.au/26808/tony-briffa-on-dsd/ | publisher = [[Organisation Intersex International Australia]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ukia.co.uk/ukia/dsd.html | title = Why Not "Disorders of Sex Development"? | work = UK Intersex Association | accessdate = 30 May 2016}}</ref> Many governments and international institutions use the term 'intersex' in preference to 'DSD', or have called for the review of medical classifications.<ref name="coe" /><ref name="iachr" /> * In the past the term "hermaphrodite" was sometimes erroneously used to describe people with intersex/DSD conditions. This term is no longer used to describe humans (or any other mammals). The correct technical definition of a hermaphrodite is a single organism that has complete sets of both male and female sexual organs, as is the case with most trees and flowering plants. * Lee et al. in a 2006 ''Consensus statement on management of intersex disorders'' proposed a system of nomenclature based on "disorders of [[sex development]]" for clinical use, suggesting that "terms such as [[intersex]], [[pseudohermaphroditism]], [[hermaphroditism]], sex reversal, and gender based diagnostic labels are particularly controversial," may be perceived as pejorative, and are confusing to practitioners and parents alike.<ref name="lee" /> However, research by the [[Lurie Children's Hospital]], Chicago, and the AIS-DSD Support Group published in 2017 found that affected persons, and care givers, object to the term, and that this may impact choice, access, and utilization of health care providers.<ref name="johnson2017">{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1016/j.jpurol.2017.03.035| issn = 1477-5131| last1 = Johnson| first1 = Emilie K.| last2 = Rosoklija| first2 = Ilina| last3 = Finlayso| first3 = Courtney| last4 = Chen| first4 = Diane| last5 = Yerkes| first5 = Elizabeth B.| last6 = Madonna| first6 = Mary Beth| last7 = Holl| first7 = Jane L.| last8 = Baratz| first8 = Arlene B.| last9 = Davis| first9 = Georgiann| last10 = Cheng| first10 = Earl Y.| author9-link = Georgiann Davis | title = Attitudes towards "disorders of sex development" nomenclature among affected individuals| journal = Journal of Pediatric Urology| volume = 13| issue = 6| pages = 608.e1| date = May 2017| url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1477513117301833}}</ref> Australian sociological research on people born with atypical [[sex characteristics]], published in 2016, found that 3% of respondents choose the term "disorders of sex development" or "DSD" to define their sex characteristics, while 21% use the term when accessing medical services. In contrast, 60% used the term "intersex" in some form to self-describe their sex characteristics.<ref name="jones2016">{{Cite book| publisher = Open Book Publishers| isbn = 978-1-78374-208-0| last1 = Jones| first1 = Tiffany| last2 = Hart| first2 = Bonnie| last3 = Carpenter| first3 = Morgan| last4 = Ansara| first4 = Gavi| last5 = Leonard| first5 = William| last6 = Lucke| first6 = Jayne| title = Intersex: Stories and Statistics from Australia| location = Cambridge, UK| date = 2016| accessdate = 2 February 2016| url = http://oii.org.au/wp-content/uploads/key/Intersex-Stories-Statistics-Australia.pdf| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160914152729/http://oii.org.au/wp-content/uploads/key/Intersex-Stories-Statistics-Australia.pdf| archivedate = 14 September 2016| df = }}</ref> * In "We Used to Call Them Hermaphrodites," Eric Vilain states that "DSD" is not a synonym for [[intersex]]; he states that it replaces medical terms based on "hermaphrodite".<ref name="vilain">{{cite journal | author = Vilain E, Achermann JC, Eugster EA, Harley VR, Morel Y, Wilson JD, Hiort O | year = 2007 | title = We used to call them hermaphrodites | url = | journal = Genetics in Medicine | volume = 9 | issue = 2| pages = 65–66 | doi=10.1097/gim.0b013e31802cffcf| pmid = 17304046 | last2 = Achermann | last3 = Eugster | last4 = Harley | last5 = Morel | last6 = Wilson | last7 = Hiort }}</ref> * A committee of the [[Senate of Australia]] found that labelling intersex as "pejorative" appeared to be a post-hoc rationalisation in the 2006 ''Consensus statement''. It recommended a review of clinical use of the term.<ref name="SenateOnSterilisation">{{cite web|url=http://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Senate/Community_Affairs/Involuntary_Sterilisation/Sec_Report/index | work = Senate Community Affairs Committee|title=Involuntary or coerced sterilisation of intersex people in Australia|date=October 2013}}</ref> * Academics like [[Georgiann Davis]]<ref name="davis-dsd">{{Cite journal|url=http://www.emeraldinsight.com/books.htm?chapterid=1943090 |first=Georgiann |last=Davis|authorlink=Georgiann Davis| date =2011|title =DSD is a Perfectly Fine Term": Reasserting Medical Authority through a Shift in Intersex Terminology|editor1-first= PJ |editor1-last=McGann|editor2-first=David J. |editor2-last=Hutson|journal=Sociology of Diagnosis (Advances in Medical Sociology)|volume =12|publisher=Emerald Group Publishing Limited|pages=155–182}}</ref> and [[Morgan Holmes]], and clinical psychologists like [[Tiger Devore]]<ref name="tiger">{{cite web|url=http://wewhofeeldifferently.info/interview.php?interview=108 |title=An Interview with Dr. Tiger Howard Devore PhD|work=We Who Feel Differently|date=February 7, 2011}}</ref> argue that the term DSD was designed to "reinstitutionalise" medical authority over intersex bodies, making intersex bodies more treatable and more of a stigma" (Holmes).<ref name="morgan-name">{{cite journal | year = 2011| title = The Intersex Enchiridion: Naming and Knowledge in the Clinic | url = http://www.euppublishing.com/doi/abs/10.3366/soma.2011.0026?journalCode=soma | journal = Somatechnics | volume = 1 | issue = 2| pages = 87–114 | doi = 10.3366/soma.2011.0026 | last1 = Holmes| first1 = Morgan|authorlink = Morgan Holmes}}</ref> or place intersex "neatly into medical turf and safely away from critics of its medicalisation" (Davis).<ref name="davis-dsd" /> * In a 2013 paper on [[Preimplantation genetic diagnosis]] and "intersex conditions" Professor Jeff Nisker describes how, "Once a difference |url=http://www.hawaii.edu/PCSS/biblio/articles/2005to2009/2007-managing-variation.html}}</ref> or of "difference",<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Diamond |first1=Milton |last2=Beh |first2=Hazel |url=http://www.hawaii.edu/PCSS/biblio/articles/2005to2009/2008-changes-in-management.html |doi=10.1038/ncpendmet0694 |pmid=17984980}}</ref> Elizabeth Reis has suggested "divergence";<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1353/pbm.2007.0054 |last1=Reis |first1=Elizabeth |year=2007 |title=Divergence or Disorder? |journal=Perspectives in Biology and Medicine |volume=50|issue=4 |pages=535–543 | url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/5893631_Divergence_or_disorder_the_politics_of_naming_intersex |pmid=17951887}}</ref> Liao and Simmonds suggest "diverse sex development".<ref name="Liao2013">{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1080/19419899.2013.831217| issn = 1941-9899| volume = 5| issue = 1| pages = 83–101| last1 = Liao| first1 = Lih-Mei| last2 = Simmonds| first2 = Margaret| title = A values-driven and evidence-based health care psychology for diverse sex development| journal = Psychology & Sexuality| date = 2013| url = http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/19419899.2013.831217}}</ref> The latter suggestions would retain the initial D in DSD.
The 2006 ''Consensus statement on management of intersex disorders'' stated that evidence for early surgery for cosmetic reasons is lacking, outcomes include "decreased sexual sensitivity" and long term outcome data is absent.<ref name="lee" /> A 2016 ''Global Disorders of Sex Development Update since 2006'' states that there is "still no consensual attitude regarding indications, timing, procedure and evaluation of outcome of DSD surgery" and "no evidence regarding the impact of surgically treated or non-treated DSDs during childhood for the individual, the parents, society or the risk of stigmatization".<ref name="2016dsd">{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1159/000442975| pmid = 26820577| issn = 1663-2818| volume = 85| issue = 3| pages = 158| last1 = Lee| first1 = Peter A.| last2 = Nordenström| first2 = Anna| last3 = Houk| first3 = Christopher P.| last4 = Ahmed| first4 = S. Faisal| last5 = Auchus| first5 = Richard| last6 = Baratz| first6 = Arlene| last7 = Baratz Dalke| first7 = Katharine| last8 = Liao| first8 = Lih-Mei| last9 = Lin-Su| first9 = Karen| last10 = Looijenga| first10 = Leendert H.J.| last11 = Mazur| first11 = Tom| last12 = Meyer-Bahlburg| first12 = Heino F.L.| last13 = Mouriquand| first13 = Pierre| last14 = Quigley| first14 = Charmian A.| last15 = Sandberg| first15 = David E.| last16 = Vilain| first16 = Eric| last17 = Witchel| first17 = Selma| last18 = and the Global DSD Update Consortium| authorlink12= Heino Meyer-Bahlburg|title = Global Disorders of Sex Development Update since 2006: Perceptions, Approach and Care| journal = Hormone Research in Paediatrics| date = January 28, 2016 | url = http://www.karger.com/?doi=10.1159/000442975}}</ref>
In 2013, [[Juan E. Méndez]], the [[United Nations Special Rapporteur]] on torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, condemned "irreversible sex assignment, involuntary sterilization, involuntary genital normalizing surgery, performed without their informed consent, or that of their parents, “in an attempt to fix their sex”" stating that "members of sexual minorities are disproportionately subjected to torture and other forms of ill-treatment because they fail to conform to socially constructed gender expectations".<ref name="Mendez2013">{{Cite conference| last = Méndez| first = Juan| authorlink= Juan E. Méndez| title = Report of the Special Rapporteur on torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, A.HRC.22.53| date = February 2013| url = http://www.ohchr.org/Documents/HRBodies/HRCouncil/Regularsession/Session22/A.HRC.22.53_English.pdf}}</ref>
In May 2014, the [[World Health Organization]] issued a joint statement on ''Eliminating forced, coercive and otherwise involuntary sterilization, An interagency statement'' with the [[OHCHR]], [[UN Women]], [[UNAIDS]], [[UNDP]], [[UNFPA]] and [[UNICEF]]. Referencing the involuntary surgical "sex-normalising or other procedures" on "intersex persons", the report recommends a range of guiding principles for medical treatment, including ensuring patient autonomy in decision-making, ensuring non-discrimination, accountability and access to remedies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/reproductivehealth/publications/gender_rights/eliminating-forced-sterilization/en/ |title=Eliminating forced, coercive and otherwise involuntary sterilization, An interagency statement|work= [[World Health Organization]]|date=May 2014}}</ref>
During 2015, the [[Council of Europe]],<ref name="coe" /> and [[Inter-American Commission on Human Rights]]<ref name="iachr" /> called for a review of medical classifications that unnecessarily medicalize intersex traits<ref name="coe">{{Citation| last1 = Council of Europe| last2 = Commissioner for Human Rights| authorlink2= Commissioner for Human Rights |title = Human rights and intersex people, Issue Paper | date = April 2015 | url = https://wcd.coe.int/ViewDoc.jsp?Ref=CommDH/IssuePaper(2015)1&Language=lanEnglish&Ver=original}}</ref><ref name="iachr">{{Citation| last = Comisión Interamericana de Derechos Humanos| authorlink = Inter-American Commission on Human Rights| title = Violencia contra Personas Lesbianas, Gays, Bisexuales, Trans e Intersex en América| date = November 12, 2015| url = http://www.oas.org/es/cidh/informes/pdfs/ViolenciaPersonasLGBTI.pdf|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref name="fra">{{Citation| last = European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights| authorlink = Fundamental Rights Agency|title = The fundamental rights situation of intersex people| date = April 2015| url = http://fra.europa.eu/sites/default/files/fra-2015-focus-04-intersex.pdf}}</ref> an end to medical interventions without consent, and improved disclosure. The Council of Europe's Human Rights Commissioner recommended: {{quotation|National and international medical classifications which pathologise variations in sex characteristics should be reviewed with a view to eliminating obstacles to the effective enjoyment, by intersex persons, of human rights, including the right to the highest attainable standard of health.<ref name="coe" />}}
The [[Fundamental Rights Agency|European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights]]<ref name="fra" /> and UN Treaty Bodies have called for informed consent by individuals subjected to medical treatment, improved disclosure, and access to redress.<ref name="crpd">{{Citation| publisher = United Nations| last1 = United Nations| last2 = Committee on the Rights of Persons with Diabilities| title = Concluding observations on the initial report of Germany (advance unedited version)| location = Geneva| date = April 17, 2015 | url = http://tbinternet.ohchr.org/_layouts/treatybodyexternal/Download.aspx?symbolno=CRPD%2FC%2FDEU%2FCO%2F1&Lang=en}}</ref><ref name="crc-ch">{{Citation| publisher = United Nations| last1 = United Nations| last2 = Committee on the Rights of Child| title = Concluding observations on the combined second to fourth periodic reports of Switzerland| location = Geneva| date = February 26, 2015 | url = http://tbinternet.ohchr.org/_layouts/treatybodyexternal/Download.aspx?symbolno=CRC%2fC%2fCHE%2fCO%2f2-4&Lang=en}}</ref>

| notes = Responsible body: [[Instituto de Antropología e Historia|IDAEH]]
| designation1 = | designation1_offname = | designation1_type = | designation1_criteria = | designation1_date = | delisted1_date = | designation1_partof = | designation1_number = | designation1_free1name = | designation1_free1value = | designation1_free2name = | designation1_free2value = | designation1_free3name = | designation1_free3value = | designation2 = | designation2_offname = | designation2_type = | designation2_criteria = | designation2_date = | delisted2_date = | designation2_partof = | designation2_number = | designation2_free1name = | designation2_free1value = | designation2_free2name = | designation2_free2value = | designation2_free3name = | designation2_free3value = | precolumbian = yes <!-- non-functional tracking parameter, do not remove/change --> }} '''El Chal''' is a [[pre-Columbian]] [[Maya civilization|Maya]] archaeological site located in the upper [[San Juan River (Guatemala)|San Juan River]] valley of the southeastern [[Petén Basin]] region, [[Guatemala]]. The site is situated approximately {{convert|30|km|mi}} to the north of the modern town of [[Dolores, Guatemala|Dolores]], near the contemporary village settlement of the same name, lying some {{convert|600|m|ft}} to the south.
El Chal was occupied from approximately 300 BC through to 1300 AD (from the Late Preclassic through to the Early Postclassic Periods of [[Mesoamerican chronology]]),<ref name="Suasnávar98354"/> although some Middle Preclassic activity has been identified in the acropolis.<ref name="Reyes08p255"/> The Late Preclassic occupation of the city was concentrated around an [[E-Group]] ceremonial complex some {{convert|2|km|mi}} north of the later site core.<ref>Quezada et al 1998, pp.3, 11-12.</ref> The site's major period of occupation was during the Late Classic Period, when it was an important centre in the southeastern Petén region.<ref name="Laporte05212">Laporte 2005, p.212.</ref> Among the structures at the site is a large quadrangular residential complex, a structural type that is uncommonly found at Southern Maya lowland sites although there is a smaller one with similar characteristics at [[Machaquilá]].
{{As of|2010}} very little restorative work has been undertaken at the site. The archaeological site is protected by the Guatemalan [[Instituto de Antropología e Historia]].<ref name="Morales493">Morales 1995, p.493.</ref>
{{TOC limit|4}}
==Location== [[File:El Chal 1.jpg|thumb|left|Entrance to the archaeological site]] El Chal is located in the [[Municipalities of Guatemala|municipality]] of [[Dolores, Petén|Dolores]] in the [[Departments of Guatemala|department]] of [[Petén Department|Petén]] in northern Guatemala.<ref name="Morales493"/> El Chal is {{convert|40|km|mi}} south of [[Flores, El Petén|Flores]], the departmental capital.<ref name="Suasnávar98354">Suasnávar 1998, p.354.</ref> The archaeological site is within the southern area of a village also named El Chal,<ref name="Morales493"/> {{convert|600|m|ft}} to the south of the highway to Flores.<ref name="Morales495">Morales 1995, p.494.</ref> The site is situated in the central Petén wet [[savanna]] in a well-drained area not subject to seasonal flooding.<ref name="Morales493"/> The local topography is [[Karst topography|karstic]] in nature, and includes hills that support some of the city's architecture.<ref name="Morales94368">Morales et al 1994, p.368.</ref>
El Chal is located within the valley of the [[San Juan River (Guatemala)|San Juan River]], which is a tributary of the [[Pasión River]], at an altitude of {{convert|270|m|ft}} [[above mean sea level]].<ref name="Morales493"/> The site is situated on a natural north-south communication route between the [[Maya Mountains]] and the central Petén region.<ref name="Morales493"/> This route was used during the Colonial Period and was likely to have been inherited from pre-Conquest times.<ref name="Morales493"/>
Some of the major architecture of the site core is covered by secondary forest, including some large trees, while much of the city's remains lie within the modern village, including mounds of various sizes.<ref name="Morales9314">Morales 1993, p.14.</ref> Some mounds were destroyed in order to build the modern streets, in other cases the mounds were robbed of stone that was reused in modern construction.<ref name="Morales9314"/> There are also instances where modern houses have been built on top of ancient mound platforms.<ref name="Morales9314"/> Modern houses had previously also occupied the outskirts of the acropolis but were relocated during the [[Guatemalan Civil War]] in the late 20th century due to guerrilla activity.<ref name="Morales9315">Morales 1993, p.15.</ref> {{clear}}
==History== El Chal was first occupied in the [[Mesoamerican chronology|Middle Preclassic Period]], with ceramics associated with a burial being recovered from the acropolis.<ref name="Reyes08p255"/> Late Preclassic occupation has only been identified in a few residential groups in the site core.<ref>Morales 1995, p.499. Quezada et al 1998, p.20.</ref> During the Preclassic the centre of the city was probably situated some distance to the northeast of the Late Classic centre, where a large ritual complex is located.<ref name="Laporte05212"/>
[[File:El Chal 4.jpg|thumb|right|Badly eroded lower panel of Stela 4, depicting three kneeling captives]] The major period of occupation at the site was during the Late Classic, when most of the major [[Maya architecture|architecture]] was built.<ref name="Morales499">Morales 1995, p.499.</ref> At this time the city centre was moved to the site core around the newly built acropolis complex.<ref name="Quezada9820">Quezada et al 1998, p.20.</ref> The sculpted monuments of the city indicate that it was important enough during the Late Classic to possess its own [[Maya script#Emblem glyphs|Emblem Glyph]].<ref name="Morales499"/> The city experienced a period of intensive construction lasting from the Late Classic through to the Terminal Classic.<ref name="Laporte05212"/> All hieroglyphic texts sculpted on monuments at El Chal date to the 8th century AD, although the inscriptions are heavily eroded.<ref name="Laporte05212"/> The residential groups constructed upon platforms in Panorama Sector were built in the Late Classic, when a flint workshop was in production in Panorama Group 19.<ref name="Quezada9818"/> During the Late Classic occupation also expanded throughout the other sectors of the city; Arrepentimiento, Municipal and Central.<ref name="Quezada9820"/>
During the Terminal Classic, El Chal maintained its primary place in the San Juan valley.<ref name="Laporte05225">Laporte 2005, p.225.</ref> This is evidenced by major building activity in the site core where the massive structures were underwent new phases of construction and by the erection of new monuments to accompany the already existing Late Classic monuments.<ref name="Laporte05228">Laporte 2005, p.228.</ref> The continued importance of El Chal in the Terminal Classic resulted in other centres in the region being eclipsed, such as El Edén and El Tigrillo to the west and Copoja, La Puente and El Ocote to the southeast.<ref name="Laporte05228"/> During the Terminal Classic, El Chal developed its own ceramic production industry.<ref name="Quezada9820"/>
In spite of the continued intensive activity in the site core, in Panorama Sector and the other peripheral residential sectors there was a diminishing of activity compared to the Late Classic, perhaps leading up to the abandonment of the city.<ref name="Quezada9818"/>
[[Mesoamerican chronology|Postclassic Period]] occupation of El Chal has been identified from ceramic fragments recovered from Structure 1 in the Northwest Plaza.<ref name="Chocon08p404">Chocón 2008, p.404.</ref> A few Postclassic [[Sherd|potsherds]] were also excavated from Group 15 in the Central Sector.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap60"/>
===Modern history=== The name El Chal first appears on a Spanish Colonial watercolour from 1735 together with other villages in the region, with the name of El Chal or El Chacal.<ref name="Morales493"/> It also appears on a map of central and southeastern Petén from 1860, together with [[Poptún]], Concepción, [[San Clemente, El Petén|San Clemente]] and the ruins of [[Ixkun]].<ref>Morales 1995, pp.493-494.</ref> Some of the stonework from the ruins has been stripped to be used in the construction of the modern village.<ref name="Morales495"/>
The site was visited by archaeologists Richard Kirsch and [[Ian Graham]] in 1974 and 1975 but their work was never published.<ref name="Morales495"/> In 1989 the Atlas Arqueológico de Guatemala mapped the site and catalogued the remaining monuments.<ref name="Morales495"/> In 1993 the first test excavations took place and an area of {{convert|4|km2|sqmi}} around the site core was explored.<ref name="Morales495"/>
In the 1970s some sculpted monuments were removed from El Chal by FYDEP (''Fomento y Desarrollo del Petén'' - "Petén Patronage and Development") and were later transferred to the [[Tikal]] National Park.<ref name="Morales495"/> By the mid-1990s the exact location and identity of these monuments had been lost.<ref name="Morales495"/>
Further excavations have taken place since the 1990s, including investigations of the West Plaza in 2003, the East Plaza in 2004, the acropolis in 2005–2006 and the Northwest Plaza in 2006.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap42">Reyes & Laporte 2005a, p.42.</ref><ref>Chocón 2008, p.402. Reyes 2008, p.245.</ref>
==Site description== [[File:El Chal 14.jpg|thumb|right|Front of Stela 4 showing an 8th-century ruler]] The site core of El Chal consists of an acropolis and three ceremonial plazas in which the majority of sculpted monuments were found, the East Plaza, West Plaza and Northeast Plaza.<ref name="Morales495"/> There are also a number of other plazas in the site core.<ref name="Morales495"/> The plazas and the majority of the residential structures were laid out upon naturally level terrain, while the acropolis was built upon a natural [[limestone]] hill and a very few residential groups were built upon artificial basal platforms.<ref name="Morales495"/>
A reservoir is located to the northwest of the acropolis.<ref name="Morales495"/> It was built with irregular limestone blocks and measures {{convert|65|m|ft}} across.<ref name="Morales495"/> In the rain season it fills to a depth of {{convert|2|m|ft}} and contains {{convert|400|m3|cuft}}.<ref name="Morales495"/> A second, natural reservoir, is located to the south of the artificial reservoir and west of the acropolis.<ref name="Morales9317">Morales 1993, p.17.</ref> In the rain season it also fills to a depth of {{convert|2|m|ft}}.<ref name="Morales9317"/>
The large ritual complex of El Chal was located a considerable distance to the northeast of the civic centre of the city and was probably first built in the Preclassic Period.<ref name="Laporte05212"/>
Archaeologists have mapped 268 structures clustered in 53 groups around approximately 68 patios in the site core.<ref name="Morales496">Morales 1995, p.496.</ref> Residential structures were concentrated in the area surrounding the ceremonial centre, especially on the north and west sides near to the reservoir.<ref name="Morales496"/> Residences tended to be larger the closer they were to the reservoir.<ref name="Morales498"/> The residential area of El Chal was extensive and archaeologists have divided it into four sectors.<ref name="Laporte05212"/> Municipal consists of the area occupied by the modern village, El Arrepentimiento is the northeastern portion of the site, Panorama is the northwestern area, and Central is the site core.<ref name="Quezada981">Quezada et al 1998, p.1.</ref> Central El Chal contains 25 groups, Arrepentimiento contains 40 groups, Panorama contains 53 groups and Municipal contains 18 groups.<ref>Laporte 2005, p.212. Quezada et al 1998, pp.15-16.</ref> Panorama was an area of [[chert]] production while Municipal is associated with the ritual complex of the city.<ref name="Laporte05212"/>
===Central Sector===
====Acropolis==== The '''acropolis''' was built on a {{convert|30|m|ft|adj=on}} high limestone hill.<ref name="Morales495"/> The base is almost square, measuring {{convert|140|m|ft}} on each side.<ref name="Morales495"/> The acropolis complex faced northwards onto the south side of the West Plaza.<ref name="Corzo0571">Corzo et al 2005, p.71.</ref> The upper part of the hill was levelled into three wide terraces with an average area of {{convert|2800|m2|sqft}}.<ref name="Morales495"/> The terraces were linked by a sunken stairway on the north side of the acropolis.<ref name="Morales495"/> The architecture of the acropolis is arranged in six groups.<ref name="Corzo0572">Corzo et al 2005, p.72.</ref>
=====Terraces===== '''Terrace 1''' is the highest terrace in the acropolis.<ref name="Morales495">Morales 1995, p.494.</ref> It supports three small patios labelled as Patios A, B and C.<ref name="Morales495"/> These patios are laid out between 10 structures.<ref name="Morales495"/> Among the structures found on Terrace 1, Structures 1, 3, 5 and 6 have been excavated by archaeologists.<ref name="Morales94370">Morales et al 1994, p.370.</ref> Structure 5 is the largest, on the west side of Patio A.<ref name="Morales9315"/> Terrace 1 has been dated to the Late and Terminal Classic.<ref name="Morales94370"/> A complex stairway divided into three flights gave access to the terrace from the south side.<ref name="Reyes08p272">Reyes 2008, p.272.</ref> The upper flight descended seven steps to a small room measuring {{convert|1.3|by|1.5|m|ft}}.<ref name="Reyes08p272"/> These steps had a tread of {{convert|0.3|m|ft}} and a riser of {{convert|0.25|m|ft}}.<ref name="Reyes08p272"/> The second flight descended from the small room to another similar room, and the third flight descended in the opposite direction to the terrace supporting Patio F (Terrace 3).<ref name="Reyes08p272"/> The wall of the upper flight was decorated with a sculpted bas-relief frame, the wall of the middle flight was coated with stucco and were painted with a red and black design.<ref name="Reyes08p272"/>
[[File:El Chal map of site core.jpg|thumb|right|350px|Map of the site core showing the acropolis, and the East and West Plazas.]] '''Terrace 2''' is situated {{convert|10|m|ft}} below Terrace 1.<ref name="Morales9315"/> It is divided into two patios (Patios D and E) by a {{convert|9|m|ft|adj=on}} high [[Mesoamerican pyramids|pyramid]] temple.<ref name="Morales495"/> Patio D was accessed via a stairway from the West Plaza directly to the north, the stairway rose in two sections with a minor terrace between them, referred to as the Lower Terrace.<ref>Corzo et al 2005, pp.72-73.</ref> The lower section of the stairway measured {{convert|59|m|ft}} long, extending {{convert|5|m|ft}} into the plaza at its lower end.<ref name="Corzo0572"/> Material excavated from the area around the stairway where it joined the base of the acropolis has been dated to the Late and Terminal Classic.<ref name="Corzo0572"/> Patio D itself was laid out at the very beginning of the Late Classic Period.<ref name="Corzo0580"/> It was resurfaced a number of times in the Late Classic, and the earliest of the surrounding structures were built at this time.<ref name="Corzo0580"/> Additional structures were built in the Terminal Classic, and the patio area was extended with the construction of the adjacent Patio G.<ref name="Corzo0580"/> Patio E was also accessed via a stairway from the base of the acropolis, although it is very poorly preserved.<ref name="Corzo0577"/> Ceramics recovered from the western portion of the Lower Terrace dated it to the Late and Terminal Classic.<ref name="Corzo0578">Corzo et al 2005, p.78.</ref> A low platform was excavated in the extreme southwestern corner of the Lower Terrace, although most of the ceramic finds were dated to the Terminal Classic, some pieces dating to the Late Preclassic were also found.<ref name="Corzo0580">Corzo et al 2005, p.80.</ref>
'''Terrace 3''' is located on the southwest side of the acropolis at the same height as Terrace 2.<ref>Morales 1993, p.315. Morales 1995, p.495.</ref> It supports one residential patio group, Patio F, formed by five structures.<ref name="Morales495"/>
=====Patio A===== '''Patio A''' was formed by a group of 5 buildings serving a dual residential and administrative function.<ref name="Reyes08p245">Reyes 2008, p.245.</ref> Evidence of this is the fact that the structures in the group were divided into multiple rooms with internal benches,<ref name="Reyes08p245"/> a form of architecture that is recognised as being a palace and that may serve for either elite domestic or administrative activity.<ref>Seibert 2006, p.110.</ref> The stone blocks used in construction measured approximately {{convert|40|cm|in}} on each side with a finely dressed front face, tapering towards the back in order to grip the structural fill.<ref name="Reyes08p246"/> This patio is situated on the west side of the main terrace of the acropolis, Terrace 1.<ref name="Reyes08p245"/> Patio A has an area of {{convert|432|m2|sqft}}, with the largest building on the west side.<ref name="Reyes08p245"/> Patio B lies to the east and Patio C to the west, a lower terrace supports Patio F to the southwest and Patio D to the north.<ref name="Reyes08p245"/> The patio was accessed via a short 3-step stairway on the southeast side.<ref>Reyes 2008, p.247.</ref>
Excavations identified 3 construction phases in Patio A, with the first two dating to the Late Classic and the final phase dating to the Terminal Classic.<ref name="Reyes08p246">Reyes 2008, p.246.</ref>
[[File:El Chal 23.jpg|thumb|left|The heavily forested acropolis as seen from the West Plaza]] '''Terrace 1 Structure 1''' is on the north side of Patio A.<ref name="Morales94371">Morales et al 1994, p.371.</ref> It consists of a long platform access via a {{convert|23|m|ft|adj=on}} wide stairway on the south side.<ref>Morales 1994, p.371. Reyes 2008, pp.247, 252.</ref> The stairway had three steps, each with a tread of {{convert|0.6|m|ft}} and a riser measuring {{convert|0.35|m|ft}}.<ref name="Reyes08p252"/> Structure 1 experienced two construction phases, in the Late Classic and in the Terminal Classic.<ref name="Reyes08p252"/> In its final form it measured {{convert|34|m|ft}} long by {{convert|8.5|m|ft}} wide and stood {{convert|1.4|m|ft}} high.<ref name="Reyes08p252">Reyes 2008, p.252.</ref> The superstructure of the building possessed a C-shaped bench.<ref name="Reyes08p252"/>
'''Terrace 1 Structure 2''' is on the northeast side of Patio A.<ref name="Reyes08p255">Reyes 2008, p.255.</ref> It was a single level platform measuring {{convert|8|by|5|m|ft}} by {{convert|2|m|ft}} high.<ref name="Reyes08p255"/> It was accessed via a projecting stairway measuring {{convert|5|m|ft}} wide and protruding {{convert|1.5|m|ft}} from the structure.<ref name="Reyes08p255"/> The five steps each had a tread of {{convert|0.25|m|ft}} and a riser measuring {{convert|0.24|m|ft}}.<ref name="Reyes08p255"/> Archaeologists were unable to investigate the summit of Structure 2 due to the large size of the trees growing upon it.<ref name="Reyes08p255"/> The structure clearly shows two construction phases, the first dating to the Late Classic and the second to the Terminal Classic.<ref name="Reyes08p255"/> Finds dating to the Middle Preclassic were recovered from trenches sunk into the patio in front of the structure, consisting of 378 potsherds associated with Burial 265.<ref name="Reyes08p255"/> A Late Classic cache was also found at the base of the stairway, consisting of 2 [[Eccentric flint (archaeology)|eccentric]] [[Obsidian use in Mesoamerica|obsidian]] artefacts shaped like [[centipede]]s, a flint arrowhead, various pieces of waste flint, and a number of flint blades and obsidian [[prismatic blade]]s.<ref name="Reyes08p261">Reyes 2008, p.261.</ref>
'''Terrace 1 Structure 3''' is on the east side of Patio A and separates it from Patio B.<ref name="Morales94371"/> Structure 3 was built in two construction phases.<ref name="Morales94371"/> The first phase was covered in stucco and raised {{convert|1.3|m|ft}} above the level of the patio.<ref name="Morales94371"/> The second phase consisted of a square platform that was {{convert|1.8|m|ft}} high.<ref name="Morales94371"/> A bench on the east side of the platform raised the height to {{convert|2.1|m|ft}} above the floor of the patio.<ref name="Morales94371"/> Structure 3 was built from small limestone blocks around a rubble core.<ref name="Morales94371"/> In its final form the structure was a rectangular platform measuring {{convert|17|by|14.5|m|ft}} and standing {{convert|3|m|ft}} high.<ref name="Reyes08p262">Reyes 2008, p.262.</ref> The stairway measured {{convert|7.5|m|ft}} wide and was divided into two by a {{convert|2.5|m|ft}} block.<ref name="Reyes08p262"/> The platform supported a bench measuring {{convert|13.5|by|7|m|ft}}.<ref name="Reyes08p262"/> An incomplete human skeleton was found next to the south wall (Burial 73), together with broken ceramic fragments dating to the Terminal Classic.<ref name="Morales94371"/> Although material excavated from the two construction phases has been dated to the Late Preclassic and the Early Classic, this material is believed to have been transported there and used as infill during the Late Classic construction of the building and not to represent earlier phases of the structure itself.<ref name="Reyes08p262"/>
'''Terrace 1 Structure 4''' is on the south side of Patio A.<ref name="Reyes08p263">Reyes 2008, p.263.</ref> The earliest version of the building measured {{convert|31|by|6.5|m|ft}}.<ref name="Reyes08p263"/> It supported a room that measured {{convert|28.5|by|2.5|m|ft}} with three doorways.<ref name="Reyes08p263"/> The central door was {{convert|3.5|m|ft}} wide and the flanking doorways measured {{convert|1.2|m|ft}} wide.<ref name="Reyes08p263"/> The front of the building was dominated by a bench that ran the entire width of the structure and became a {{convert|9|m|ft|adj=on}} wide stairway descending to the patio and extending {{convert|1.5|m|ft}} from the platform.<ref name="Reyes08p263"/> The stairway had 3 steps, each with a height of {{convert|0.3|m|ft}} and a tread of {{convert|0.4|m|ft}}.<ref name="Reyes08p263"/> The first construction phase included a {{convert|1|m|ft|adj=on}} high wall that was later covered by the stucco floor of a small north-facing room.<ref name="Morales94371"/> On the east side of the structure, the walls were still found to stand to a height of {{convert|2.55|m|ft}}.<ref name="Reyes08p263"/> Structure 4 was deliberately demolished in antiquity.<ref name="Morales94371"/> The second construction phase extended the building to a size of {{convert|31|by|8.5|m|ft}}.<ref name="Reyes08p282">Reyes 2008, p.282.</ref> It supported three rooms with benches, the combined width of the rooms was {{convert|28.5|m|ft}} by {{convert|2.5|m|ft}}.<ref name="Reyes08p282"/> The same three doors from the earlier phase continued in use.<ref name="Reyes08p282"/>
'''Terrace 1 Structure 5''' is on the west side of Patio A.<ref name="Morales94374">Morales et al 1994, p.374.</ref> It consists of a single platform that is the highest in the entire acropolis.<ref name="Morales94374"/> It measures {{convert|19.5|by|6|m|ft}} and was {{convert|1.5|m|ft}} high.<ref name="Reyes08p264">Reyes 2008, p.264.</ref> Structure 5 was joined to Structures 1 and 4 since its earliest phase of construction.<ref name="Morales94374"/> Structure 5 was accessed by a projecting stairway that ascended the east side,<ref name="Morales94374"/> it measured {{convert|5.5|m|ft}} wide and protruded {{convert|2.6|m|ft}} from the platform.<ref name="Reyes08p264"/> The stairway joins a {{convert|2.25|m|ft|adj=on}} ''[[Talud-tablero|talud]]'' wall topped by a {{convert|0.8|m|ft|adj=on}} high cornice that projects {{convert|10|cm|in}} from the ''talud'' wall.<ref name="Morales94374"/> The walls of Structure 5 were built from finely dressed limestone blocks.<ref name="Morales94374"/> No trace of any superstructure was found on top of the platform, nor was any earlier substructure identified.<ref name="Morales94374"/> Only the lowest courses of limestone blocks were found to be still in place and it is believed that the upper courses were stripped in antiquity.<ref name="Morales94374"/> Finds made near the southeast corner of Structure 5 include a piece of a greenstone axe, two spherical stones, pieces of human bone (labelled as Burial 70) and a concentration of broken domestic ceramics.<ref name="Morales94374"/> These finds are believed to represent activity from the very end of the Terminal Classic prior to the abandonment of the site.<ref name="Morales94374"/> Burial 278, that of an infant, was found under the floor of Structure 5 and was dated to the Late Classic.<ref name="Reyes08p264"/>
=====Patio B===== [[File:El Chal 24.jpg|thumb|right|Structures on Terrace 1 of the acropolis]] '''Patio B''' was filled with a large amount of rubble in order to bring it up to the same level as the pre-existing Patio A, which lies immediately to the west.<ref name="Reyes08p288">Reyes 2008, p.288.</ref> It is an enclosed courtyard with an area of {{convert|768|m2|sqft}}.<ref name="Reyes08p288"/> Three structures were built upon the new patio, closing it on the north, east and south sides, while the west side was enclosed by Structures 1,2 and 3 of Patio A.<ref name="Reyes08p288"/>
'''Terrace 1 Structure 6''' is on the south side of Patio B.<ref name="Morales94374"/> It is a square platform with two stepped levels.<ref name="Morales94374"/> After the last phase of construction it had two benches on the top and a wide projecting stairway on the north side,<ref name="Morales94374"/> it measures {{convert|9|m|ft}} wide.<ref name="Reyes08p288"/> The structure measures {{convert|14.5|by|12.5|m|ft}},<ref name="Morales94374"/> the first bench measures {{convert|11|by|5|m|ft}} and the second {{convert|10|by|3|m|ft}}.<ref name="Reyes08p288"/> Various human bone fragments, representing pieces of three individuals, were excavated together with domestic ceramics.<ref name="Morales94374"/> A smaller second stairway jutted from the southeast corner of the building.<ref name="Morales94374"/> Structure 6 has been dated to the Late and Terminal Classic.<ref name="Reyes08p288"/>
'''Terrace 1 Structure 7''' is a low platform on the east side of Patio B.<ref name="Reyes08p290">Reyes 2008, p.290.</ref> It measured {{convert|22.5|by|4|m|ft}} and stood {{convert|0.64|m|ft}} high.<ref name="Reyes08p290"/> Upon the platform was a {{convert|1.5|m|ft|adj=on}} wide bench, and a single {{convert|9.5|m|ft}} wide step lead down to the patio.<ref name="Reyes08p290"/> Excavations of the platform uncovered material that was dated to the Late Preclassic, Late Classic and Terminal Classic.<ref name="Reyes08p290"/> Structure 7 was the last to be built on Patio B, postdating the construction of Structures 6 and 8.<ref name="Reyes08p291">Reyes 2008, p.291.</ref>
'''Terrace 1 Structure 8''' is on the north side of Patio B.<ref name="Reyes08p291"/> It is a rectangular platform measuring {{convert|18|by|8.5|m|ft}} with a {{convert|5|m|ft|adj=on}} wide south-facing embedded stairway.<ref name="Reyes08p291"/> The structure was not completely explored due to the dense vegetation covering it.<ref name="Reyes08p291"/>
=====Patio C===== '''Patio C''' was added to Terrace 1 at the same time as Patio B, using a large amount of rubble to extend the terrace.<ref name="Reyes08p331">Reyes 2008, p.331.</ref> It is to the northwest of Patio A and is slightly lower than it.<ref name="Valle08p349">Valle 2008, p.349.</ref> Patio C is bordered by 2 structures, on the north and west sides, with the West Structure being the largest.<ref name="Valle08p349"/> The fill beneath the patio has a depth of {{convert|6|m|ft}}, which was previously the height of the retaining ''talud'' wall of the northwest side of Patio A, as found during excavations.<ref name="Valle08p350">Valle 2008, p.350.</ref> Patio C had 2 construction phases and served an administrative function directly associated with the buildings of Patio A.<ref name="Valle08p350"/>
The '''West Structure''' contained a {{convert|1.2|m|ft|adj=on}} wide room accessed via a {{convert|0.7|m|ft|adj=on}} wide doorway.<ref name="Valle08p353">Valle 2008, p.353.</ref> The rear room of the structure contained a bench, or throne, that measured {{convert|2.4|by|2.95|m|ft}} and stood {{convert|0.45|m|ft}} high.<ref name="Valle08p353"/> Material recovered from the structure has been dated to the Late and Terminal Classic Periods, with a small amount dating to the Postclassic.<ref name="Valle08p354">Valle 2008, p.354.</ref>
The '''North Structure''' was a low platform that was covered with stucco and painted red.<ref name="Valle08p362">Valle 2008, p.362.</ref>
=====Patio D===== '''Terrace 2 Structure 1''' is on the north side of Patio D.<ref name="Corzo0582">Corzo et al 2005, p.82.</ref> It is a low rectangular platform measuring {{convert|2|m|ft}} high.<ref name="Corzo0582"/> Its walls rest upon the last surface layer of the patio and the structure's surface was littered with abundant Terminal Classic ceramic remains.<ref name="Corzo0582"/> A sunken stairway climbed the structure at a point {{Convert|10|m|ft}} from the southeast corner.<ref name="Corzo0582"/> The tread of the steps measured {{convert|0.5|m|ft}} deep while the risers measured {{Convert|0.2|m|ft}} high.<ref name="Corzo0582"/> During the Late Classic this structure apparently had an administrative function. However, by the Terminal Classic it was used as a domestic building, as evidenced by the abundant ceramics and stone artefacts recovered, the latter include a fragment of a ''[[metate]]'' milling stone, an obsidian knife and two flint knives.<ref name="Corzo0582"/>
[[File:El Chal 10.jpg|thumb|left|Unrestored pyramid on the acropolis]] '''Terrace 2 Structure 2''' is on the east side of Patio D.<ref name="Corzo0588">Corzo et al 2005, p.88.</ref> It was a {{convert|9|m|ft|adj=on}} tall pyramidal platform that did not possess a summit superstructure.<ref name="Morales495"/><ref name="Corzo0588"/> The upper east side of the pyramid has collapsed and looters' trenches on the west side were filled in by IDAEH in 1991.<ref name="Corzo0588"/> The walls possessed ''taluds'' and excavations uncovered traces of red paint.<ref name="Corzo0588"/> The stairway faced west onto Patio D, the treads measured {{convert|0.2|m|ft}} and the risers {{convert|0.25|m|ft}}.<ref>Corzo et al 2005, pp.73, 90.</ref> The stairway projected {{convert|1.3|m|ft}} into the patio from the pyramid.<ref name="Corzo0590">Corzo et al 2005, p.90.</ref> A burial cist was found near the front of the pyramid, it was labelled as Burial 264 and was dated to the Late Classic.<ref name="Corzo0589">Corzo et al 2005, p.89.</ref> The platform had five layers of stucco flooring.<ref name="Corzo0589"/> Material recovered during excavation of the stairway dated to the Terminal Classic.<ref name="Corzo0590"/>
'''Terrace 2 Structure 3''' encloses the west side of Patio D.<ref name="Corzo0593">Corzo et al 2005, p.93.</ref> Structure 3 does not face onto Patio D but rather is part of the Terminal Classic construction activity that extended Terrace 2 with the addition of Patio G.<ref>"Corzo et al 2005, pp.93-94."</ref> The structure measured {{Convert|7.8|m|ft}} from east to west.<ref name="Corzo0593"/> Excavated artefacts around the base have been dated to the Late and Terminal Classic.<ref name="Corzo0593"/> The stairway is on the west side, facing onto Patio G.<ref name="Corzo0594">Corzo et al 2005, p.94.</ref> The structure is believed to have been built in a single burst of activity in the Terminal Classic.<ref name="Corzo0594"/> It had two stepped levels and a north-south stairway was identified upon the summit of the structure.<ref>Corzo et al 2005, p.95.</ref>
=====Patio F===== '''Patio F''' is on a terrace at the same level as Patios D and E.<ref name="Valle08p368">Valle 2008, p.368.</ref> The patio is a closed courtyard formed by 5 structures on the west and south sides, while the other two sides are formed by the retaining walls of Patios A and C.<ref name="Valle08p368"/> The structures were residential buildings built upon low platforms, with the principal structure on the south side of the patio.<ref name="Valle08p368"/> A long, low platform on the west side supports two structures, labelled as Structures 1 and 2.<ref name="Valle08p368"/> Excavations of this platform recovered ceramic remains dating to the Late and Terminal Classic.<ref name="Valle08p370">Valle 2008, p.370.</ref>
'''Structure 1''' measures {{convert|19.3|m|ft}} north-south by {{convert|4.8|m|ft}} east-west and was built upon the same platform that supports Structure 2.<ref name="Valle08p368"/> The structure had a single room measuring {{convert|7.5|by|2|m|ft}}, which contained a bench.<ref name="Valle08p368"/>
'''Structure 2''' is to the south of Structure 1, resting upon the same basal platform.<ref name="Valle08p368"/> It measured {{convert|7.1|by|5.6|m|ft}} with a room measuring {{convert|4.44|by|1.66|m|ft}}.<ref name="Valle08p368"/>
'''Structure 3''' was built directly upon Patio F, and is therefore lower than Structures 1 and 2.<ref name="Valle08p370"/> It was on the southwest side of Patio F and measured {{convert|6.2|by|5.3|m|ft}} and had a {{convert|2.13|m|ft|adj=on}} wide projecting stairway extending {{convert|0.66|m|ft}} from the facade.<ref name="Valle08p370"/> Ceramics from the structure were largely dated to the Terminal Classic, with a few pieces dating to the Postclassic.<ref>Valle 2008, p.371.</ref>
'''Structure 4''' was located on the south side of Patio F.<ref name="Valle08p374">Valle 2008, p.374.</ref> Ceramics from the structure were dated to the Terminal Classic.<ref name="Valle08p374"/>
====East Plaza==== [[File:El Chal 13.jpg|thumb|right|The East Plaza]] The '''East Plaza''' covers an area of {{convert|6300|m2|sqft}},<ref name="Morales495"/> making it the largest open ceremonial space in the entire city.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap42"/> On its east side it is delimited by 2 medium-height structures (East Plaza Structures 1 and 2), on the south side by the base of the acropolis, on the west side by Structure 3 of the West Plaza and on the north side by the South Structure of the Northeast Plaza.<ref>Morales 1995, pp.494, 503. Reyes & Laporte 2005a, p.42.</ref> Six stelae and three altars were found in the East Plaza.<ref name="Morales94375">Morales et al 1994, p.375.</ref> The plaza had two construction phases, the first dated to the Late Classic and the second to the Terminal Classic.<ref name="Morales94375"/> A few Late Preclassic ceramic fragments were also recovered.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap42"/> The levelling of the East Plaza involved a considerable inversion of labour due to the limestone bedrock being extremely close to the surface at one side and {{convert|2|m|ft}} under the surface at the other.<ref name="Morales94375"/>
'''East Plaza Structure 1''' is on the east side of the plaza.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap42"/> In its final form it was a platform with two levels standing to a total height of {{convert|7|m|ft}}.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap43">Reyes & Laporte 2005a, p.43.</ref> It measured {{convert|20|m|ft}} north-south by {{convert|15|m|ft}} east-west.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap43"/> The structure had a {{convert|2|m|ft|adj=on}} wide stairway climbing from the plaza on the west side, the stairway was {{convert|10|m|ft}} long.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap43"/> The lower level was the main platform. It was built from finely dressed limestone blocks.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap43"/> The upper level was built of very poor quality limestone and is extremely badly preserved.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap43"/> A bench was built on top of the structure. It measured {{convert|8|by|3|m|ft}} with a protruding section measuring {{convert|3|by|5|m|ft}}.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap47">Reyes & Laporte 2005a, p.47.</ref> The bench was {{convert|25|cm|in}} high.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap47"/> A large number of flint chippings were excavated from the structure. They have been dated to the Late Classic.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap47"/>
'''East Plaza Structure 2''' is also on the east side of the plaza.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap42"/> It is a rectangular platform measuring {{convert|17|by|10|m|ft}} and facing westwards onto the plaza itself.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap48">Reyes & Laporte 2005a, p.48.</ref> A stairway climbs the west side of the building. It measures {{convert|12|by|1.2|m|ft}}.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap48"/> The platform supports a bench measuring {{convert|12|by|3|m|ft}}.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap48"/> The broken remains of Stela 6 are scattered in front of the structure.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap48"/> Relatively few ceramic remains were found associated with this structure. Those that were have been dated to the Terminal Classic, although a pit sunk into the summit uncovered remains dating to the Late Classic at a depth of {{convert|1|m|ft}}.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap50">Reyes & Laporte 2005a, p.50.</ref> Lithic artefacts included a piece of an obsidian knife.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap50"/>
====West Plaza==== [[File:El Chal 17.jpg|thumb|right|Fallen stela with associated altar in the West Plaza]] The '''West Plaza''' covers an area of {{convert|3500|m2|sqft}}.<ref name="Morales495"/> The south side of the plaza is formed by the north side of the acropolis and the plaza is also enclosed by four structures that measure more than {{convert|5|m|ft}} high.<ref name="Morales495"/> The highest structure is on the west side and measures {{convert|13|m|ft}} high.<ref name="Morales495"/> A {{convert|7.5|m|ft|adj=mid|-wide}} series of three steps stretched between the north wall of Structure 4 and the southwest corner of Structure 1 and gave access to the Northwest Plaza.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp110"/> These steps had a {{convert|0.5|m|ft|adj=on}} tread and were {{convert|0.2|m|ft}} high.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp110"/> Six monuments were found in the West Plaza.<ref name="Morales495"/> During the final phase of occupation during the Terminal Classic, refuse found at the base of the acropolis indicates that the West Plaza was occupied as a residential area, with the inhabitants using flimsy perishable structures.<ref name="Corzo0577">Corzo et al. 2005, p. 77.</ref>
'''West Plaza Structure 1''' is on the north side of the West Plaza, near the northwest corner.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap51">Reyes & Laporte 2005a, p.51.</ref> The structure faces southwards onto the plaza and has a stairway that measures {{convert|12|by|3|m|ft}} climbing the front of the building.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap51"/> The final version of the structure measured {{convert|27|by|20|m|ft}}.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap51"/> A bench on the summit of the structure measures {{convert|22|by|4|m|ft}}.<ref>Reyes & Laporte 2005a, pp. 51-52.</ref> The structure has two phases of construction, the earliest of which dates to the Late Classic.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap52">Reyes & Laporte 2005a, p. 52.</ref>
