'''West Plaza Structure 2''' is on the north side of the West Plaza.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap51"/> It is a rectangular platform measuring {{convert|27|by|20|m|ft}} with a projecting stairway on the south side that measures {{convert|12|by|3|m|ft}}.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap56">Reyes & Laporte 2005a, p. 56.</ref> It is the only building on the West Plaza that did not possess a bench upon the summit.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap56"/> A number of potsherds dating to the Terminal Classic were recovered from the front of the platform.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap56"/>
[[File:El Chal 20.jpg|thumb|left|West Plaza Structure 3 seen from the East Plaza]] '''West Plaza Structure 3''' is on the east side of the West Plaza and separates it from the East Plaza.<ref name="Morales94378">Morales et al. 1994, p. 378.</ref> It is a rectangular building with a wide stairway climbing from the west.<ref name="Morales94378"/> The structure measures {{convert|38|by|18|m|ft}} and possesses a bench on the summit that measures {{convert|25|by|6|m|ft}}.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap58">Reyes & Laporte 2005a, p. 58.</ref> After its final construction phase the platform stood {{convert|4.45|m|ft}} high.<ref name="Morales94378"/> A pit sunk into the structure revealed the presence of two earlier substructures.<ref name="Morales94378"/> The first was {{convert|2.85|m|ft}} high and the second stood {{convert|3.15|m|ft}} high.<ref name="Morales94378"/> All three stages were filled with a rubble core, although the earliest stage consisted of larger pieces than the latter stages.<ref name="Morales94378"/> Various artefacts were recovered from the southwest corner of the final stage of the stairway, including pieces of flint, obsidian blades, ''metates'' (milling stones) and a large amount of domestic ceramics.<ref name="Morales94379">Morales et al. 1994, p. 379.</ref>
=====Structure 4===== '''West Plaza Structure 4''' is on the west side of the West Plaza and is the tallest structure at El Chal.<ref name="Morales94379"/> The platform measures {{convert|46|m|ft}} north-south and {{convert|30|m|ft}} east-west;<ref name="Morales94379"/> it has a rectangular base that was formed of three stepped sections.<ref>Morales 1994, p.379. Reyes & Laporte 2005b, p. 110.</ref> The lowest section measured {{convert|1.83|m|ft}} high with a {{convert|1.3|m|ft}} wide platform between its upper edge and the beginning of the second section.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp110"/> The middle section was {{convert|1.2|m|ft}} high with a {{convert|0.6|m|ft|adj=mid|-wide}} platform between its upper edge and the base of the upper section.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp110"/> The wall of the top section is poorly preserved with just two courses of stonework remaining in place.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp110"/> The sides of the structure have largely collapsed due to erosion, leaving the north side as the best preserved.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp110">Reyes & Laporte 2005b, p. 110.</ref> The stairway has not been positively identified but is believed to be a wide sunken stairway on the east side.<ref name="Morales94379"/> The broken fragments of Stela 1 were found at the base of this stairway.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp115"/>
The platform supported a long superstructure facing onto the West Plaza, as evidenced by the bases of its walls.<ref name="Morales94379"/> Originally the superstructure consisted of a single, long room but this was later subdivided; another room to the south was probably demolished at the same time.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp112"/> The floor of the superstructure is {{convert|11.5|m|ft}} above the level of the West Plaza.<ref name="Morales94379"/> The walls were {{convert|1.1|m|ft}} thick and the entrance doorway measured {{convert|2.5|m|ft}} wide.<ref name="Morales94379"/> This superstructure was divided into five rooms, each measuring {{convert|2.9|by|0.5|m|ft}}.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp111">Reyes & Laporte 2005b, p. 111.</ref> These rooms were completely sealed, and in some cases destroyed, by a layer of compact white soil during the Terminal Classic.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp111"/> The rooms were upon a low platform upon the summit and were accessed from the upper section of the basal platform via three steps measuring {{convert|22|m|ft}} wide, with a tread of {{convert|0.25|m|ft}} and a height of {{convert|0.3|m|ft}}.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp112">Reyes & Laporte 2005b, p. 112.</ref> Stucco fragments with traces of pigment indicate that the rooms were once painted.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp112"/>
'''Room 1''' was extremely poorly preserved and is the southernmost of the rooms.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp113">Reyes & Laporte 2005b, p. 113.</ref> Only one doorjamb and a portion of wall belonging to a rear bench were found during excavations.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp113"/>
'''Room 2''' is one of the best preserved of the rooms atop Structure 4.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp113"/> It measured {{convert|2.9|m|ft}} north-south by {{convert|0.5|m|ft}} east-west.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp113"/> The doorway to the room was {{convert|1.8|m|ft}} wide.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp113"/> The room has been dated to the Terminal Classic.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp113"/>
'''Room 3''' is the middle room of the superstructure.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp114">Reyes & Laporte 2005b, p.114.</ref> It was the only room not to have been sealed during the Terminal Classic and due to this is in a poor state of preservation.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp114"/> The room possessed a bench against the back wall the measured {{convert|0.2|m|ft}} in height and {{convert|1|m|ft}} wide.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp114"/>
'''Room 4''' was well preserved and is very similar to Room 5.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp114"/> It measured {{convert|2.9|m|ft}} north-south by {{convert|0.5|m|ft}} east-west,<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp114"/> the door was {{convert|1.8|m|ft}} wide.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp114"/> The bench of the room measured {{convert|0.6|m|ft}} high by {{convert|1|m|ft}} thick.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp114"/>
'''Room 5''' is of identical proportions as rooms 2 and 4.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp115">Reyes & Laporte 2005b, p.115.</ref> It was extremely well preserved, including the rear wall of the bench and the room was used as a model for investigations of the other rooms in Structure 4.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp115"/>
Some artefacts were recovered from the northeastern portion of the structure.<ref name="Morales94379"/> They included fragments of a ''[[metate]]'' and of a ''[[mano (stone)|manos]]'' (handstone for use with a ''metate'') and a large quantity of domestic ceramics.<ref name="Morales94379"/> Stela 1 and Altar 7 were found in front of Structure 4.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp108">Reyes & Laporte 2005b, p.108.</ref>
=====Ballcourt===== The '''[[Mesoamerican ballcourt|Ballcourt]]''' is on the north side of the West Plaza.<ref name="Morales495"/> It runs north-south and measures {{convert|18|m|ft}} long by {{convert|4.8|m|ft}} wide.<ref name="Morales495"/> The sides of the ballcourt measure approximately {{convert|4|m|ft}} high.<ref name="Morales495"/> These side structures supported rectangular stone benches.<ref name="Morales94379"/> The west structure has been damaged by a looters' trench and originally had a stairway that climbed the west side.<ref>Morales et al. 1994, pp. 379, 383.</ref> Sculpted blocks of stone were found on the benches of both side structures and once decorated the aprons of the ballcourt.<ref name="Morales94383">Morales et al. 1994, p. 383.</ref> The four surviving blocks bear geometric designs and parts of sculpted figures deity masks.<ref name="Morales94383"/> The stucco floor at the south end of the ballcourt was found to be well preserved.<ref name="Morales94383"/> The ballcourt has been dated to the Late Classic Period.<ref name="Morales94383"/>
====Northeast Plaza==== The '''Northeast Plaza''' covers an area of {{convert|850|m2|sqft}}.<ref name="Morales495"/> It is located to the north of the East Plaza.<ref name="Morales94384">Morales et al 1994, p.384.</ref> The Northeast Plaza is enclosed by four structures of similar size and form and was accessed from the northeast corner.<ref name="Morales495"/> The tallest structure measures {{convert|5|m|ft}} high.<ref name="Morales495"/> The four buildings completely enclose an area measuring {{convert|30|by|35|m|ft}}.<ref name="Morales9315"/> These four structures consist of stepped rectangular platforms and were built from finely dressed limestone blocks.<ref name="Laporte05212"/> Excavations revealed remains of the superstructure of the tallest structure, including rooms with different entrance doorways.<ref name="Laporte05212"/> Construction at the plaza dates to the Late Classic period.<ref name="Laporte05212"/>
'''Northeast Plaza Structure 2''' has a rectangular base.<ref name="Morales94384"/> The structure is believed to have had three stepped levels that were built with finely dressed stone blocks, some of which were decorated with a double-trapezoid design.<ref name="Morales94384"/> Some of the blocks were found to have a thin coating of cream-coloured stucco.<ref name="Morales94384"/> The rear of the structure has the form of a truncated pyramid.<ref name="Morales94384"/> The stairway and the upper parts of the structure were deliberately destroyed in antiquity, leaving only the lower courses of stonework in place.<ref name="Morales94384"/> The southeastern portion of the platform is the best preserved, where a ''talud'' wall stands to a height of {{convert|1.5|m|ft}}.<ref name="Morales94384"/> Structure 2 is believed to have faced onto the Northeast Plaza.<ref name="Morales94384"/> Ceramic remains were found on the east side of the platform and also where Structure 2 joins Structure 4.<ref name="Morales94384"/> Excavations of the upper platform revealed five layers of stucco flooring, all dating to the Late Classic.<ref name="Morales94384"/> Burial 67 was found deposited in a [[cist]] under the second layer, its location had been marked on that floor with a painted red circle.<ref name="Morales94384"/> Upon the top of the platform were found traces of a small ({{convert|0.5|m|ft|adj=on}} wide) room with doorways facing the east and west.<ref name="Morales94386">Morales et al 1994, p.386.</ref> The walls were {{convert|1.35|m|ft}} thick and their remains stand to a height of {{convert|35|cm|in}}.<ref name="Morales94386"/> The floor of the room slopes noticeably down to the east.<ref name="Morales94386"/>
====Northwest Plaza==== {{Maya civilization}} The '''Northwest Plaza''' covers an area of {{convert|3600|m2|sqft}}.<ref name="Morales495"/> It is enclosed by two structures, the largest of which is a pyramid on the west side.<ref name="Morales495"/> No monuments were found within the Northwest Plaza.<ref name="Morales495"/> The plaza occupies a privileged position at the centre of the city although it does not have a high concentration of structures.<ref name="Chocon08p400">Chocón 2008, p.400.</ref> Three construction levels have been identified within the Northwest Plaza, all of them date to the Late Classic.<ref name="Chocon08p401">Chocón 2008, p.401.</ref>
'''Northwest Plaza Structure 1''' has a rectangular base measuring {{convert|44|m|ft}} east-west by {{convert|25|m|ft}} north-south and standing {{convert|2.5|m|ft}} high.<ref name="Chocon08p403">Chocón 2008, p.403.</ref> The lowest level of the platform body has an inclining ''talud'' wall.<ref name="Morales94383"/> A {{convert|15|m|ft|adj=on}} wide stairway projects {{convert|2|m|ft}} from the wall of the structure.<ref>Chocón 2008, pp.401, 403.</ref> The stairways was built during the earliest construction phase of the plaza, rising from the lowest plaza level.<ref name="Chocon08p403"/> After the second surfacing of the plaza an unusual inclining ''talud''-style [[Dado (architecture)|dado]] was added to the stairway.<ref name="Chocon08p403"/> At the same time a small bench-type structure was attached to the west side of the platform in order to widen the lower level of the building.<ref>Morales 1994, p.383. Chocón 2008, p.403.</ref> The small blocks used in this extension contrast with the large, finely dressed blocks used in the main structure.<ref name="Chocon08p403"/> Potsherds recovered from the structure mainly represent Late to Terminal Classic utilitarian wares, with additional fragments representing a Postclassic occupation of the structure.<ref>Chocón 2008, pp.403-404.</ref>
'''Northwest Plaza Structure 2''' is a {{convert|5.5|m|ft|adj=on}} high pyramid on the west side of the plaza.<ref>Chocón 2008, pp.400, 404, 408.</ref> Its base measures {{convert|30|by|24|m|ft}}.<ref name="Chocon08p408"/> The architectural quality of the pyramid was poor, as demonstrated by the small, irregular blocks used in construction, and it has been badly damaged by the collapse of its sides.<ref name="Chocon08p404"/> These blocks average {{convert|10|cm|in}} on each side.<ref name="Chocon08p406">Chocón 2008, p.406.</ref> The pyramid has also been damaged by a looters' pit on the west side of the structure.<ref name="Chocon08p408">Chocón 2008, p.408.</ref> Architectural detail has been largely obliterated by the pyramid's poor state of preservation, but inset corners have been identified on the north and south sides.<ref name="Chocon08p408"/> Surface ceramic finds all date to the Terminal Classic.<ref name="Chocon08p408"/> Artefacts recovered include portions of a ceramic [[Censer|incense burner]] and broken obsidian [[prismatic blade]]s.<ref name="Chocon08p408"/>
====Southeast Plaza==== '''Southeast Plaza Structure 1''' is a rectangular platform with at least two levels.<ref name="Morales94383"/> It has been dated to the Late Classic Period.<ref name="Morales94383"/>
====Groups 13 and 15==== '''Group 13''' and '''Group 15''' are located just outside the protected archaeological zone, opposite the custodian's house.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap58"/> Group 15 is situated immediately north of Group 13 and some structures are shared by both groups.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap59"/> Ceramic fragments recovered from the two groups have been dated to the Late Preclassic, Late Classic, Terminal Classic and Postclassic, with the majority dating to the Terminal Classic.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap59">Reyes & Laporte 2005a, p.59.</ref>
'''Group 15 Structure 2''' is a rectangular platform with a projecting stairway.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap60">Reyes & Laporte 2005a, p.60.</ref> It measures {{convert|18|by|7.2|m|ft}} with a projecting stairway that measures {{convert|9|by|1.2|m|ft}}.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap60"/> A few domestic ceramics were recovered during excavations.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap60"/>
'''Group 15 Structure 5''' was found to have a [[midden]] near the northwest corner from which were excavated a large amount of Terminal Classic potsherds together with a few pieces dating to the Postclassic Period.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap60"/>
====Group 18==== This group is a residential group to the northeast of the site core.<ref name="Morales94386"/> Four low structures were built upon a basal platform, largely clustered on the east side.<ref name="Morales94386"/> The plaza area had an area of {{convert|300|m2|sqft}}.<ref name="Morales94386"/> The plaza had two construction phases, the earliest dating to the Late Preclassic Period and the second to the Late Classic.<ref name="Morales94386"/> Burial 68 was found in the centre of the plaza, under the earlier floor level.<ref name="Morales94388"/>
'''Group 18 Structure 1''' is on the north side of the plaza.<ref name="Morales94387">Morales et al 1994, p.387.</ref> It was severely damaged when a modern street was laid out, cutting through its north side.<ref name="Morales94386"/> Only the south wall remains.<ref name="Morales94386"/>
'''Group 18 Structure 2''' is on the east side of the plaza.<ref name="Morales94387"/> Its earliest phase dates to the Late Preclassic.<ref name="Morales94387"/> The Preclassic remains consist of a low north wall running east-west.<ref name="Morales94387"/> A later construction phase was built over this. It consisted of a rectangular platform that supported a bench.<ref name="Morales94388">Morales et al 1994, p.388.</ref> A small [[pyrite]] disc was found near the front wall.<ref name="Morales94388"/> Obsidian prismatic blades were found on top of the platform, together with pieces of a thin earthenware bowl.<ref name="Morales94388"/> Burial 69 was found in front of the base of the platform.<ref name="Morales94388"/>
'''Group 18 Structure 3''' is a rectangular platform located on the south side of the plaza.<ref name="Morales94387"/> The core consists of large pieces of rubble that suggest some kind of older substructure.<ref name="Morales94388"/> The platform has been dated to the Late Classic.<ref name="Morales94388"/>
'''Group 18 Structure 4''' is situated on the west side of the plaza.<ref name="Morales94387"/>
====Group 21==== This group is located to the north of the reservoir.<ref name="Morales94388"/> The layout of the group is difficult to discern due to destruction caused by the construction of a street, although two low structures survive.<ref name="Morales94388"/> Group 21 is distinguished by being the only group outside of the ceremonial centre of the city to possess stone monuments, the badly eroded Stela 10 and Altar 6.<ref name="Morales94388"/>
====Other structures==== The various minor residential groups, including Groups 7 through to 12, were formed by clusters of very small structures with platforms not exceeding {{convert|1|m|ft}} in height.<ref name="Morales499">Morales 1995, p.499.</ref> Groups 4 to 6, 13 to 17, 20 to 24, 26 and 52 all date to the Late and Terminal Classic.<ref name="Morales94390">Morales et al 1994, p.390.</ref> Late Preclassic ceramics were recovered from Group 23.<ref name="Morales94390"/>
===Municipal Sector and E-Group=== The '''Municipal Sector''' is the area north of the highway running from Flores to Dolores.<ref name="Quezada983">Quezada et al 1998, p.3.</ref> Part of this sector actually falls within the municipality of Santa Ana.<ref name="Quezada983"/> Eighteen residential groups have been mapped in this sector.<ref name="Quezada983"/> These residential groups are clustered around a group of larger structures forming an [[E-Group]] ceremonial complex, located {{convert|2|km|mi}} from the site core.<ref name="Quezada983"/>
The '''E-Group''' consists of a number of structures around a small plaza.<ref name="Quezada9811"/> These include a pyramid at the west side, a long structure on the east side supporting an upper platform and two smaller structures on the north and south sides.<ref>Quezada et al 1998, pp.4, 11.</ref> The E-Group was first built in the Late Preclassic Period, it was lightly occupied during the Early Classic and was then expanded with the addition of two structures in the Late Classic.<ref name="Quezada9811"/> By this time major activity at El Chal had been transferred to the area around the acropolis, leaving the once central E-Group on the periphery.<ref name="Quezada9812">Quezada et al 1998, p.12.</ref>
The '''East Platform''' of the E-Group has produced ceramics dating to the Late Preclassic, Early Classic and Late Classic.<ref name="Quezada987">Quezada et al 1998, pp.7-8.</ref> The East Platform was built from limestone blocks and was accessed via a stairway at the rear of the building that projected {{convert|6|m|ft}}.<ref>Quezada et al 1998, pp.7,11.</ref> This stairway climbed a {{convert|9|m|ft|adj=on}} wide projection from the rear of the building.<ref name="Quezada9811"/> The east platform does not support the usual lateral structures found at E-Groups, with the Central Platform being the only upper platform upon the basal platform.<ref name="Quezada9811"/>
The '''Central Platform''' of the E-Group is situated upon the middle section of the East Platform.<ref name="Quezada9811"/> It has produced ceramics dated to the Late Preclassic.<ref name="Quezada989">Quezada et al 1998, p.9.</ref> The platform has a total height of {{convert|8|m|ft}}.<ref name="Quezada9811">Quezada et al 1998, p.11.</ref>
The '''West Pyramid''' of the E-Group produced ceramic evidence dating the Late Preclassic, Early Classic and Late Classic.<ref name="Quezada989"/> Although the limestone blocks used for its construction are very poorly preserved, the West Pyramid is believed to have been a radial pyramid dating to the Late Preclassic Period.<ref name="Quezada9811"/>
The '''North Structure''' of the E-Group has not been securely dated but is believed to date to the Late Classic, based on comparisons with E-Groups at other Maya cities.<ref name="Quezada9811"/>
The '''South Structure''' of the E-Group has not been securely dated but is also believed to have been built in the Late Classic.<ref name="Quezada9811"/>
===Arrepentimiento Sector=== The '''Arrepentimiento Sector''' is located beside the highway running from El Chal to [[Santa Elena, El Petén|Santa Elena]].<ref name="Quezada9815">Quezada et al 1998, p.15.</ref> It contains about 40 groups of structures concentrated upon karstic hills, with lesser occupation in low-lying areas.<ref name="Quezada9815"/> Settlement extends northwards from the highway for about {{convert|600|m|ft}} until the dry riverbed of the Río El Chal.<ref name="Quezada9815"/> The majority of the architectural groups are located among cattle pasture.<ref name="Quezada9815"/> Some of the groups have been heavily looted, mostly those groups covered by dense vegetation.<ref name="Quezada9815"/> Those groups in open pasture have not been subject to looting but have suffered from the stripping of their stonework in order to use it in modern construction.<ref name="Quezada9815"/>
The arhcitectural groups of the Arrepentimiento Sector are residential in nature, with low platforms measuring between {{convert|10|and|40|cm|in}} high laid out around patios with alignments of uncut stones.<ref name="Quezada9815"/> The structures in these groups date to the Late Classic.<ref name="Quezada9815"/>
The North Mound of Group 1 and the South Mound of Group 2 are the only structures that are greater than {{convert|1|m|ft}} in height.<ref name="Quezada9815"/>
===Panorama Sector=== [[File:Petén savannah 1.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Petén savanna used for cattle ranching, similar to the terrain of Panorama Sector]] This sector is located within the lands owned by Finca Panorama, some {{convert|3|km|mi}} from El Chal along the highway towards Santa Elena.<ref name="Quezada9815"/> The altitude is very close to that of the site core, averaging {{convert|270|m|ft}} above mean sea level.<ref name="Quezada9815"/> Panorama Sector occupies an area of cattle pasture with very few trees but a great many [[Attalea cohune|Corozo Palms]], the fruit of which is used locally to produce [[Vegetable fats and oils|vegetable oil]].<ref name="Quezada9815"/> The northern part of the sector possesses a number of hills upon which residential groups were built, while towards the south the land descends towards an area of unoccupied seasonal swamps.<ref name="Quezada9815"/> Panorama Sector possesses 53 architectural groups, 34 of which are in the periphery, together with a [[sacbe|causeway]].<ref>Quezada et al 1998, pp.15-16.</ref>
Of the ceramic fragments recovered from Panorama Sector, 374 pieces have been dated to the Late Classic, representing 62% of the total ceramics found in the sector.<ref name="Quezada9817"/> The vast majority of these are domestic in nature.<ref name="Quezada9817"/> 234 pieces were dated to the Terminal Classic, representing the remaining 38%.<ref name="Quezada9818">Quezada et al 1998, p.18.</ref>
'''Group 4''' is located {{convert|80|m|ft}} west of Group 1.<ref name="Quezada9816">Quezada et al 1998, p.16.</ref> It consists of three structures arranged around a courtyard that is open on the south side.<ref name="Quezada9816"/> Structure 1 is the largest structure in the group.<ref name="Quezada9816"/> Structures 2 and 3 have been looted.<ref name="Quezada9816"/> The group has been dated to the Late Classic Period.<ref name="Quezada9816"/>
'''Group 5''' is {{convert|500|m|ft}} southwest of Group 1.<ref name="Quezada9816"/> It consists of three structures laid out around a patio that is open of the east side.<ref name="Quezada9816"/> Group 5 is dated to the Late Classic.<ref name="Quezada9816"/>
'''Group 6''' is {{convert|30|m|ft}} south of Group 1.<ref name="Quezada9816"/> Like Group 5 it consists of three structures laid out around a courtyard that is open on the east side.<ref name="Quezada9816"/> Group 6 is dated to the Late Classic.<ref name="Quezada9816"/>
'''Group 7''' is located on a hillside to the east of Group 15.<ref name="Quezada9816"/> It consists of five structures completely enclosing a patio.<ref name="Quezada9816"/> Structure 1, on the north side, and Structure 5, on the west side, are the largest structures in the group.<ref name="Quezada9816"/> Structures 1, 2 and 3 have all been looted.<ref name="Quezada9816"/> Group 7 dates to the Late Classic Period.<ref name="Quezada9816"/>
'''Group 9''' is {{convert|20|m|ft}} south of Group 7.<ref name="Quezada9816"/> It consists of 5 structures, four of them are small while the west structure is larger.<ref name="Quezada9816"/> This group is dated to the Late Classic.<ref name="Quezada9816"/>
'''Group 10''' is on a hillside to the southeast of Group 9.<ref name="Quezada9816"/> It consists of four structures forming an enclosed patio group and dates to the Late Classic.<ref name="Quezada9816"/>
'''Group 15A''' is located on an artificial platform formed by levelling a natural elevation.<ref name="Quezada9816"/> The group is formed of six structures, four of these are large and enclose a patio.<ref name="Quezada9816"/> Two smaller structures are located to the southeast and southwest.<ref name="Quezada981617">Quezada et al 1998, pp.16-17.</ref> The group has been looted, recovered ceramics date to the Late and Terminal Classic.<ref name="Quezada9817">Quezada et al 1998, p.17.</ref>
'''Group 15B''' is situated on the south side of the same artificial platform that supports Groups 15A and 15C.<ref name="Quezada981617"/>
'''Group 15C''' is situated at the south end of the same artificial platform that supports Group 15A.<ref name="Quezada981617"/> It is composed of three structures arranged around a patio that is open on the north side.<ref name="Quezada9817"/> Group 15C has been dated to the Late Classic.<ref name="Quezada9817"/>
'''Group 16''' has not been excavated but is notable for a {{convert|70|m|ft|adj=on}} long causeway running north-south past its plaza.<ref name="Quezada9817"/> The causeway is {{convert|9|m|ft}} wide and bordered by {{convert|20|cm|in|adj=on}} high parapets.<ref name="Quezada9817"/> The original length of the causeway has not been determined.<ref name="Quezada9817"/> The plaza itself is bordered by the remains of walls that stand {{convert|15|to|20|cm|in}} high.<ref name="Quezada9817"/>
'''Group 19''' consists of three structures laid out around a patio that is open on the south side.<ref name="Quezada9817"/> The group has been tentatively identified as a stone workshop due to the great quantity of waste product found there, and it may have produced flint cores.<ref name="Quezada9817"/> Group 19 has been dated to the Terminal Classic.<ref name="Quezada9817"/> Stela 19 and Altar 9 were found {{convert|40|m|ft}} east of Group 9. They are the only monuments that have been found in Panorama Sector.<ref name="Quezada9817"/>
===Monuments=== Nineteen carved stone monuments were originally found at El Chal, all of which are badly eroded.<ref>Morales 1995, pp.494, 496.</ref> Various monuments are broken into fragments.<ref name="Morales496"/> Only five [[Maya stelae|stelae]] and three altars bore sculpted designs.<ref name="Morales496"/> The stelae exhibit a variety of forms but all the altars are circular.<ref name="Morales496"/> None of the [[Maya script|hieroglyphic texts]] found on the monuments of El Chal have yet been deciphered.<ref name="Morales496"/> The sculptural style of the monuments is similar to that of 8th century monuments from [[Sacul, El Petén|Sacul]], [[Ucanal]] and [[Naranjo]].<ref name="Morales499"/>
'''Stela 1''' was found at the west side the West Plaza, at the base of Structure 4.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp108"/> It was associated with Altar 7.<ref name="Morales496"/> The stela is broken into various fragments and was sculpted with a rectangular frame containing the portrait of a standing person with an elaborate feathered headdress, holding a staff in his right hand.<ref name="Morales496497">Morales 1995, pp.496-497.</ref> The figure is accompanied by a vertical hieroglyphic panel containing a [[Maya calendar|calendrical date]].<ref>Reyes & Laporte 2005b, p.117. Morales 1995, p.497.</ref> The text is badly eroded but the numbers 10 and 13 can be read.<ref name="Morales497">Morales 1995, p.497.</ref> The stela was resting upon the last construction phase of the plaza.<ref name="Morales497"/> Stela 1 measured {{convert|1.75|m|ft}} high by {{convert|1.5|m|ft}} wide and was {{convert|0.35|m|ft}} thick.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp115"/> The best preserved fragment, that possessing the sculpted portrait, was moved to the [[Museo Regional del Sureste de Petén]] ("Southeastern Petén Regional Museum") in Dolores in 2005.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp117">Reyes & Laporte 2005b, p.117.</ref> This fragment measured {{convert|1.75|m|ft}} high by {{convert|0.66|m|ft}} wide and was {{convert|0.35|m|ft}} thick.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp117"/> Five stela fragments were left where they had fallen, they contained parts of the frame and of the feathered headdress.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp117"/> The central pieces of the stela were not found during the excavations that took place in 2004 and 2005.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp117"/>
'''Stela 2''' was found in centre of the West Plaza.<ref name="Morales495497">Morales 1995, pp.495, 497.</ref> The butt of this stela was found in its original location, although the shaft has broken and fallen backwards.<ref name="Morales496497"/> Stela 2 does not appear to have had any sculpted designs or text.<ref name="Morales497"/> It was associated with Altar 1.<ref name="Morales497"/>
'''Stela 3''' was found in the West Plaza.<ref name="Morales495"/> Stela 3 was originally erected at the base of Structure 3.<ref name="Morales496497"/> It was sculpted with a rounded frame containing the figure of a person facing left and accompanied by a badly eroded and completely illegible hieroglyphic text.<ref name="Morales497"/> Stela 3 had been moved from its original location and was associated with Altar 2.<ref name="Morales497"/>
[[File:El Chal 3.jpg|thumb|right|Stela 4, front, showing a king standing upon three war captives. Altar 3 is in the foreground.]] '''Stela 4''' was found in the northern part of the East Plaza.<ref name="Morales497"/> It was the only monument at El Chal to have been sculpted on both sides and had been moved from its original location.<ref name="Morales497"/> Due to its sculptural style and its location, it is believed to have been associated with Altars 3 and 4.<ref name="Morales497"/> The upper portion of the front of the stela bears a hieroglyphic text with a calendrical date that has been interpreted as 9.16.10.0.0. 1 Ahau 3 Zip (17 March 761) together with the site's [[Maya script#Emblem glyphs|Emblem Glyph]].<ref name="Morales497"/> This side of the stela depicts a Maya [[Bloodletting in Mesoamerica|bloodletting ritual]] with a richly dressed person standing with legs apart standing on top of three sitting prisoners, the middle of which bears his own name written upon his left leg.<ref name="Morales497"/> The principal figure bears a spear topped by a serpent head with a flint spearhead emerging from it.<ref name="Morales497"/> This spear is very similar in style to one depicted on Stela 8 at [[Naranjo]].<ref name="Morales497"/> The reverse of the stela depicts three individuals standing upon a monster mask seen in profile.<ref name="Morales497"/> A child or youth is seated before two adult figures. All of them wear rectangular headdresses and hold something in their hands that cannot now be distinguished.<ref name="Morales497"/> Hieroglyphic texts are carved above the heads of the two standing figures and probably represent their names.<ref name="Morales497"/> The sculptural style of the two sides is different, and the foot-level of the standing figures on each side is different, with the figures on the reverse being positioned higher up the shaft than the figure on the front.<ref name="Morales497"/> This probably indicates that both sides were sculpted in situ at different times, with the reverse of the stela being crafted after the floor level of the plaza had risen to cover the base of the front side.<ref name="Morales497"/>
[[File:El Chal 6.jpg|thumb|left|Stela 5]] '''Stela 5''' was situated at the base of Structure 1 in the East Plaza.<ref name="Morales498"/> It was carved with a rounded frame containing a figure in profile facing to the left.<ref name="Morales498"/> The figure is standing with the legs together and is wearing a feathered headdress and bears a zoomorphic head on its back, from which hang more feathers.<ref name="Morales498"/> The hands of the figure are extended forward and appear to bear a staff of rulership.<ref name="Morales498"/> The stela bears a hieroglyphic panel with an incomplete dedicatory date that must fall within the range from December 740 to November 805.<ref name="Morales498"/> The text also contains the name of the king who dedicated the stela, Shield Jaguar, and the Emblem Glyph of El Chal.<ref name="Morales498"/>
'''Stela 6''', '''Stela 7''', '''Stela 8''' and '''Stela 9''' are all either fragments or butts of stelae that were removed in the 1970s by FYDEP and are now lost.<ref>Morales 1995, pp.494, 498.</ref> All of these stelae fragments are situated in the southern half of the East Plaza, with Stela 6 to the east and Stela 9 to the west.<ref name="Morales498"/>
'''Stela 6''' is broken into multiple pieces that are scattered at the base of East Plaza Structure 2.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap48"/> It was a plain limestone monument.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Ap48"/>
'''Stela 10''' was found in Group 21 together with Altar 6. They are among the very few monuments that were placed outside of the ceremonial centre of the city.<ref name="Morales498"/> Stela 10 was carved with a frame containing a figure, now badly eroded.<ref name="Morales498"/> The figure is standing with feet separated and turned outwards. Small hieroglyphic panels accompany it.<ref name="Morales498"/> Stela 10 had been moved from its original location, which was probably somewhere nearby.<ref name="Morales498"/>
'''Stela 11''' was found at the base of one of the structures in the Southeast Plaza, it was a plain monument.<ref name="Morales496498">Morales 1995, pp.496, 498.</ref> Stela 11 has fallen and is lying on its back.<ref name="Morales94383"/>
'''Stela 12''' was found with Altar 9 some {{convert|40|m|ft}} east of Group 19 and {{convert|350|m|ft}} south of the highway to Flores, in Panorama Sector.<ref name="Quezada9817"/> They are the only monuments to have been found in Panorama Sector.<ref name="Quezada9817"/> Stela 12 is a plain monument sculpted from limestone. It has fallen from its upright position and is half buried.<ref name="Quezada9817"/> It is broken in the middle and measures {{convert|2|m|ft}} long by {{convert|0.8|m|ft}} wide by {{convert|0.3|m|ft}} thick.<ref name="Quezada9817"/>
'''Altar 1''' was found in centre of the West Plaza, together with Stela 2.<ref name="Morales495497"/> This altar was found in its original location. It was a plain monument.<ref name="Morales496497"/>
'''Altar 2''' was found in the West Plaza, where it was associated with Stela 3 at the base of Structure 3.<ref name="Morales495497"/> Altar 2 was a plain monument and had been moved from its original location.<ref name="Morales497"/>
'''Altar 3''' was found in the northern part of the East Plaza, where it was associated with Stela 4.<ref name="Morales497"/> It was sculpted although it is now badly eroded.<ref name="Morales497"/> It bears the images of two seated anthropomorphic figures but further details cannot be distinguished.<ref name="Morales497"/>
[[File:Guate Sep-Oct 2010 813.jpg|thumb|right|The badly eroded Altar 4]] '''Altar 4''' is a circular monument.<ref name="Morales9315"/> It was also found in the northern part of the East Plaza and was associated with Stela 4.<ref name="Morales497498">Morales 1995, pp.497-498.</ref> It depicts three seated prisoners, the central figure is facing to the left while the other two are facing inwards towards him.<ref name="Morales498">Morales 1995, p.498.</ref> Hieroglyphic texts are carved underneath the prisoners and upon the sides of the altar.<ref name="Morales498"/> The altar has been dated on stylistic grounds to the latter part of the 8th century AD.<ref name="Morales498"/>
'''Altar 5''' was found in the East Plaza.<ref name="Morales497498"/> It has been broken into various pieces and is badly eroded but is believed to have been sculpted with a scene similar to that represented on Altar 4.<ref name="Morales498"/>
'''Altar 6''' is a plain monument that was found in Group 21 together with Stela 10.<ref name="Morales498"/> Like its associated stela it had been moved from its original location in antiquity but was probably not moved far.<ref name="Morales498"/>
'''Altar 7''' was found in the West Plaza at the base of Structure 4 together with Stela 1.<ref>Reyes & Laporte 2005b, pp.115, 117.</ref> The altar is plain, without sculpted figures or text and rests upon the last construction phase of the plaza.<ref name="Morales497"/> It was circular and measured {{convert|1.5|m|ft}} in diameter and was {{convert|0.5|m|ft}} high.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp117"/> It is broken in three parts.<ref name="ReyesLaporte05Bp117"/>
'''Altar 8''' was found in its original location in the Southeast Plaza.<ref name="Morales496498"/> It was a plain altar without signs of being sculpted.<ref name="Morales498"/> The monument is badly cracked.<ref name="Morales94383"/>
'''Altar 9''' was found with Stela 12 in Panorama Sector, near Group 19.<ref name="Quezada9817"/> It is located {{convert|10|cm|in}} from one end of Stela 12 and is also a plain monument.<ref name="Quezada9817"/> It is a circular altar, broken in fragments and half buried.<ref name="Quezada9817"/> It measures {{convert|60|cm|in}} in diameter and {{convert|45|cm|in}} thick.<ref name="Quezada9817"/> Only the upper {{convert|20|cm|in}} are exposed.<ref name="Quezada9817"/>
'''Altar 11''' was found in its original location.<ref name="Morales496"/>
'''Altar 19''' was found in its original location.<ref name="Morales496"/>
===Burials=== '''Burial 67''' was found in a cist under the second of five stucco floor levels in Northeast Plaza Structure 2.<ref name="Morales94384"/> The skeleton was lying on its back with the head towards the north.<ref name="Morales94384"/> The remains were poorly preserved but belonged to an adult.<ref name="Morales94384"/> Of the skull only some dental remains were found.<ref name="Morales94384"/> A ceramic plate had been placed under the head of the deceased and another plate was placed upon the knees.<ref name="Morales94384"/> The plate was painted with four seated anthropomorphic figures with inclined head and wearing leather gloves with jaguar claws.<ref name="Morales94384"/> The facial features of the figures are unusual.<ref name="Morales94384"/> The bottom of the plate bears the image of a dancer.<ref name="Morales94384"/> The ceramics date the burial to the Late Classic.<ref name="Morales94385">Morales et al 1994, p.385.</ref>
'''Burial 68''' was found in the centre of the Group 18 plaza.<ref name="Morales94388"/> The corpse was poorly preserved, it was laid out on its back with the skull towards the north.<ref name="Morales94388"/> The remains were covered with small pieces of limestone mixed with brown soil.<ref name="Morales94388"/> A piece of the upper jaw indicated that the remains were those of a child aged between 5 and 10 years old.<ref name="Morales94388"/> Four ceramic pieces were deposited as an offering; two plates, an earthenware bowl and a bowl.<ref name="Morales94388"/> Burial 68 is dated to the Late Preclassic.<ref name="Morales94388"/>
'''Burial 69''' was found in front of the base of Group 18 Structure 2.<ref name="Morales94388"/> The remains were extremely poorly preserved but the deceased may have been laid out on their back with the head towards the north.<ref name="Morales94388"/> Associated funerary offerings included a tripod plate, a polychrome vase and a flint projectile point.<ref name="Morales94388"/> The burial was securely dated to the Late Classic.<ref name="Morales94388"/>
'''Burial 264''' was found in a cist under the earliest level of the stucco flooring of Terrace 2 Structure 2, a pyramid on the acropolis.<ref name="Corzo0589"/> The cist was built from stone slabs and measured {{convert|0.7|by|0.6|m|ft}} by {{convert|1.4|m|ft}}.<ref name="Corzo0589"/> The human remains consist of some skull fragments and some pieces of the longbones, with the skull at the east end.<ref name="Corzo0589"/> The offering consisted of a ceramic pot with lid dated to the Late Classic period.<ref name="Corzo0589"/>
'''Burial 265''' was found at the base of the stairway of Terrace 1 Structure 2 in the acropolis.<ref>Reyes 2008, pp.255, 257.</ref> Ceramics associated with the burial have been dated to the Middle Preclassic Period.<ref name="Reyes08p255"/> This burial is the only evidence yet found of such early activity at the site.<ref name="Reyes08p257">Reyes 2008, p.257.</ref> It consists of the burial of a seated infant together with a newborn.<ref name="Reyes08p257"/> The burial was laid out upon a layer of large stones and was accompanied by a plate and other ceramics as a funerary offering.<ref name="Reyes08p257"/> The child's skull was found underneath the plate itself.<ref name="Reyes08p257"/> Burnt stones and earth were found next to the burial.<ref name="Reyes08p257"/>
'''Burial 278''' was that of an infant, deposited in a cist under the floor of Terrace 1 Structure 5 in the acropolis.<ref name="Reyes08p264"/> It was unaccompanied by any offering, the few ceramic fragments found associated with the cist were dated to the Late Classic Period.<ref name="Reyes08p264"/> The remains were laid out on their back, with the skull oriented to the south.<ref>Reyes 2008, p.268.</ref>

revision.text:
The [[English language]] is sometimes described as the ''[[lingua franca]]'' of computing. In comparison to other sciences, where [[Latin]] and [[Greek language|Greek]] are the principal sources of vocabulary, [[computer science]] borrows more extensively from English. Due to the technical limitations of early computers, and the lack of international standards on the [[Internet]], computer users were limited to using English and the Latin alphabet. However, this historical limitation is less present today. Most software products are [[Internationalization and localization|localized]] in numerous languages and the use of the [[Unicode]] character encoding has resolved problems with non-Latin alphabets. Some limitations have only been changed recently, such as with [[domain name]]s, which previously allowed only [[ASCII]] characters.
==Influence on other languages== The computing terminology of many languages borrows from English. Some language communities resist actively to that trend, and in other cases English is used extensively and more directly. This section gives some examples for the use of English terminology in other languages, and also mentions any notable differences.
===Bulgarian=== Both English and Russian have influence over [[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]] computing vocabulary. However, in many cases the borrowed terminology is translated, and not transcribed phonetically. Combined with the use of [[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]] this can make it difficult to recognize loanwords. For example, the Bulgarian term for [[motherboard]] is 'дънна платка' (IPA /danna platka/ or literally "bottom board").
* компютър /kompiutar/ – computer * твърд диск /tvard disk/ – hard disk * дискета /disketa/ – [[floppy disk]]; like the French disquette * уеб сайт /web sait/ – web site; but also "интернет страница" /internet page/
===Faroese=== The [[Faroese language]] has a sparse scientific vocabulary ''based on the language itself''. Many Faroese scientific words are borrowed and/or modified versions of especially Nordic and English equivalents. The vocabulary is constantly evolving and thus new words often die out, and only a few survive and become widely used. Examples of successful words include e.g. "telda" (computer), "kurla" (at sign) and "ambætari" (server).<ref>[http://www.fmn.fo/listar/teldord/teldord-f-e-d3.htm List of Faroese-English-Danish IT words]</ref>
===French=== {{see also|Franglais}} In [[French language|French]], there are some generally accepted English loan-words, but there is also a distinct effort to avoid them. In France, the [[Académie française]] is responsible for the standardisation of the language and often coins new technological terms. Some of them are accepted in practice, in other cases the English loanwords remain predominant. In Quebec, the [[Office québécois de la langue française]] has a similar function.
* ''email/mail'' (in Europe); ''courriel'' (mainly in [[French-speaking Canada]], but increasingly used in French-speaking Europe); ''mél.'' (only used as an abbreviation, similar to "tél."<ref>[http://www.academie-francaise.fr/questions-de-langue#26_strong-em-courriel-ml-em-strong "Questions de langue" on the Académie Française's website]</ref>); more formally ''courrier électronique'' * ''pourriel'' – spam * ''hameçonnage'', phishing – phishing * ''télécharger'' – to download * ''site web'' – website * ''lien'', ''hyperlien'' – website [[hyper-link]] * ''base de données'' – database * ''caméra web'', ''webcaméra'', short ''webcam'' – webcam * ''amorcer'', ''démarrer'', ''booter'' – to boot * ''redémarrer'', ''rebooter'' – to reboot * ''arrêter'', ''éteindre'' – to shut down * ''amorçable'', ''bootable'' – bootable * ''surfréquençage'', ''surcadençage'', overclocking – overclocking * ''refroidissement à l'eau'' – watercooling * ''tuning PC'' – [[case modding]]
=== German === {{see also|Denglisch}} In [[German language|German]], English words are very often used as well: * nouns: Computer, Website, Software, E-Mail, Blog * verbs: downloaden, booten, crashen
=== Icelandic === The [[Icelandic language]] has [[Icelandic vocabulary#Modern neologisms|its own vocabulary of scientific terms]], still English borrowings exist. English or Icelandicised words are mostly used in casual conversations, whereas the Icelandic words might be longer or not widespread.
=== Norwegian === It's quite common to use English words in regards to computing in all Scandinavian languages.
nouns: keyboard, webside, mail, software, blogg, spam
verbs: å boote, å spamme, å blogge
=== Polish === [[Polish language]] words derived from English: * ''[[wikt:dżojstik|dżojstik]]'': [[joystick]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sjp.pwn.pl/slownik/2562347/joystick|title=dżojstik|publisher=[[Polish Scientific Publishers PWN]]|work=[[Słownik języka polskiego]]|accessdate=26 September 2012}}</ref> * ''[[:pl:wikt:kartridż|kartrydż, kartridż]]'': [[wikt:cartridge|cartridge]] * ''[[:pl:wikt:interfejs|interfejs]]'': [[interface (computing)|interface]] * ''[[wikt:mejl|mejl]]'': [[e-mail]]
=== Russian === * [[History of computer hardware in Soviet Bloc countries]] * [[Computer Russification]]
=== Spanish === The English influence on the software industry and the internet in Latin America has borrowed significantly from the Castilian lexicon.
;Frequently untranslated, and their Spanish equivalent *email: ''correo electrónico'' *mouse (only in Latin America): ''ratón'' (mainly in Spain) *messenger: ''mensajero'' *webcam: ''cámara web'' *website: ''página web, sitio web'' *blog: ''bitácora'', 'blog' *ban/banned: ''vetar, vetado'' *web: ''red''
;Not translated *flog
;Undecided Many computing terms in Spanish share a common root with their English counterpart. In these cases, both terms are understood, but the Spanish is preferred for formal use: *link vs ''enlace'' or ''vínculo'' *net vs ''red''
== Character encoding == The early computer software and hardware had very little support for alphabets other than the Latin. As a result of this it was difficult or impossible to represent languages based on other scripts. The [[ASCII]] character encoding, created in the 1960s, only supported 128 different characters. With the use of additional software it was possible to provide support for some languages, for instance those based on the Cyrillic alphabet. However, complex-script languages like Chinese or Japanese need more characters than the 256 limit imposed by 8-bit character encodings. Some computers created in the former [[Soviet Union|USSR]] had native support for the Cyrillic alphabet.
The wide adoption of [[Unicode]], and [[UTF-8]] on the web, resolved most of these historical limitations. ASCII remains the de facto standard for command interpreters, [[programming language]]s and text-based communication protocols.
* [[Mojibake]] – Text presented as "unreadable" when software fails due to character encoding issues.
== Programming language == {{see also|Non-English-based programming languages}} The syntax of most programming languages uses English keywords, and therefore it could be argued some knowledge of English is required in order to use them. However, it is important to recognize all [[programming languages]] are in the class of [[formal languages]]. They are very different from any natural language, including English.
Some examples of non-English programming languages:
* [[Arabic language|Arabic]]: [[ARLOGO]], [[Qalb (programming language)|قلب]] * [[Bengali language|Bengali]]: [[BangaBhasha]] * [[Chinese language|Chinese]]: [[Chinese BASIC]] * [[Dutch language|Dutch]]: [[Superlogo]] * [[French language|French]]: [[LSE (programming language)|LSE]], [[WinDev]], [[Pascal (programming language)|Pascal (although the English version is more widespread)]] * [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]]: [[Hebrew Programming Language]] * [[Icelandic language|Icelandic]]: [[Fjölnir (programming language)|Fjölnir]] * [[Languages of India|Indian Languages]]: [[Hindawi Programming System]] * [[Russian language|Russian]]: [[Glagol]] * [[Spanish language|Spanish]]: [[Lexico]]
== Communication protocols == Many application protocols use text strings for requests and parameters, rather than the binary values commonly used in lower layer protocols. The request strings are generally based on English words, although in some cases the strings are contractions or acronyms of English expressions, which renders them somewhat cryptic to anyone not familiar with the protocol, whatever their proficiency in English. Nevertheless, the use of word-like strings is a convenient mnemonic device that allows a person skilled in the art (and with sufficient knowledge of English) to execute the protocol manually from a keyboard, usually for the purpose of finding a problem with the service.
Examples: * [[FTP]]: USER, PASS (password), PASV (passive), PORT, RETR (retrieve), STOR (store), QUIT * [[SMTP]]: HELO (hello), MAIL, RCPT (recipient), DATA, QUIT * [[HTTP]]: GET, PUT, POST, HEAD (headers), DELETE, TRACE, OPTIONS
It is notable that response codes, that is, the strings sent back by the recipient of a request, are typically numeric: for instance, in HTTP (and some borrowed by other protocols) * '''200 OK''' request succeeded * '''301 Moved Permanently''' to redirect the request to a new address * '''404 Not Found''' the requested page does not exist
This is because response codes also need to convey unambiguous information, but can have various nuances that the requester may optionally use to vary its subsequent actions. To convey all such "sub-codes" with alphabetic words would be unwieldy, and negate the advantage of using pseudo-English words. Since responses are usually generated by software they do not need to be mnemonic. Numeric codes are also more easily analysed and categorised when they are processed by software, instead of a human testing the protocol by manual input.
== Localization == {{see also|Internationalization and localization}}
=== BIOS === Many personal computers have a [[BIOS]] chip, displaying text in English during boot time.
=== Keyboard shortcut === [[Keyboard shortcut]]s are usually defined in terms of English keywords such as [[CTRL+F]] for [[Find (Unix)|find]].
== English on the World Wide Web == {{see also|Internet slang|Languages used on the Internet}} [[English language|English]] is the largest language on the [[World Wide Web]], with 27% of internet users.
=== English speakers === Web user percentages usually focus on raw comparisons of the first language of those who access the web. Just as important is a consideration of second- and foreign-language users; i.e., the first language of a user does not necessarily reflect which language he or she regularly employs when using the web.
==== Native speakers ==== English-language users appear to be a plurality of web users, consistently cited as around one-third of the overall (near one billion). This reflects the relative affluence of English-speaking countries and high Internet penetration rates in them. This lead may be eroding due mainly to a rapid increase of Chinese users.<ref>[http://blogs.guardian.co.uk/online/archives/2005/08/16/english_grip_on_internet_being_eroded.html English grip on internet being eroded | Technology | Guardian Unlimited<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
First-language users among other relatively affluent countries appear generally stable, the two largest being German and Japanese, which each have between 5% and 10% of the overall share.
=== World Wide Web content === One widely quoted figure for the amount of [[web content]] in English is 80%.<ref>[http://www.englishenglish.com/english_facts_8.htm What percentage of the internet is in English?<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Other sources show figures five to fifteen points lower, though still well over 50%.<ref>{{cite web|title=Usage of content languages for websites|url=http://w3techs.com/technologies/overview/content_language/all|work=W3Techs.com|accessdate=30 December 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.verisign.com/press_releases/pr/page_029135.html |title=News |website=Symantec |accessdate=31 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051224063055/http://www.verisign.com/press_releases/pr/page_029135.html |archivedate=24 December 2005 |df= }}</ref><ref>[http://www.trnmag.com/Stories/2001/112101/English_could_snowball_on_Net_112101.html English could snowball on Net TRN 112101<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> There are two notable facts about these percentages:
The English web content is greater than the number of first-language English users by as much as 2 to 1.{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}}
Given the enormous lead it already enjoys and its increasing use as a ''lingua franca'' in other spheres, English web content may continue to dominate even as English first-language Internet users decline. This is a classic [[positive feedback loop]]: new Internet users find it helpful to learn English and employ it online, thus reinforcing the language's prestige and forcing subsequent new users to learn English as well.
Certain other factors (some predating the medium's appearance) have propelled English into a majority web-content position. Most notable in this regard is the tendency for researchers and professionals to publish in English to ensure maximum exposure. The largest database of medical bibliographical information, for example, shows English was the majority language choice for the past forty years and its share has continually increased over the same period.<ref>[http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?artid=1175804 Language and country preponderance trends in MEDLINE and its causes<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The fact that non-Anglophones regularly publish in English only reinforces the language's dominance. English has a rich technical vocabulary (largely because native and non-native speakers alike use it to communicate technical ideas) and many IT and technical professionals use English regardless of country of origin ([[Linus Torvalds]], for instance, comments his code in English, despite being from Finland and having Swedish as his first language).

[[File:The Garden of Earthly Delights by Bosch High Resolution.jpg|thumb|400px|''[[The Garden of Earthly Delights]]'' in the [[Museo del Prado]] in [[Madrid]], c. 1495–1505, by [[Hieronymus Bosch]]]] {{Fantasy}} '''Fantastic art''' is a broad and loosely defined [[art]] [[genre]].<ref name="jahsonic" /> It is not restricted to a specific school of artists, geographical location or historical period. It can be characterised by subject matter – which portrays non-realistic, mystical, [[mythical]] or [[folklore|folkloric]] subjects or events – and style, which is representational and naturalistic, rather than abstract - or in the case of magazine illustrations and similar, in the style of [[graphic novel]] art such as [[manga]].
Fantasy has been an integral part of art since its beginnings,<ref name="Schurian"/> but has been particularly important in [[mannerism]], [[magic realism|magic realist]] painting, [[romantic art]], [[Symbolism (arts)|symbolism]], [[surrealism]] and [[lowbrow (art movement)|lowbrow]]. In French, the genre is called le [[fantastique]], in English it is sometimes referred to as ''visionary art'', ''grotesque art'' or [[mannerism|mannerist art]]. It has had a deep and circular interaction with [[fantasy literature]].
The subject matter of Fantastic Art may resemble the product of hallucinations, and Fantastic artist [[Richard Dadd]] spent much of his life in mental institutions. [[Salvador Dalí]] famously said: "the only difference between me and a madman is that I am not mad".<ref>{{cite web|title=thinkexist.com |url=http://thinkexist.com/quotation/the_only_difference_between_me_and_a_madman_is/175604.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130804105007/http://thinkexist.com/quotation/the_only_difference_between_me_and_a_madman_is/175604.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=4 August 2013 |accessdate=4 August 2013 }}</ref> Some recent Fantastic Art draws on the artist's experience, or purported experience, of [[hallucinogenic drugs]].
The term '''Fantasy Art''' is closely related, and is applied primarily to recent art (typically 20th century onwards) inspired by, or illustrating, fantasy literature. The term has acquired some pejorative overtones.
Fantastic art has traditionally been largely confined to painting and illustration, but since the 1970s has increasingly been found also in photography. Fantastic art explores fantasy, imagination, the dream state, the [[grotesque]], visions and the uncanny,<ref name="Schurian">Schurian, Walter (2005) Beyond Mere Understanding. In: ''Fantastic Art'', Schurian, W. & Grosenick, U. (Ed.), [[Taschen]], p.6-25. {{ISBN|978-3-8228-2954-7}} (English edition)</ref> as well as so-called "[[Goth]]" art.
==Related genres== {{Speculative fiction|cTopic=Fantasy fiction}} Genres which may also be considered as Fantastic Art include the [[Symbolism (arts)|Symbolism]] of the [[Victorian era]], and [[Surrealism]]. Works based on classical mythology, which have been a staple of European art from the [[Renaissance]] period, also arguably meet the definition of Fantastic Art, as art based on modern mythology such as [[JRR Tolkien]]'s [[Middle Earth]] mythos unquestionably does. [[Religious art]] also depicts supernatural or miraculous subjects in a naturalistic way, but is not generally regarded as Fantastic Art.
== Historic artists and fine artists == Many artists have produced works which fit the definition of fantastic art. Some, such as [[Nicholas Roerich]], worked almost exclusively in the genre, others such as [[Hieronymus Bosch]], who has been described as the first "fantastic" artist in the Western tradition,<ref name="Schurian"/> produced works both with and without fantastic elements, and for artists such as [[Francisco de Goya]], fantastic works were only a small part of their output. Others again such as [[René Magritte]] are usually classed as Surrealists but use fantastic elements in their work. It is therefore impossible to give an exhaustive list of fantastic artists, but a selection of major and influential figures is listed below.<ref name=jahsonic>{{cite web|title=Jahsonic, a vocabulary of culture|url=http://www.jahsonic.com/FantasticArt.html|accessdate=4 August 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Larkin|first=David (ed.)|title=Fantastic Art|year=1973|publisher=Pan Ballantine}}</ref> [[File:God kväll, farbror! Hälsade pojken.jpg|thumb|Illustration for ''The boy and the trolls'' by [[John Bauer (illustrator)|John Bauer]], 1915]] * [[Giuseppe Arcimboldo]] * [[John Bauer (illustrator)|John Bauer]] * [[William Blake]] * [[Arnold Böcklin]] * [[Hieronymus Bosch]] * [[Pieter Brueghel the Elder|Brueghel]] * [[Marc Chagall]] * [[Giorgio de Chirico]] * [[Richard Dadd]] * [[Salvador Dalí]] * [[Paul Delvaux]] * [[Monsù Desiderio]] * [[Gustave Doré]] * [[Max Ernst]] * [[Caspar David Friedrich]] * [[Henry Fuseli]] * [[Francisco de Goya]] * [[Hans Baldung|Hans Baldung Grien]] * [[Matthias Grünewald]] * [[Thomas Häfner]] * [[Max Klinger]] * [[Gustave Moreau]] * [[Giovanni Battista Piranesi]] * [[Arthur Rackham]] * [[Odilon Redon]] * [[Nicholas Roerich]] * [[Henri Rousseau]] * [[Yves Tanguy]] * [[Clovis Trouille]] * [[George Frederic Watts]]
==Twentieth century== The rise of [[fantasy]] and [[science fiction]] "pulp" magazines demanded artwork to illustrate stories and (via cover art) to promote sales. This led to a movement of [[science fiction]] and [[fantasy]] artists prior to and during the Great Depression, as anthologised by [[Vincent Di Fate]], himself a prolific SF and [[space]] artist.<ref>{{cite book|last=Di Fato|first=Vincent|title=Infinite Worlds: The Fantastic Visions of Science Fiction Art}}</ref>
In the United States in the 1930s, a group of Wisconsin artists inspired by the Surrealist movement of Europe created their own brand of fantastic art. They included [[Madison, Wisconsin]]-based artists Marshall Glasier, Dudley Huppler and [[John Wilde]]; Karl Priebe of [[Milwaukee]] and [[Gertrude Abercrombie]] of [[Chicago]]. Their art combined macabre humor, mystery and irony <ref>Sara Krajewski, “Surreal Wisconsin: Surrealism and its Legacy of Wisconsin Art,” Madison Art Center, 1998 http://members.aol.com/MenuBar/surreal/surreal.htm accessed 3/26/2003</ref> which was in direct and pointed contradiction to the [[American Regionalism]] then in vogue.
In postwar [[Chicago]], the art movement [[Chicago Imagism]] produced many fantastic and grotesque paintings, which were little noted because they did not conform to New York [[abstract art]] fashions of the time. Major imagists include [[Roger Brown (artist)|Roger Brown]], [[Gladys Nilsson]], [[Jim Nutt]], [[Ed Paschke]], and [[Karl Wirsum]].<ref name=Vine>Richard Vine, "Where the Wild Things Were", ''[[Art in America]]'', May 1997, pp. 98-111.</ref>

==Non-European Art== Non-European art may contain fantastic elements, although it is not necessarily easy to separate them from religious elements involving supernatural beings and miraculous events.
Sculptor [[Bunleua Sulilat]] is a notable contemporary Asian Fantastic artist.

'''Gavi Gangadhareshwara Temple''' also Gavipuram Cave Temple, an example of [[Indian rock-cut architecture]], is located in [[Bangalore]] in the state of [[Karnataka]] in [[India]]. The temple is famous for its mysterious stone discs in the forecourt and the exact planning allowing the sun to shine on shrine in certain time of the year. It was built in the 16th-century by [[Kempe Gowda I]], the founder of the city.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Shastry|first1=Vyasa|title=The mysteries of Bengaluru’s famed Gavi Gangadhareshwara temple|url=http://www.livemint.com/Sundayapp/X3uvXrojiRaPr31fhf6IQI/The-mysteries-of-Bengalurus-famed-Gavi-Gangadhareshwara-tem.html|work=Livemint|accessdate=2 March 2017|date=25 February 2017}}</ref>
==Temple== This cave temple dedicated to [[Shiva]] in Bengaluru is a well visited temple. Built in the 16th century AD by Kempe Gowda, the founder of Bengaluru, Temple Gavi Gangadhareshwara is an architectural marvel that attracts the faithful by the hordes. One of the oldest temples in Bengaluru, Gavi Gangadhareshwara temple was built by Kempe Gowda in recognition after being released from prison of five years by Rama Raya. There are other idols inside idol Agnimurthi including having two heads, seven hands and three legs. Those who worship this deity believe will cure one of the defects of the eye. The temple is also known for its four monolithic pillars, representing [[Damaru]], [[Trishula|Trishul]] and two fans on the patio.
Built in a natural cave in Gavipuram, the temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and cut into a monolithic stone. The courtyard of the temple here contains several monolithic sculptures. The main attractions of Gavi Gangadhareshvara temple are two granite pillars that support the giant disk of the sun and moon, while the other two have a number of Nandi at the top.
On the occasion of [[Makar Sankranti]], temple witnesses a unique phenomenon in the evening sunlight passes through an arc between the horns of [[Nandi (bull)|Nandi]] and falls directly on the [[linga]] inside the cave and illuminating the interior idol. This phenomenon is a proof of the technical excellence of the ancient architects.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.templenet.com/Karnataka/gavigang.html |title=Gavi Gangadhareshwara Temple at Bangalore(Karnataka) |publisher= |accessdate=2006-09-13 }}</ref>
== Illumination of shrine by the Sun == Thousands of devotees come in mid January every year on [[Makar]] [[sankranti]] Day to this cave temple. This is a special day when the sunrays fall on the [[Shivalinga]] for one hour as it passes between the horns of the [[Nandi (bull)|Nandi]]. Such was the knowledge of architecture and astronomy that the ancient sculptors could craft the horns of the stone bull outside the temple so that the sun's rays would pass through its horns and light up the deity [[Shiva]] [[Linga]] inside the cave.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tourtravelworld.com/hot_spots/bangalore/gavi_gangadhareshwara_temple/ |title=About Gavi Gangadhareshwara Temple |publisher= |accessdate=2006-09-13 }}</ref> Comparison of contemporary structures and earlier drawings by [[Thomas Daniell]] and William Daniell show that earlier the temple has less structures and the Sun illuminated the shrine in summer and winter solstice.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.currentscience.ac.in/Downloads/article_id_095_11_1632_1636_0.pdf |title=Astronomical Significance of the Gavi Gangadhareshwara temple in Bangalore |publisher=Current Science, Vol.95, No. 11, 10 December 2008. |accessdate=2010-06-18 }}</ref> Also today the Sun illuminates Shivalinga two times per year - from 13 to 16 January in late afternoons and from 26 November to 2 December.
==Protected temple== The temple shrine is a protected monument under the ''Karnataka Ancient and Historical Monuments, and Archaeological Sites and Remains Act 1961''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Gavi Gangadhareshwara Temple, Bangalore|url=http://www.bengaloorutourism.com/gavi-gangadhareshwara-temple.php}}</ref> and many more temples which are of great importance for the Indian culture
==Specialities== People believe that there is a tunnel which may lead to Kashi. However there are no sources to support this.
==Nearby holy places ==
* Gosaayi Math *Just behind the temple of Gavi Gangadhareshwara temple, there is a samadhi of a great yogi called Bet [[Narayan Maharaj]]. * Sri Bande Mahakali Temple

{{other uses2|Gord}} [[File:Groß Raden.jpg|thumb|right|Reconstructed [[West Slavs|West Slavic]] [[Groß Raden Archaeological Open Air Museum|fortified settlement (gord) in Groß Raden]], Germany]] [[File:Grod birow wejscie.JPG|thumb|Section of reconstructed fortifications at [[Birów]] near [[Ogrodzieniec]], Poland]] [[File:Gród na górze Birów 2.JPG|thumb|Part of reconstructed fortifications at Birów]] [[Image:Stara Rawa grodzisko01.jpg|thumb|''Grodzisko'' in Stara Rawa, Poland]] [[Image:Gorod PL.PNG|thumb|right|Towns and villages in Poland with names derived from ''gród'' (pink circles)]] [[Image:Pmaww7 DSC1547.JPG|thumb|Model of Bródno gord in [[National Museum of Archaeology (Poland)|National Museum of Archaeology]] in [[Warsaw]]]] A '''gord''' is a [[Middle Ages|medieval]] [[Slavs|Slavic]] fortified wooden settlement, sometimes known as a '''burgwall''' after the [[German language|German]] term for such sites. Gords were built during the late [[Bronze Age|Bronze]] and early [[Iron Age]]s by the [[Lusatian culture]] (c. 1300–500 [[Common Era|BCE]]), and later in the 8th–7th centuries BCE, in what is now [[Poland]], the [[Czech Republic]], [[Hungary]], [[Slovakia]], eastern [[Germany]], [[Romania]]/[[Moldova]], [[Belarus]] and western [[Ukraine]]. These settlements were usually founded on strategic sites such as hills, riverbanks, lake islands, or peninsulas.
==Construction and evolution==
A typical gord was a group of wooden houses built either in rows or in circles, surrounded by one or more rings of walls made of earth and wood, a [[palisade]], and/or [[moat]]s. Some gords were ring-shaped, with a round, oval, or occasionally polygonal fence or wall surrounding a hollow. Others, built on a natural hill or a man-made mound, were cone-shaped. Those with a natural defense on one side, such as a river or lake, were usually horseshoe-shaped. Most gords were built in densely populated areas on sites that offered particular natural advantages.
As Slavic tribes united to form states, gords were also built for defensive purposes in less-populated border areas. Gords in which rulers resided or that lay on trade routes quickly expanded. Near the gord, or below it in elevation, there formed small communities of servants, merchants, artisans, and others who served the higher-ranked inhabitants of the gord. Each such community was known as a ''suburbium'' ({{lang-pl|podgrodzie}}). Its residents could shelter within the walls of the gord in the event of danger. Eventually the ''suburbium'' acquired its own fence or wall. In the [[High Middle Ages]], the gord usually evolved into a [[castle]] or [[citadel]] ([[Kremlin (fortification)|kremlin]]) and the ''suburbium'' into a [[town]].
Some gords did not stand the test of time and were abandoned or destroyed, gradually turning into more or less discernible mounds or rings of earth ([[Russian language|Russian]] ''gorodische,'' [[Polish language|Polish]] ''grodzisko,'' [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] ''horodyshche,'' [[Slovak language|Slovak]] ''hradisko,'' [[Czech language|Czech]] ''hradiště,'' and [[Serbian language|Serbian]] ''gradiška''/''градишка''). Notable archeological sites include [[Biskupin]], Poland; and Bilsk, Ukraine (see [[Gelonus]]).
==Etymology==
The term ultimately descends from the reconstructed [[Proto-Indo-European]] root ''[[wikt:Reconstruction:Proto-Indo-European/ǵʰortós|ǵʰortós]]'', enclosure. From this same root come the [[Germanic languages|Germanic]] word elements *''gard'' and *''gart'' (as in [[Stuttgart]]), and likely also the names of [[Graz]], [[Austria]] and [[Gartz]], [[Germany]]. Cognate to these are English words such as ''yard'', ''garth'', ''girdle,'' and ''court.''<ref>ON. ''garðr''; goth. gards; den. -gaard; island. -gard; cimb. -garthur; aleman. -gardo; welsh. -gardd; holln. -gaerde; span. -gardin; pomern. -gard; slav. -grod, -hrad</ref><ref>A Concise Etymological Dictionary of the English Language. Oxford. 1911; Jane Chance. Tolkien and the invention of myth. [https://books.google.com/books?id=8LLxZXqgJdwC&pg=PA70&dq=gar%C3%B0r+gaard+gard&hl=pl&ei=OARyTeDGKs7JswaHo5mEDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=book-preview-link&resnum=7&ved=0CEsQuwUwBg#v=onepage&q&f=false . 70]</ref> Also cognate but less closely related are Latin ''hortus,'' a garden, and its English descendants ''horticulture'' and ''orchard''.
Further afield, in [[Greater Iran|ancient Iran]], a fortified wooden settlement was called a ''gerd'', which became ''jerd'' under later Arab influence. Burugerd or [[Borujerd]] is a city in the West of Iran. The Indian suffix ''-garh,'' meaning a [[fort]] in [[Hindi]], [[Sanskrit]], and other [[Indo-Iranian languages]], appears in many Indian place names.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/most/p2vidal.htm|title=Urban vocabulary in Northern India – City Words WP No. 4|website=www.unesco.org|access-date=2016-05-09}}</ref> Given that both Slavic and Indo-Iranian are sub-branches of Indo-European and that there are numerous similarities in [[Russian language|Russian]] vocabulary and [[Sanskrit]] vocabulary, it is plausible that ''garh'' and ''gorod'' are related, although this is strongly contradicted by the phoneme /g/ in Indo-Iranian, which cannot be a reflex of the Indo-European palatovelar /*ǵ/.<ref Name="RBTH">{{cite web|url=https://in.rbth.com/blogs/2014/11/01/sanskrit_and_russian_ancient_kinship_39451|title=Sanskrit and Russian: Ancient kinship|website=in.rbth.com|access-date=2016-05-09}}</ref>
The [[Proto-Slavic]] word ''*gordъ'' later differentiated into '''grad''' ([[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]]: град) and '''gorod''' (Cyrillic: город), etc.<ref Name="Taylor1898">{{cite book | last =Taylor | first =Isaac | authorlink =Isaac Taylor (canon) | title =Names and Their Histories: A Handbook of Historical Geography and Topographical Nomenclature | publisher =Rivingtons | year =1898 | location =Original from the University of Michigan | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=faxMAAAAMAAJ&dq=wall+Grad+gorod&cad=0 | doi = | page =331 }}</ref><ref Name="Taylor1864">{{cite book | last =Taylor | first =Isaac | authorlink =Isaac Taylor (canon) | title =Words and Places, Or, Etymological Illustrations of History, Ethnology, and Geography | publisher =Macmillan | year =1864 | location =Original from Oxford University | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=fxQLAAAAQAAJ&dq=wall+Grad+gorod&cad=0 | doi = | page =128 }}</ref><ref Name="Anthropologische">{{cite book | last =Anthropologische Gesellschaft in Wien | first = | authorlink = | title =Mittheilungen der anthropologischen Gesellschaft in Wien | publisher =F. Berger & Söhne | year =1880 | location =Original from the University of Michigan | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=HqcbAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA40&dq=Gord+wall+Grad+gorod| doi = | page =40 }}</ref> It is the root of various words in modern [[Slavic language]]s pertaining to fences and fenced areas (Ukrainian '''horod'''yty, Czech o'''hrad'''it, Russian o'''grad'''it, [[Serbo-Croatian]] o'''grad'''iti, and Polish o'''grad'''zać, '''grod'''zić, to fence off). It also has evolved into words for a [[garden]]: *[[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] ''город'' (horod) *[[Russian language|Russian]] ''огород'' (ogorod) *[[Serbian language|Serbian]], [[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]], and [[Macedonian language|Macedonian]] ''градина'' (gradina) *[[Serbian language|Serbian]] ''oграда''/''ograda'' *[[Polish language|Polish]] ''ogród'' *[[Slovak language|Slovak]] ''záhrada'' *[[Czech language|Czech]] ''zahrada''
Additionally, it has furnished numerous modern Slavic words for a [[city]] or town: *[[Russian language|Russian]] ''gorod'' *[[Pomeranian language|Ancient Pomeranian]] and modern [[Kashubian language|Kaszubian]] ''gard'' *[[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]], [[Croatian language|Croatian]], [[Macedonian language|Macedonian]], [[Slovene language|Slovene]], and [[Serbian language|Serbian]] ''град''(grad) *[[Slovak language|Slovak]] and [[Czech language|Czech]] ''hrad'' (the modern word for ''castle'') *[[Polish language|Polish]] ''gród''
The names of many Central and Eastern European cities harken back to their pasts as gords. Some of them are in countries which once were but no longer are mainly inhabited by Slavic-speaking peoples. Examples include: * [[Horodok (disambiguation)|Horodok]] * [[Gorod (toponymy)]] * [[Hrod (toponymy)]] * [[Harad (toponymy)]] * [[Hrud (toponymy)]] * [[Horod (toponymy)]] * [[Hrad (toponymy)]] * [[Gard (Slavic toponymy)|Gard (toponymy)]] * [[Grod (toponymy)]] * [[Grad (toponymy)]]
The Polish word for ''suburbium'', ''podgrodzie'', literally means a settlement beneath a town: the ''gród'' was frequently built at the top of a hill, and the ''podgrodzie'' at its foot. (The Slavic prefix ''pod-'', meaning "under/below" and descending from the Proto-Indo-European root ''[[wikt:Reconstruction:Proto-Indo-European/pṓds|pṓds]],'' meaning foot, is equivalent to Latin ''sub-''.) The word survives in the names of several villages ([[Podgrodzie, Subcarpathian Voivodeship]]) and town districts (e.g., that of [[Olsztyn]]), as well as in the names of the German municipalities [[Puttgarden]], [[Wagria]] and [[Putgarten]], [[Rügen]].
== Important gords in Europe ==

'''Grace Marion Jantzen''' (May 24, 1948 – May 2, 2006) was a [[Canadian people|Canadian]] [[Feminist philosophy|feminist philosopher]] and [[Feminist theology| theologian]]. She was professor of [[religion]], [[culture]] and [[gender]] at [[Manchester University]] from 1996 until her death from cancer at the age of 57.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/deaths/grace-jantzen-academic-1948-2006/article318933|location=Toronto|work=The Globe and Mail|title=Grace Jantzen (1948-2006)|date=March 17, 2009}}</ref>
In ''Becoming Divine: Towards a Feminist Philosophy of Religion'', Jantzen proposed a new [[philosophy of religion]] from a feminist perspective. She also authored works on Christian mysticism and the foundations of modernity. Her approach was influenced by Continental scholarship, particularly that of [[Michel Foucault|Foucault]].<ref Name="Guardian">{{cite news|last=Carrette|first=Jeremy|title=Grace Jantzen|work=Obituary|publisher=[[Guardian Unlimited]]|date=May 11, 2006|url=https://www.theguardian.com/obituaries/story/0,,1772262,00.html|accessdate=March 31, 2017|location=London, UK}}</ref><ref name="Feminist Theology">{{cite journal|title=Grace Jantzen (1948-2006)|journal=Feminist Theology|year=2006|volume=15|issue=1|url=http://intl-fth.sagepub.com/cgi/reprint/15/1/121.pdf|pages=121–23|doi=10.1177/0966735006071131}}</ref>
In her final publication, ''Foundations of Violence,'' Jantzen, sketches the fascination with death and violence -- what she calls a 'necrophilia' -- that she believes has characterized much of Western culture from classical antiquity through Christianity to present paradigms. In Jantzen's view, this emphasis on violence and death comes at the expense of the physical body in the present (a denigration of the senses, sexuality and sensuality), and thus, establishes a yearning for mystical worlds beyond the here and now.<ref>Cambridge Dictionary of Christianity, "Death, Feminist Views of" by [[Kathleen O'Grady]]. Daniel Patte (ed.), 2010.<!-- ISSN/ISBN, page(s) needed --></ref>
